Be prepared to be asked if you want a watch or handbag every five mins, don't be shy to say no, these people are keen but not aggressive. There is a spice and gold souk which is interesting, fruit juice stalls are nice and if you go late afternoon you can be sure of plenty of shade. It's a vibrant, Indian, Pakistani, Afghan, African mix. Well worth an afternoon. On the other side of the creek there is a heritage site which again is worth a look.Don't bother with the dinner cruises. I've never done one but they don't look up to much. Best get a small Abra and look at them lit up while you cut about the creek. The only thing you need to be aware of is the toilets are......rustic
Dhow Cruise. Very good place for Dhow cruise. We can see the beauty of the Dubai Creek when sit inside Cruise and watch. Food, Entertainment very good

Wow Boat ride in Dubai Creek. Dubai Creek or Khor Dubai (Arabic: خور دبي, Khawr Dubayy) is a saltwater creek located in Dubai, United Arab Emirates (UAE). It ends at Ras Al Khor Wildlife Sanctuary. Some sources say that the creek extended as far inland as Al Ain, and that the Ancient Greeks called it River Zara.[1] Historically, the creek divided the city into two main sections – Deira and Bur Dubai. It was along the Bur Dubai creek area that members of the Bani Yas tribe first settled in the 19th century, establishing the Al Maktoum dynasty in the city.[2] In the early 20th century, the creek, though incapable then of supporting large scale transportation, served as a minor port for dhows coming as far away as India or East Africa. Although it impeded the entry of ships due to current flow, the creek remained an important element in establishing the commercial position of Dubai, being the only port or harbour in the city.[3] Dubai's pearling industry, which formed the main sector of the city's economy, was based primarily on expeditions in the creek, prior to the invention of cultured pearls in the 1930s.

Dinner cruise. Ther are many dinner cruises along the creek that cruise the creek at night with music and dinner. Absolutely lovely. In the afternoon we walked along the creek admiring all the boats , and activity
wasted trip. Hated every minute of it, the food was disgusting the entertainment was rubbish. Could'nt wait to get back to the hotel and ther we stayed

lots of activity. The Dubai creek is a location with a great number of different things to do. Along the creek you will find evening dinner cruses, high end luxury hotels and shopping along side more traditional souks such as the gold souk.

Experience the flavors and sights of Old Dubai. For a mere 1 dirham do take the brief abra ride across the Dubai creek to the atmospheric Spice souk. Discover tiny stalls stocked high with multicolor, fragrant spices and sample chocolate coved dates and exotic seasonings. The busy dock sides on either side of the creek offer an authentic peek at the Dubai of the past where as a tourist you will be in the minority. There are longer boat rides of an hour + that cruise to the mouth of the creek where it enters the Arabian Sea.

Spend a Little Time in Old Dubai. We spent time on both shores of the creek, and although the constant harrassing of the guys in the souks can be tiring, it's much more of a real experience of the local culture (albeit mostly Indian or Iranian merchants) than any of the famous malls.
Great spot. Very nice light up at night ...took a water taxi ride which was very pleasant which took in various sites around the harbour.

Unique Beautiful Experience . After spending a few hours at the Spice and Gold Souks we took the boat across the creek 5 min ride and cost was 1 AED which was 30cents Canadian. So we asked for a private 30 min ride to tour the creek which was 60 AED well worth it! Great pictures
"Nice". Take the abra for 1dirham, cross over to the souq's and take in the sights of old and new Dubai. Beautiful at night time and worth a visit.
access to cheap shopping. took abra across creek to old souk where prices for local wares were less expansive than other souks or mall shops.

Historical Dubai. In the Dubai Creek you'll see the older Dubai which has a lot of history. Here I'd recommend an Abra tour crossing the river - then you'll see the Creek from another perspective. During sunset time it is really beautiful. The Dubai Creek has a lot of small local shops, and it is quite cosy to just take it easy and walk around here. A lot of nice places to visit where you can relax and enjoy life.

A different Dubai. I was pleased to see something more authentic than just skyscrapers and shopping mall. I suggest to visit old dubai first with Dubai museum and then walk to the creek where you can board the abras, the traditional boats used as a mean of transportation by those who live on the other side of the creek, and have a nice trip on the water. You can 'rent' a boat just for yourself for around 100-120 dirhams for an hour sail and then maybe ask the guy to drop you on the spice souk side, which is a nice experience too.

Dubai creek. Idea is ok,Dubai by night but I didn't have best possible experience.Ship, food and entertainment, quite average from all points of view ..probably due to the fee around 100 AEd/person. Choose something better
Best Value in Dubai. Take the abra across the creek for 1 dirham. Then visit the souks and come back across the creek for a n interesting view of old Dubai.

very nice lunch. we had lunch in an open restaurant, in a balcony where we could see the creek and all the boats that were navegating on it. we eat grilled hamour and also the typical and tasty falafel
Great Atmosphere. Liked the clean air and surrounding areas, incl. old market with souvenirs and boats to take you across the creek to other side...

Great place day and night.. Big contrast to the modern and developed Dubai, but worth seeing an old and traditional part of this city with its wooden boats and busy life.
It is easy to get there by metro.

Stunning at night time. We had an evening meal on a traditional dhouw while cruising the creek. It was a fascinating sight to see all the dhouw restaurants plying the creek. The food was excellent and is a must do when in Dubai.

A vibrant combination of new and old Dubai, and a great contrast from downtown Dubai. The creek is a bustling area lined by buildings old and new, including various souqs, mosques and the British Embassy, not to mention modern offices, hotels and exhibtition centres. Abras (water taxis) constantly ferry both locals and tourists from one side of the creek to the other for 1 Dihram, whilst Dhow cruises run up and down the creek (including the Big Bus Tours' very own Dhow, a ride on which was included in our 48 hour hop on hop off bus ticket). Colourful trading boats from places such as India can also be seen moored along the side of the creek. A great contrast from downtown Dubai.

Busy and traditional. This is the life blood of Dubai with traditional wooden boats bringing consumer items, saw mountains of tyres on the dock side.A very pleasant time to while the time inbetween other activities.

Creek has many faces -as Dubai does. Dubai Creek - with its view has many faces. Transportation boats with lot of boxes -as clean as other parts. Abrak - personal transport is a must to try. Oldstylish, strange a bit in Dubai, but really enjoyable.
Very Good. Very good, bigger than I expected, we took a water taxi across from the shops one side to the shops the other, only cost about 20p so well worth the experience.

Dubai Cruise. The creek provide a cruise out for leisure, the wonderful beaches, tall buildings, cruise entertainment. It is an acknowledgement of Nature's provision to mankind. It is good to stay off hurdles and get refreshed for continuity.
We loved it. Staying near the creek really added to our experience, taking the abra (water taxi across to the souks is great and only 1dhm (about 20p)
Boat trip. Round trip gives a view of most of the town. Ideal booking is from the Old Soukh waterfront.Hire one of the hundreds of small boats where you sit outside (weather permitting of course...)

Traditional trading.. The Creek is where Dubai originated. Dubai is a trading Emirate, has little oil, and the dhows from here traded to the East coast of Africa using Monsoon weather and also to India/Pakistan and Iran. It is great to see the variety of cargoes waiting to be loaded and to discover their destination. The Creek itself has the usual buzz of the abras, the water taxis, plying their trade. A visit here is a must and a bonus is the opportunity to visit the adjacent souqs.
Relaxing atmosphere in evening. if you are tired from all day activity drive to the creek and spend night there .. grab a cup of coffee and chill

Hectic part of the City. Dubai Creek is a bustling community. Lots of markets, ships loading by the hundreds with all kinds of goods. Very interesting place to take in some of the local
Culture and food.

Really interesting cultural comparison and relaxing afternoon stroll. We went here as a family of 3 adults. We had a great stroll around the Souk (market) as well. There is plenty on offer for sale, prepare to be spoken to by the stall owners to get you to their shop. My impression was that it was very geared towards tourists though. Once we got to the creek we crossed over in one of the boats. It was very cheap and if you want to you can take a boat tour for pleasure, although on this occasion we were using it as transport. It wasn't entirely clear which boat we had to get on but if you ask they are very helpful. The boat is quite open so sit in the middle if you're a bit water-phobic. You might also need help stepping on and off the boat if your balance isn't great. I really enjoyed seeing all the different people using the creek though and it was just really interesting to compare with a similar place in the UK. This would be a nice relaxing day out I think, although perhaps not ideal if you have kids.

Old Dubai. Catch it quick before it Disappears!. I used to travel to Dubai over thirty years ago and used to stay at the Sheraton beside the creek. The large influx of tourists has now meant that a new docking and loading area for the dows has been created further along and only a few does are present loading and unloading all types of goods in the old style. The spaces are now taken up with dinner and river boat trips. Watching all sots of white goods, cars, tractors if you are lucky, with all sorts of bundles give the real essence of what trading was like.So... if you still want to see part of the old Dubai hurray up!!

Decent evening out. It's worth going to the creek on an evening as there's a decent atmosphere. You can wander round the souks, take a water taxi and eat quite cheaply.Can't get an alcoholic drink though!It's on the Metro line as well.
Too Good. Night view is amazing....do try local abra water taxi...just 1 dh for crosing the creek in 10 mins......avoid dhow cruise..if u want..try dhow cruise are marina

A hive of activity. We call them rivers, Abra's very active during the day transporting people across and up and down the "creek". Some at night,but many floating restaurants,colourfully lit bring the creek to life at night

Creek dinner cruise. Excellent night out with delicious buffet style food. Buffet was organized well with plenty of choice for vegetarians and non vegetarians. Great local dancer as entertainment. Good value for money.

Thoroughly enjoyed the Creek. Loved the little water taxis (abras) that ply their trade back and forth across the river for 1 Dirham each. The Creek is a real working river with many types of boats and many buildings on its banks. Lovely just to sit on a terrace, have a fruit juice and watch the water boats going up and down / back and forth. We hired an abra for the four of us, which took us up the creek to the floating bridge and back. Cost 120 Dirham standard fare. There were four of us, so 30 Dirham, around €7.50 each. Well worth it.
Very interesting. Had a great time. All the little shops & stalls around. Need to barter. Very interesting talking to the locals. The spice & gold Souk (market) were great

Romantic Dhow Cruise Dinner. What could be more romantic than a dinner on a dhow cruise as it glides silently along the Dubai Creek by moonlight. While you cruise aboard it offers on intriguingly different view of the amazing city - old town, Sheikh Saeed's house, birthplace of Sheikh Saeed, Heritage village, golf club, parks and well as the famous modern skyscrapers of the city in the spectacular night lights, On the Cruise delicious Arabic/ International buffet dinner will be served .
"Nice Place". This place is the place to be before sunset so that u can enjoy a beautiful array of breeze plus the light full creek side of dubai not forgetting the colorful beautiful ambiance.

Ugly. It's an ugly creek, nothing to really look forward to. We took an Abra, a water taxi, across to the Old Town to see the Gold and Spice Souks, but it was not anything to write hone about. The water is gross.
Loved it. Got a water taxi over to the souk...loved it very atmospheric really busy on the creek but we'll worth a ride

Loved going to the other side. We enjoyed the boat ride to the other side where the regular workers live and shop. The stores were amazing, and I don't mean the tourist ones. One really needs to visit here to see more of real life, the other side of Dubai.
Don't miss it!. A really interesting area showing old and new architecture side by side, best seen from the boat trip included in the Big Bus Ticket

Fun but tame. This is the nearest you can probably get to historic Dubai apart fro the sand dunes maybe. The hustle and bustle is interesting and crossing the creek in the water taxis is fun and virtually free. Its amazing how many retailers selling the same thing there are and the gold souk certainly can't be beaten for bling sales. I've seen souks that are more challenging to navigate such as Marrakesh and Jerusalem, but its definitely interesting and worth a visit.
it is good. it is in bur dubai there is a boad to go from bur dubai to deria they take 1 dhs there are also small shop over there where u can buy food
Interesting. Part of the old Dubai, plenty to see, and in the evening the meal on the river boat is well worth it
part of big bus tour worth doing. enjoyable boat ride, see sights and how many of the locals travel, fun and interesting, and a comfortable boat ride offering refreshments on your 45 minute trip

Good place to have a one hour cruise to relax.. Included in the hop on bus (Red Bus) red route was a one hour cruise on a two tiered boat. Nice and comfortable and good to relax in this oh so busy city surrounded by high buildings. There were dhows which didn't look that comfortable and water taxis across the creek.

Witnessing Old ways. Dubai Creek is still in use and one of old way of transports. You will find parks, dhow cruises and nice places at the banks for creek. Also you can enjoy the traditional Abra while going from one end to another.

Do the Gold Souk, Spice Market and a Dhow ride - in that order. 1) Go to the gold souk - it is a rare experience. Shops laden with incredible quantities of gold jewelry line long hallways. The gold is of very high quality. The prices, fair - you can look up the current gold trading price and will find the shop prices are very close to it. This place will forge a great family memory. If you do not buy and only window shop, this will consume maybe 30-45 minutes Take a Dubai taxi - usually a Camry, cream body and red top. They are metered, and honest. Inside, on the door pillars between the front and back seats, is a metal tag. It has the number of the taxi. You may take note of it - if you leave anything behind, it is your way to find the taxi. You will get your stuff back. 2) the spice market is a short walk from the gold souk. A wondrous place that you will imagine has remained unchanged for centuries. Big open baskets and gunny sacks are piled high with brightly colored spices. Other bags overflow with sweet smelling dried flowers. Smaller containers hold different kinds of incense, amber. Look for Iranian dates and saffron. They are of the highest quality. The shopkeeper will be happy to offer a sample date for you to try. This will consume 45 minutes. Linger, it is worth it. 3) End the evening with a private dhow cruise. I think it cost 50 Dhiram per person (divide by 3.6 to get US$) for a 30 minute ride. We extended for another 30 minutes for another 50 Dhiram/person. The ride is magical. The night air is sweet and cold, a sharp contrast to the heat of the day. You might need a light jacket. Being on a boat that has remained unchanged in design for hundreds of years and going past elegant and very modern buildings on the banks of the creek is a unique experience. Three hours of wonder between the gold souk, the spice market and the dubai creek cruise. For about $12 a person. Excluding any gold you buy, of course!

Lovely experience . I was awed by the fact its manmade! At night there are cruise boats lined up for a dinner cruise. Lovely and serene experience. They are a bit more pricey early in the evening but are cheaper right before they sail off.
route to the Souks. The Creek was clean and interesting. There were hundreds of boats for trips up and down the creek and also for crossing the creek to the Souks. The cost was 6UK pence.

Nighttime creek crossing. took the ferry across the creek to get from the gold souk to the spice and textile souk, it's was quite magical crossing at night with all the boats lit up with lovely coloured fairy lights.A great experience I really do recommend you do this at night during call to prayer, hearing the chants as you go down the creek is a memory I will keep forever.
The Dhow Experience. Same again done ths several years ago when we visited our daughter, fantastic experience on the Creek enjoying the City from the water.
Awsome place. Great place, Loads of rides, ideal place for family BBQAlso lovely place to take those lovely picture of beautiful Dubai

Sharjah Wanderers Hockey Club - 25 year Reunion 2015. Revisiting Dubai was an amazing experience seeing just how 25 years had transformed this very cosmopolitan City. Going down Dubai Crerk is a must as it's at the heart of the old city. Take the Abra Taxi and see the contrast of the old and new.There are some beautiful new buildings, to see going in land. Coming back towards the sea, you'll see the Old Museum, and most importantly the very old houses and the tall Arabian wind towers. Amidst this, you have a bee hive of local traders with the Dhows moored up, with their cargo being unloaded. Heading to the mouth of the Creek on the right hand side is Bur Dubai, Deira a Tower and the very old Souqs, maiden with Spices, Arabian gold jewellery. To get this into your schedule suggest at least 4 hours, either go early morning while its still reasonably cool or after 4pm, and listen to the cocophany of the Mullas wailing from their Mosques for "Call to prayer".All in all, Dubai Creek gives you a balanced perspective of the historical and modern blend of a fantastic city. Aptly the old local Arabs are great people too.

Delightful old Dubai. The Creek has been integral to Dubai & the heritage shows. It's lovely to walk along & be in the fresh air rather than a mall for a change. The textile souq on Bur Dubai side is terrific for atmosphere & some fun bargaining for souvenirs. There's a terrific water front cafe near the water taxis - wonderful hummus! You can grab a real abra (water taxi) with the locals over to Deira & walk up to the spice & old gold souqs.
worth a walk around in the day and at night. just nice to look at the boats, different pace and scenery. Good photo opportunities too. Cheap boat ferrys too

interesting place to visit. When in Dubai, this area is certainly not to be missed. it's where you get a bit of history , a look into the past, where real Dubai life takes place. The souks are awesome (gold souk, spices souk, clothing souk, etc...) And spend some time sitting in one of the cafés along the creek, just looking at the dhows sail by.
Awesome Park. Great Park with a huge area, wonderful rides, cable car, view of the creek in front. Best place for a family barbeque...even to celebrate birthday. Entry is Dhs 5

Connects the parts of Dubai well. We travelled using economical ferries across dubai creek to visit gold souks & dubai museum..as such a nice port to see sunset by evening, bt nothing spectacular per se

Made to look old. This is area isn't all shiny but it's also not as old as you would think. It was built to look old to give a feel of what the area used to be like. It's a really nice area to walk around - along the water but also going a little further inland to see some of the markets and shops. Some amazing food over here too! We tried a place where the locals eat across the street from the bus station.
A trip into Dubai's past. Rode a dhow for an hour on the Dubai Creek. In Old Dubai and before or after your ride you can explore the gold or spice souks. Worth a visit

Brother-in-law's surprise. Bateaux Dubai did not let us down. The food was surprisingly very good and the drinks were free flowing once we had set off. There's not really that much to see but it is nevertheless worthwhile just for the adventure and something different. Many thanks to The Meydan Hotel for the use of their brand new Jaguar XL and the car reception guys at Al Qasr for joining in with the birthday surprise.
Shisa on the creek. atmosphere was lovely. It was shisa with friends, sitting in the open and enjoying the sunset. Awesome place in a great location.

Abra Ride. If one is in Dubai, one must take a couple of Abra rides up and down the creek from Bur Dubai to Deira. The Creek has been the city's lifeline for centuries and remains so even today. its clean and offers a nice way to spend a lazy afternoon.

Take a boat ride across the creek and soak up the ambience. The creek is full of activity and it is interesting just to spend some time to watch for a bit. We took a boat ride from the Dubai Museum area across to the Gold and Textile Souks. Very reasonable at 1 dirham and gives you a good flavour for the area.

Take a boat ride across the creek and soak up the ambience. The creek is full of activity and it is interesting just to spend some time to watch for a bit. We took a boat ride from the Dubai Museum area across to the Gold and Textile Souks. Very reasonable at 1 dirham and gives you a good flavour for the area.
Dissapointing. Food was not as advertised it had been sitting out for some time prior to our arrival. The trip was a bit on the dull side, time may have been better spent wandering.
Took the little boats. Took the little ferry boats across the river and back. Quick and cheap little water taxi service up and down the creek

A Visit to the Old Town. We enjoyed our visit to the Gold and Spice Souks with the interaction with the locals. We reached it by crossing on an ancient dhow for which we paid the owner one dirham (20p). No life jackets or health & safety instructions here! It was however the only bargain to be found in Dubai and well worth the experience.
Old city sightseeing. This area is in historical part of dubai. There are a lof of boat tour for fun at night like traditional belly dancing show, sword dans, falcon show.
Old Dubia. Really interesting ,go to the museum and take the local small ferrys across the creek. Lots of things to see and do

Dubai Creek. Is a must for all travellers. As I live in Dubai, I always take my visitors there to visit the gold, and the spice souk.A ride on the alumbra across the creek and a meal in one of the waterside cafes always brings a smile to the tourists.

water taxi. The Creek was only a 10 minute walk from our hotel. They have water taxis, which are nice but i did not find the time tables very clear. The times are not mentioned at each stop, so once we ended up waiting for 20 minutes ans then we walked away because nothing came. It has a nice atmosphere, nice little cafe's.

Grab an Abra and Enjoy!. We headed to Dubai Creek and grabbed an Abra aka water taxi and were given a great tour - 1/2 hr north and then 1/2 hr south for a very reasonable amount of dirhams. Loved looking at all of the boats on the creek coming and going with their cargo. So much old world charm. Make time to do this!

If you like Heritage, this one is for you. On my first afternoon in Dubai I walked extensively along the Heritage Village side of the Creek and was pleasantly surprised to see how many eating places there were. I enjoyed walking through the Heritage Village. The Photographic Museum was most interesting and captured the Old and the New Dubai in beautiful photography

on the water. travel with the locals and you see life as it is, this is another must do travel from one side to the other on these small boats if you want to visit the old souk. then cross over to the spice & gold souks. great experience do remember to barter

A must stop area..explore the old city old dubai. If you want to see the old city of dubai,how the city started and taste a bit of the local heritage, this is the area to visit!take the metro to al ghubaiba station, walk along the creek and visit the old houses ans art galleries and museums, then take the Abra (small wooden boat) to cross the creek to the other side and walk through the old souks : spice souk, carpet souk, reaching the gold souk...and walk through the souks till you reach bani-yas square where you can take the metro back. In fridays do not go before the Friday prayer because the souk will be closed. Enjoy it! :)

the creek is nothing special. the view is great, the creek itself is only a busy waterway. The crossing in a Watertaxi however is a great expereince, its quick, fun and very cheap ( 1 AED per corssing)

A trip back in time.. We has a great time walking around and caught a glimpse of 'old Dubai' in the old buildings on the edge of the Creek. The Souk's are an interesting place to visit, but be prepared to be a little hassled by the merchants (all part of the fun) and take a trip across the creek in one of the small boats...only one Dirham! Also the restaurant jutting out over the Creek near where the boats leave is a great place for a spot of Mezze.

zigzag. Consider taking a small boat ride from one side to other side it cost only few dirham per person lots of fun diesel operating wood small boats like multi seating taxi we zigzag from one side to the other it was cost effective and fun.
Food excellent. We went to the Boardwalk Restaurant - shaped as a ship overlooking the Creek. The best fillet steak I have tasted.

Great TIme. The Creek - is in fact a small river - it is surrounded on both sides by Hotels and on the other by the Old Dubai. There are old Dhows that have been plying up the East African Coast of years that berth there. It is always a busy place with boats going up and down constantly. Take an abra across the Creek for a great experience!

nice place. If you are looking for a place close to real life and little stores, this is the place. You can have a seat near the water and enjoy the view. Take a boat to cross the river for practically no money.
Authentic Dubai?. Well worth a visit - stroll along the promenades. Be sure the take an abra ferry crossing - the kids will love it.
time pass. this place looks like an artist's portrait..ideal for people who wish to draw it on their canvas.April is the best time to visit.
Old city both sides. Everybody reviews modern Dubai and skyscrapers, while old Dubai and the Creek are really worth visiting. Take a walk and public boat for 1 DH

A nice change from new construction & AC. A lot of Dubai is shiny & new, so much that at times it feels like a movie lot, and some streets reminded me of the Wild West, where the only buildings are along the main drag in town, with nothing behind that first row. The Dubai Creek, on the other hand, provides you with some actual history. Locals will tell you there's still not THAT much history there, but it doesn't feel quite as Disneyfied as other parts. You can access the major souks (marketplaces) from here, and take a water taxi across to reach others. There are creek cruises that cater to tourists, but you don't get much more on them than you do for a 2dh water taxi ride. The souks are fun, but there's a lot of touristy junk too. Keep in mind it's customary to haggle, and so the price the seller quotes could easily be twice or more what you should actually pay. A good rule of thumb is to start at less than half. Locals advised me that 1/2 the quoted price is the "fair price," but these guys are very savvy, and know fresh tourist pickings when they see them. I knew i paid too much because a few places gave me extras after I paid " as a gift." Be ready to walk away, ignore the guys trying to sell knock-off watches & handbags, and stick to your guns. Be polite, but don't get bullied into buying anything. I had one man run out & wrap a pashmina around me, and had to stop & drop it on a stack of his other merchandise, and my poor crowd & stranger-contact adverse partner had his head grabbed and wrapped in traditional headcoverings twice, with many more attempted :) Great photos... Still, it's an experience! As this is a more traditional area, don't dress like you might see at the Western hotels & clubs- ladies should wear looser clothes that go past your knees, and tops that at least cover your shoulders and don't show much cleavage. Some sites recommend you cover your head in the souks, but I was fine. I brought a scarf to be safe. I felt very safe despite the pushiness and the narrow alleys, and really enjoyed my visit.If you want to feel like you experienced at least a little Middle Eastern culture while in Dubai, the Creek and the souks are a must.

Very atmospheric. I have been to Dubai many times over the years and while many places have changed out of recognition this place still has the same hustle and bustle that I first remember - I love it and always go back when in town - this is the real Dudai
Boat taxis. Even though there's land transportation, I loved taking the small boats over to the souks -- try it.

Dubai Creek Golf & Yacht Club. Spent a couple of days enjoying a private lesson and then playing the par3 9 hole course as I am new to golf. Unlimited access to driving range, chipping and putting on day of lesson which was real good value for money. These took place at the Academy but we walked to the main Golf Clubhouse for drinks etc and was blown away by the beauty of the setting. The terrace overlooks the Creek and we saw traditional Dhows cruising by and seaplane tours taking off. The main golf course is manicured within an inch of its life and a must see place even if you don't golf. Found the drinks and food very reasonable too. Enjoy.
Souks & Markets. Great area to mingle with the locals browsing the market areas, restaurants which are a great place to watch the dowes crisscrossing the water.
Man-made creek. Impressive, noting how our tour guide told us that the government actually expanded it to allow big ships to pass through the city.

Checking out the sights of old Dubai. Spent a nice morning browsing through the shops of the souk & watching the comings & goings of the tourists by bus. Many people were crossing the Creek on the cheap & plentiful traditional boats called abras. All in all, a pleasant way to spend the morning & a few dirhams!

Excellent Show!. Kids ought to be here. Seals and Dolphins rule the show. Dolphins paint, sing, dance & so does the seals. You get mascots of the Dolphins to be bought and taken as momentos back home and the children will love them.

a great cruise. the dhow cruise along the dubai creek is an exciting expereance with a foray in to the open seaand the sultan boat is very nice and well decorated the dinner is fine and so are the shows but the one of the head stewards needs a liltle more polishing of being nice to the visitors

Catch a Dhow across the creek like a local. For just 1 dirham (about 20p) you can catch a shuttle Dhow across Dubai Creek to visit the Old Souk, Gold Souk and Spice Souks. We really enjoyed it and it was a great way to get about. We also did it late on Friday night and one thing about Dubai is that you feel completely safe. Also along the creek are some great floating restaurants, prices vary dramatically. We googled online and booked via a voucher company like Groupon and got a great bargain, all you could eat traditional food, drinks, and entertainment. Although being the only westerners on board, and being so 'blonde' I think I might've been more entertainment than the Whirling Dervish in his illuminating skirt.

Worth a trip on the local abra. Ry a boat trip across the water and see the souk and smell of spices, watching all the large wooden boats being unloaded is fascinating there are views of old and new Dubai , wonderful, god restaurants and an everning trip on a boat with meal included is always worth the trip, enjoy

Old dubai. Old Dubai is by the creek,markets,gold souk,spice souk. You can get on a water bus in bur Dubai over to diera where there is street after street of shopping,a very lively place in the evenings. The water taxi/bus is one dirham each way which is about 20p .enjoyable way to spend an evening

beautiful golf course. Beautiful course, walk tl the river, and see the old wooden boats, still transporting white good, keep walking the riverand see wooden yachts, $$$$$$$ down to old dubai and the markets, ,,,including the gold markets. ?. Worth seeing
DCGC. Dubai Creek Golf Club is absolutely fantastic. Went to the Indain Cusine evening with a group of friends. We all loved it. Thanks to all the staff.
Nice, relaxing. You can take an inexpensive boat ride to the famous gold and spice souks. Real good photo opportunities. Many shops and restaurants through the Creek area.
See it - it is so different. It is for sure worth while going for a sailtrip at least across the Creek to see the contrast to the rest of the city.
old is gold. dubaibcreek is the heart of Dubai while you are here you can visit the spices market and gold market also in the opposite side you can visit textile market
Water taxi. I loved going back and forth on the abras. They cost a few pence and are run on old washing machine motors. Not to be missed.

Excellent experience in contrast the the 'modern' Dubai. We did this as part of the Big Bus tour and so glad we did. We went across the creek in a really old wooden boat which was some sort of water taxi. It was really interesting to see all the Dhows being loaded with fridges, TV, microwaves etc. to be taken to India etc. One wonders if the Dhows are capable of these continuous trips back and forward with the amount of cargo on them.

Here it all started. The richness of Dubai is its aptitude to commerce, which made it a crucial port in the exchanges from/towards India and the far East in the past. Dubai's Creek, a natural harbor, excellent for ships to load/unload their goods, is still today one of Dubai's palpitating souls. The Creek can be crossed with barges who charge some dirhams only. A very interesting experience!

Original Dubai. Although this place is not 'old' by Dubai standards... It feels like you have stepped back in time.. Fabulous local foods to be sampled and lovely atmosphere while wandering the many streets and alleyways. A total contrast from the 'new' Dubai and well worth the sore feet!!!

The old Dubai. Really good atmosphere. Dhows being loaded by had to sail across the gulf to as far away as Mumbai. All under sail. Would not like to visit during british summer time - there is no shade. Very close to gold and spice souk. Great for a trip on an Abra across the creek.

Lovely walk. After visiting the Heritage Village nearby I had a very nice walk alongside the Dubai creek. I found it very characteristic, passing through the souq, seeing the typical dow going on the water, arriving at the Sheikh Saeed al-Maktoum House. I did it at sunset and it felt magical.

Birds, Water and a Delightful evening!!. I am writing this review, not as a tourist to Dubai, I have relocated to Dubai and have been living here for the past few weeks. This was my second weekend that I spent going around Dubai and I was wondering why didn't I visit this place in the first weekend. There are various souk's (markets) in Dubai along the banks of the Creek. It depends on which souk you would want to visit. To reach Dubai Creek you need to take the metro through the Green Line and reach Al Ghubaiba and walk to the area where there are lot of ships (called Abra). You will have to pay just 1AED to reach "Diera" which is the Gold Souk. We also found a lot of shops selling spices.We caught the ABRA which dropped us to Bur Dubai again on the banks of the creek where we found the textile souk. Please ignore this place if you wish to shop. The fun lies in travelling on the boats and viewing the scenery and the old Dubai where there are no high raise buildings. The birds that fly on the water will surely capture your attention. You will enjoy the hustle and bustle of many sellers and beware of sellers who would wish to sell duplicate goods to you.
good experience. Good to have a cruise ride with dinner and the famous tanura dance. The ships are very decorative with different lights.

Dubai Creek. Caught the metro all the way to the Dubai Creek from the JBR area, so cheap and very easy to understand, took around an hour. Caught a boat over the creek to the gold & spice souks, great atmosphere and well worth the visit. Got preserved to buy handbags, watches etc but all very friendly banter!
Beauty and bliss. We went for cruise dinner on Dubai creek in night and it was just beautiful to see the lighting in night around creek.

Always fun to experience the creek!. Visitors from out of town do we wanted to visit the creek! From the stroll down by the shipping boats with the cargo on the dock, the spice souk, the gold souk, the misc souks such as the electronics, housewares, across on the boat to the other side to wander by the merchants and tasting local indian treats, sugar cane drinks and more and then the boat back across to the other side. Always fun to explore and wander in the shops as well !

Original but underwhelming. Perhaps we were in the sting place - and we visited during the day rather than at night - but it appeared to be a long line of dhows moored up but with nothing open! The only place to get a drink was in a very run down bar set back from the creek May be it's more lit up at night

Soothing and beautiful. Whether you experience the Creek from afar during the City Tour.. or cruise down it during dinner on a Dhow Cruise with the fascinating lights of Dubai on both sides, you will definitely not regret it... The Creek is very nicely maintained.

the best view. Incidentally I was staying at Deira and the room overlooked the creek. We went to the creek for walks and i must say its just a beautiful and soothing place unlike what you would expect.

A nice scenic stroll. My friends and I got a cab to Dubai Creek one afternoon for something to do (we were struggling for things to do with the weather being bad)This afternoon was sunny - though not overly warm and the Dubai creek was a pleasant experience.We casually strolled around looking at the boats and enjoying the sunshine. Not sure it's a tourist attraction as such but if you want to while away a couple of hours this certainly does the job.

Different Experience- FULLY Authentic. if you will use the ferry on dubai creek , you will go in different world like old days. if you are travelling there dont forget to try this. ONLY IN 1 AED, can you beat that :)
very enjoyable. We really enjoyed the water taxi across Dubai Creek - such a unique experience! Seeing the abras and old boats in all their color made you know you were somewhere different!

Unbeleivable experience.. There is so much to enjoy, from the boat ride across the creek for 1 dirham, to just being able to wander around the souks, or even trying some street food. This is a must see and do part of Dubai. Even try a ride down the creek - its amazing!!!!

Where old meets the new !. When visiting Dubai you need to come to the creek to see the old part of Dubai merging into the new..old "Dhow" boats will ferry you across two major regions of Dubai, connecting Bur Dubai & Deira..you cannot miss the smaller boats, the "abra" which will take you across for just 1 dirham (local currency) across the creek..on the other side in Bur Dubai you have the Heritage village where you can visit Dubai's heritage buildings as well as taste some of the local delicacies..theres also a very wide & long promenade which you could walk down with wonderful breeze blowingfrom the creek..lastly you should also try the tea stall on the Deira side from the tea stalls..you will also see smaller ships ferrying cargo from Dubai to neighboring countries..which use to be the old wharf..a place to visit when in Dubai..

Pleasent cruise. Dubai creek in the middle of Dubai is surrounded by the tall buildings and parks or Dubai. There are very good evening cruise dinners available with excellent views of the city. Very enjoyable

Interesting view of the city. The creek is more like a river and it's good to take one of the abbas (water boat taxis) and cruise over or down it. You get some nice perspective of the city and the souks. Seagulls fly like crazy on the new city side and people relax at the Creekside cafe. Only 2 dirham to cross on the water taxi.

Water Taxi across the creek. After the Dubai museum we used the water taxi to cross to the other side to visit the gold and spice markets. This is where you see the REAL Dubai. So diverse. It was one of the highlights of our trip. I recommend it.

Such a contrast to the modern hotels and malls!. We walked through the souks and managed to find the creek which was quite tricky as we got slightly lost in the souks. The sight of the creek made me gasp as the contrast to the modern malls and hotels was incredible. We had a ride down the creek on an Abra which was fun although no shelter so midday was not the best time to go. The creek is busy and fascinating. A trip to Dubai I think should definitely include a visit to the Creek.
Must see the old Dubai. So much to see and do here and if you want to see the old Dubai then this is the place to come and do some browsing around the Souks

River Zara. Dubai Creek is a saltwater creek located in Dubai, United Arab Emirates. It ends at Ras Al Khor Wildlife Sanctuary. Some sources say that the creek extended as far inland as Al Ain, and that the Ancient Greeks called it River Zara

Brilliant - if you want fake watches and loads of hassle.... Visited Dubai Creek area one evening during a 10 day stay in the UAE... If your accessing this area via the metro, then you need to be on the green line and get off at Al Guhbaiba station.We have travelled all over the world and love the hustle and bustle of a market, so we're looking forward to the challenge of the Dubai Creek Sukhs... What a disappointment ! If your into to fake watches, knock off sun glasses and alike being sold by aggressive shop owners who "will not" take no for an answer then this is the place for you.A dirty and unimpressive area of Dubai which looks like it has been left to rot.The 1AED (£0.18 / $0:23 / €0.27) boat trip across the creek itself is novel and very enjoyable but the banks either side are not, couldn't wait to get out of the area & won't be going back.

Good to visit. One of the best attractions in Dubai.... The creek divides Deira and Bur Dubai.... A hotspot for shopping enthusiasts.... And it also has good number of restaurants..... A must visit place in Dubai....
Amazing time.. Have been there for lunch on a beautiful day and it was amazing. The food,the view,the drinks,the service!Just perfect1

Interesting heritage place. This is where I believe Dubai started growing!From Al Ghubaiba you can walk around the heritage area , have a meal at a restaurant by the creek & take the Abra ride across for just 1 aed! Across, you can enjoy camel milk date ice cream & walk through the spice souk, bargain for saffron & gape at the gold on display at the gold souk ( maybe buy some!)

The real taste of Dubai. Dubai Creek is like stepping back in time. It gives traveller an invite on the real people and cultures in Dubai. The soukes and spice markets are a treat and you can purchase almost anything for a reasonable price. Well worth a visit.
Dhow Cruise. Dhow cruise was good. Initially we had thought the dhow would be ordinary but our Dhow was very well made as special, better than all the others Dhows on the creek.

Old and new Dubai in a charming setting. Dubai Creek has been the heart of Dubai for many decades, and for most it typifies old Dubai and its legacy of seafaring.The Dhows (old style trading barges) line the Creek in a dazzling display of colour and make a beautiful photograph with the skyscrapers as a back drop to the old boats. Another charming feature of Dubai Creek are the ubiquitous Abra Water Taxis that ply both sides of the creek and are a common form of transport for workers. For around US$0.50 you can enjoy a speedy trip across the water from the Deira side of Dubai to Bur Dubai. It's a bit scary, but well worth it!The Creek area also offers some tasty snacks and more upmarket restaurants on the Bur Dubai side. Try the fresh coconut juice from the actual shell and the famous Shwarma (lamb or chicken in a rolled up chappati-style Arabic bread. Delicious.The best time to visit the Creek in my opinion is just before sunset when it s cooler and you can enjoythe sunset over Bur Dubai.
Dhow Cruise. This was a very different view of Dubai, complete with an evening cruise and dinner. Can recommend this.

Wenn old meets new. It's lovely to take a Dhow along the creek and see the traditional Dhows loading for there journey to India and other places. The gold souks and shops for locals is all very interesting. It give us an impression of how Dubai used to be... and in the background the new high tech Skyscrapers. A trip with an Abra is also a must!

relaxing. very beautifully done p place classy and great facilities. must visit and great place to hang out.dubai is great place for everything EXCEPT BUSINESS- ITS A GREAT MIRAGE thats all.!!! be very careful when you do business or deal with guys suited booted and arriving in huge cars and entertaining you in huge villas or hotels- finally thats the bait finally its your own money which you shall be rooked off.. sad but true. the original locals dont do business they are rich. the outsiders are the ones who do it - crooks of the highest order. you can enjoy spend and have fun but not many have been able to make money and take it out to their countries. dubai is collection of the biggest crooks on earth all in one place trying to crook each other and make money. in this deal only local dubai makes money or assets as all invest there and when its time to go you have to leave all thats constructed there itself. BE CAREFUL. GO HAVE FUN ENJOY DRIVE MOST FANCY CARS BUT PLEASE THINK 100 TIMES BEFORE INVESTING AND DOING BUSINESS. A sincere true advise from many many years of experience and observation.
Busy Watercourse. It's fun to ride the little boat taxis across this busy little waterway to get from the historical precinct to the Spice and Gold Souks (marketplaces) - a must to visit in Dubai

A great way to spend a few hours.. We stayed at The Sheraton on the Creek which was a handy location.From our side of the Creek we could take a very easy stroll by the river to the Gold Souks. Along the river there are loads of water taxis and typically to cross to the Old Souks market (and museum) one way it will cost you 1 Dirham (about 20p). This mode of transport is not a good option if you have any mobility problems.There are a number of river side restaurants on both sides.We took an evening trip up and down the river on a floating restaurant called Le Bateau which was brilliant, but the price is not for the faint hearted!
Dinner in cruise. Creek is the best place to visit in the evening...enjoyed the dinner in dhow cruise and the food...very nice the beauty of dubai can be viewed in the cruise drive...

Crossing the creek on an Abra.. My wife and I visited Dubai in July 2012. One afternoon we went on a half day Dubai City Tour. The tour included views of Burj Al Arab, the Jumeirah Mosque, a visit to the Dubai museum in Bur Dubai, a view of the Textile souk, and a visit to experience the hustle and bustle of Dubai's Gold & spice souk, which was the final stage of the tour. After being in Bur Dubai you have to cross the Dubai Creek to Deira where the Gold & spice souk is. To cross the Creek you have to take a trip aboard an Abra (a rickety little boat). There are hundreds of "abras" which ferry passangers between Bur Dubai and Deira, costing 1 AED (Dirham) per trip and takes around five minutes. The Dubai Creek is not much to look at, but it is the surrounding neighborhoods on both sides of the waterway that provide a peek at what old Dubai was all about. Make sure you take a ride on an "Abra", it's a wonderful little journey, offering superb views of the fascinating muddle of Creekside buildings with their tangles of souks, wind towers, mosques and minarets. Hope you enjoy, we did.
Good network. A fantastic network and first class facility, however despite paying the gold class ticket we discovered others had not, but still managed to obtain access and were not moved on.

Nice place to spend evenings. i think this should be one of the best parks in Dubai.Nicely maintained nestled along the creek . Good entertainment park. you can simply sit at the creek side and enjoy view or take a walk all along. spend evenings .
Nice evening cruise on a Dhow. It's nice to visit it at night on a Dhow dining on it with true arab cuisine. . Very nice opportunity to see thr hart of Dubai from the creek

Use the water Taxi's. The creek is an Excellent place to visit so much to see and bartering with the shop keepers is great fun. Just looking in the jewellery stores is amazing - using the water taxi's to cross the creek is well worth doing as well

A must for Dubai visitors. We stayed two nights in old Dubai, and the first morning we walked to the creek and took a small boat to the other side to visit the gold and spice souks. On the creek we saw the changes that happened to Dubai. On returning we had lunch at Akbars on the creek.

Dhow Dinner Cruise. We took this cruise on the evening of our Golden Wedding anniversary and found it to be a good night although a bit expensive for what we had a buffet meal with soft drink included we had to pay extra for a wine and beer which is pretty expensive although in saying that it was worth doing as the scenery was lovely with all the lights and other dhows on the creek all lit up so yes I would recommend it.

Lots of character(s). Old Dubai has a lot more personality than the gleaming towers of the marina area, so don't miss it. Just be prepared to fend off endless merchants trying to lure you into their shops to sell you a fake watch, handbag, shawl, etc etc. The vendors in the gold souq were especially aggressive, but some of the stalls/stores seemed to be favored by locals, so bargains probably could be had for those willing to haggle. The spice souq was much more appealing, also the shops with textiles on the other side of Dubai Creek. Take the 1 Dirham boat ride across the water (feels a bit like the Grand Canal in Venice) and find your way to the Dubai Museum and heritage center at the Al Fahidi fort.
Abra trip. Take the kids on a quick Abra trip - they'll love it, and it costs just 20p each way, then explore the spice souk and be dazzled in the gold souk
Happy. i was happy to go there . my advice is to go at night you can have shisha and chat with your friends

Two sides of the Creek. Definitely worth a visit. On one side are fragrant spice and nut shops seĺling sacks of cardomon and pistachios, a small souk and lots of commercial activity. On the other is a heritage centre, small museum and restaurants. One dirham pays for a boat ride across the creek. Fascinating to watch the river traffic. Convenient Metro stops on both sides.

Dinner Cruise. This was delightful. We were very pessimistic about this trip, but we were picked up at hotel on time and escorted to the Dhow, when we set sail we were enthralled by all the Dhows were all lit up in several colours , food plentiful and very enjoyable can highly recommend this trip.

The heart of old Dubai. Dubai Creek in itself is not much to look at it. But it's the surrounding neighborhoods on both sides of the waterway that provide a peek at what old Dubai was all about. Make sure to take a ride on the Abra, shop in the Gold Souk, visit the Dubai Museum and even wander around the restored Bastakiya area. There is much to see but it all can be done easily in one day.

Al Mansour Dhow river cruise with buffet dinner. A really excellent evening out. A very good buffet for the money, especially if you get a bogof voucher from eBay! Advisable to book and ask for top deck by the window. I wouldn't have wanted to be downstairs.

Wonderful day. The day we visited the Dubai Creek was the very best day of our trip. For just 120AED (about £20) we had an hour's cruise on the creek, just myself and my husband. We also visited all the souks on the Deira side and then paid just 1 AED to return to the Bur Dubai side later in the day.
A Pleasant experience. Visited Dubai Creek as part of BIG BUS TOUR of Dubai. Plenty of boats available for short cruise of creek. Excellent views. Some Construction works.
Average. We took a dhow trip on the creek. It is a nice view from the water, but I think we could've spent our time more productively.

Loved the haggling!. We loved the creek - for twenty pence you can cross the creek on a Dow (small boat) living like the locals!! I bought a beautiful rug and a lamp - both are gorgeous and cost me a fraction of what they would've done over in the UK.

Old Dubai. You would be all astonished by how modern Dubai is especially on Sheikh Zayed Road with the huge towers/sky scrapers along with with the Metro and big malls. The Creek area is vividly different than that. It is an old part of the city with old boats, Gold Souk (market), Spices souk and a long Corniche. Go there for a drink or a cup of coffee. Experience something a bit old and authentic.

Wonderful Experience. If you are in Dubai, your visit will remain incomplete if you don't do Dhow Cruise in Dubai Creek. Its the best way to see Dubai's night skyline. Excellent experience, most of the cruises are good and the quality of dinner served is also good.

Good Photo Op. Took the add on extension to the hop on hop off bus tour...one hour boat trip up the creek and back again.Interesting photo oportunity with some of the historical old buildings contrasting against the modern and the newer fishing boats versus the more ancient Arab Dhow.Waters are calm and the boat we were on was well shaded with cold drinks for sale on board.We did not try the side to crossing in the water taxis this trip...This add on to the bus tour well recomended and quite relaxing after the hop on hop off...

Old Dubai, souks, haggling, old boats, exciting and jolly good fun.. The area of old Dubai, whichever side of the creek you are ensure you cross over in one the old wooden motorised boats - basically a lump of wood with a motor! cost 1 dirham or about 20p! The spice souk is full of wonderful aromas, the gold souk loads of gold - all gold is fixed price with notices all around and is sold on weight - no haggling! Everything else haggle!The dress (clothes) souk is full of vibrant colour and there are quite a few local street food places. This is a place not to be missed, if you are on the souk side and cross over then a must visit is the Dubai museum. You probably need a whole day to do the area justice.

Great to be on the water. We took an abra - small motor boat across the Creek to the Gold and Textile Markets. A pleasure to be on a boat, only about .30cents to cross and it took about 8-10 minutes. Would highly recommend it.

If you haven't been to the Creek, you haven't been to Dubai. The Creek is where Dubai started. Today, although most of the tidal mudflats have long gone, and extensions of the Creek are being excavated through the desert, around the Burj, and under Sheikh Zayed Road, the Section from Deira to the sea retains a lot of its historic attraction. Dhows line the wharves. Abra (public water taxis) ferry people across and back between Bur Dubai and Deira, and you'll find more locals than tourists. Definitely a highlight of Dubai.

A journey into the past. I just loved going on the small boat to cross the Creek. I also went on one of the larger boats which takes you on a tour of the creek, taking in the wood boats which bring in goods from such places as India. Well worth a visit & also a visit to the souks is a must!

Plenty to see and do. We stayed at the Raddison on the creek which is ideally placed to wander around this historical area. About a 10 minute walk along the waterfront brought us to the abra station. For 2 Dirham, about 30p we crossed the creek in an old wooden boat. This dropped us close to the textile souk which had a vast selection of fabrivs ad well as clothing and hundreds of pashmina which the shop keepers drape around you in the hope you will buy.From the souk we walked to the restored historic area of Balistrka whete we found a bedoin tent complete with a camel falcon.. We were invited in and offered tea and dates and a seat on a colourful cushion. There are lots of old houses in this area, many of which have been converted into art galleries and museums with free entry. We walked back along the creek from here and caught the abra back across the creek to the gold and spice souk. An inexpensive and interesting way to spend a day in old dubai.
Old charm of Dubai. Here you can enjoy a dhow cruise with dinner. It takes about 2 hours and you can see all the buildings beautifully lighted up.A good experience to relax and enjoy the scenery.

Personal boar for 25 EUR - I'm in!. This is the old part of Dubai which is way different if compared to the new parts. You'll face different people selling stuff here - they are really trying hard which is understandable knowing this area is mainly populated by poorer people. Can't say they are too annoying, but if you have issues with patience - better ignore the market completely. This part is roughly 2 times cheaper then newer and more prestigious areas, so might be a good option if you want to save on eating out. But the best part is the boat tour you can have for 25 EUR or so. You just go to one of the boats, say the magic sentence which is "I want a personal tour with no people in the boat I don't know" and you'll get it. It's quite a long way to go passing lit up bots, so people attracted by shiny lights may find themselves being in ecstasy during the whole trip. All in all I liked it in here. Didn't spend too much time, so might have missed something, so will definitely come back.

Interesting. Spent a morning in this area lovely to walk round stopped at one of the cafes for lunch. Went across the creek for a very touristy boat ride good fun,very different to the high rise Dubai

Relaxing Experience M. First we stroll around the Gold souk then took a half hour traditional Abra ride for 60 dirhams. Sunset and evening are the best time for Abra ride, we enjoyed the scenic Abra ride with historic places on one side and burj Khalifa and high rises on the other side with lots of small ships and boats moving around you with fancy light and music over them.
peaceful pleasure. go there to just standby on the creek, feel the breeze, lets the waves splash in front of you. enjoy the feeling, no hustle
If your short on time don't bother.. Pretty much what you'd expect (tourist trap). Yes nice for a few photo's but if your short on time I wouldn't bother.

relax and absorb the culture in Dubai. If your not into commercialism and are interested in culture and history this is the area in Dubai for you.The restored traditional house museums are well worth a visit and make a pleasant diversion while strolling along the river bank.There is also a free safe /clean underpass that takes you under the water from one side of the river to the other. An area with plenty of variety all of which can be accessed in a relaxing way on foot., with your return across the river with the locals on the cheap ,frequent river boats.

Authentic Dubai. A fascinating waterway, flanked by Deira and its souks, residences and busy Emirati life on one side, and the restored historic areas of Bur Dubai and Al Fahidi, with their old windtower houses, Dubai Fort Museum and souks on the other. Really worth a visit.

After 20 minutes I'd had enough. Go for the Gold Souk or the diamond souk. Lots of hassle from sellers. The grand bazaar in Istanbul is a better experience. The water bus across the creek is worth it and atmospheric.

Creek in Dubai is exotic. Dubai Creek is something specialBig Malls and shopping You can find anywherebut walking along the Creek or crossing it by abras that is real DubaiAlso the government has seen that and under construction are now different areas around the CreekOn both sides of the Creek you can find old parts of Dubai: Heritage areas spice suq and the original Gold suq

The Old Dubai. This is a good place to come to get a completely different picture to the glamorous malls and bars/restaurants in Downtown Dubai.Start in Meena Bazaar and haggle with the shopkeepers on some spices and little gifts and then take an abra across the water to the Gold Souk. FYI this will cost 1Dhs per person (thats less than 20p!) and it is a super relaxing and scenic little ride! You can find some real bargains in the Gold Souk if you know how to haggle!!I enjoyed my time here - the shopkeepers become a bit exhausting with their constant "come in come in i give you good price" and sometimes it gets a bit tiring when you know the shopkeeper is just trying to rip you off - but it depends if you're up for the challenge!If you like seeing the real part of town and the locals - then head over to the Creek!

Amazing!. In the always busy Dubai, this was one of the most relaxing, and beautiful moments I had in Dubai! It is extremely cheap to rent a waterboat only €10 and it will bring you almost everywhere you want on the creek! I wish I had done this earlier my stay, because I would have done it multiple times! I loved it Defenitly a good thing to do when you are in Dubai!
Dolphin show rocks. Please visit Dolphin show. 70 Dirham per adult and 40 AED per child. Very good family thing. Child would surely love.

Dhow Cruice. Night cruise creek journey with dance dinner was very interesting. Two hours Cruise journey view of lighted Dubai metro city is an amazing . The dinner also very fine. Most of our team members enjoyed the journey. Those who visit Dubai Don't miss this Journey. Every day 7.30 pm the boarding in to Wooden ship will start.
Dhow trip. We went along the creek in a show. No commentary, but interesting and got us off the bus, and away from the traffic.

Good One. The creek is located at the heart of city in Bur Dubai area. It has the old shopping center for Dubai and various shops for Spices, Gold, Cloths can be found here. You must visit this place if you need to Shop...
Go for it!. Very real Dubai the water taxis are old and you do feel as if it has been there a long time. Sit downwind as the fumes from the engine are awful! Best value at 1 dirham!

Fascinating!. Spent a few hours at the Creek, took an Abra across to the Souks....the best 1 dirham we spent all holiday! Walk down the side of the creek and watch them loading cargo onto the old boats, it's fascinating! Brought back memories of Michael Palin boarding a boat in Dubai in the tv series 'around the world in 80 days' for those old enough to remember it!

What a treat - not to be missed. This is a taste of the Dubai of old.
Take a taxi down to Abra, and board a dhow. Its a short ride across the creek. The most fun you will ever have for 1 Dirham
Take a Stroll. A good place to talk a long walk along the creek specially at night after dinner during this time of the year.

Creek is good. Its good for time pass.
But few stuff are costly.
can enjoy with family. Go woth bunch of ppl. u will njy a lot
great place. We loved the old city, wandering around the souks and gold markets and watching the boats. Great fun bartering in the markets for goods, friendly people.

Old traditional place. Dubai creek is old traditional place. You can find traditional boat to go from one side to other side (deira to bur dubai). Hindu temple is there. Also dow crusie are station their. You can go for dow trip. Best time to go during night time.
Great atmosphere. Loved the creek and souks. Well worth a visit. The creek only costs one dirham to cross. The spice souks are amazing

Take a ride on boat - that's the besy way to look at Creek. At our 1st visit we walked there. At second - took an evening ride at arabian boat - the largest wooden boat built (as I was said).
Definitely worth visiting, but Dubai Marina Walk has much better views - especially after sunset.

Well worth a Visit.. 1Dirham for a trip across the Creek. Whilst there a Must Visit to Dubai Museum. Telling the growth @ history of Dubai. Then there's the Souk,s Haggle, haggle, Haggle. And you should get a Good Deal on Everything but the kitchen sink. And I,m sure they would find you one of those. Nice Eating places. We always eat at Bayt Al Wakeel Restaurant. Overlooking the Creek. Great food Great Service. But gets very busy.
Dubai the great outdoors. A great chance to get outdoors, to stroll and look at boats, to cross on an abra. It's cooler than most places with a breeze along it.

Old meets new. It's a fascinating place where yachts are moored near Dhows. Take a water taxi up the creek and marvel at the Dhow's bringing goods in. Watch the hive of activity as they are unloaded.The gold and spice Souks are in this area, as are the heritage buildings which are the best anywhere.

Good place - but nothing exciting. We visited the creek as a part of the City tour, The creek is man made. There is an area for water taxi. Do use it, it costs around 20 Dirahms. Its a good place to take photographs.

DUBAI CREEK - LIFE LINE OF DUBAI. Dubai creek divides Dubai in two areas - Bur Dubai and Deira Dubai... It is here, where pearl diving used to happen.... its a natural harbour which has brought prosperity to Dubai.

A bit of space... Good to be able to take 1DIRHAM abra across creek and see the surrounding skyscrapers. Lots trading vessels docked on creek side. Very bustling area. Indian majority with little souk alleys nearby. Good eats at creek side.
The heart of Dubai. Sit at a cafe on the creek in Bur Dubai and watch the dhows etc go past. You can also walk along the creek which is an enjoyable walk.

A step back in time to authentic Dubai. A trip to Dubai Creek is a must whilst in Dubai. The Creek is a very busy place and a hive of activity.For just a couple of dirhams you can hop aboard a wooden abra for a short ride across the creek to visit the spice souk and the gold souk. The textile souk is on the other side of the creek. Be prepared for some hard selling by the locals, which can be a bit overbearing at times. If you see something you like, enjoy the bartering experience and you can get a bargain, particularly in the textile and spice souks, There are lots of little side alleys stuffed with all kinds of souvenirs and bargains. We found a lovely cafe on the creek bank on the side of the textile souk, which was shaded and provided an excellent view of the creek whilst enjoying a delightful lunch. Give yourself at least three hours to enjoy this experience and go and bag a bargain! Word of warning, the ladies toilets in the car park by the spice souk are the stand up kind and there is no hook to put your bag on. Quite an experience!

Amazing views, great place for a walk.. We stayed at the Sheraton Dubai Creek and just had an amazing panoramic view from our Suite. It's just gorgeous at sunset and sunrise and a wonderful place for a morning walk and evening chill out spot. Lots to do, malls, restaurants, and the souks.

Just a Dirham for an Abra ride. I stayed in Bur Dubai and Dubai Creek separates this neighborhood from the Diera neighborhood. It is one Dirham to cross by wooden abra and the short ride is worth the Dirham in convenience and views of Dubai Creek. There are many old wooden dhows that ply the waterway. Access to Gold and Spice Souk necessitate crossing the creek. I did not see access for handicapped people being to easy but maybe there were other abras that can accommodate. This is a must do while in Dubai. There are dhow cruises you can take up the length of the creek as well.

OK. I found the Creek a place of interest. Looking at all the boats moored because of the current embargo to Libya. Going from one side of the creek and the water taxis was fun but a bit wobbly for a person with a slight disability. The Souk eye opening. All in all worth a visit!

Brilliant! Fantastic!. This is a must for any visitors to Dubai. Take the little boats across the creek for only 1 AED, amazing value! The whole chaotic experience is a memory that will last forever. we took dozens of photos and lots of video. we will definitely return when next in Dubai.

Excellent way to see Dubai from a different perspective. As a part of our ticket price for the Hop On Hop off bus we took a one hour cruise on the creek. We really enjoyed seeing the city from the water. It was fascinating to see the boat traffic and to see some of the famous landmarks from a quieter aspect. It well worth the time and price.

Interesting. It is an unusual place, especially for europeans. You can find here spices, gold, and just ncie walking place. Please make sure you visit it before noon, or in the evening, because some of the attractions close.

Shopping the Creek. This was a hustle bustle area, and could be intimidating if you
don't have a map and a well planned route.

Lovely in the evening. This is very pretty in the evening with all the boats and hotels lit up,The Bateau Dubai has excellent food and ambiance but although the dhows have the same view the food was very cold in the past so I was not willing to risk that again.
Taking a taxi across the creek GBP 40pence. Taking a water taxi is cheap and easy you can also pay more so that you barter the price to travel along the creek
Bateaux evening dinner cruise. This was a complimentary part of our holiday and the food was good. However it took an hour and a half to drive there from our hotel due to the high volume of traffic.

Inside history. If you cross the creek with an Abra, or a Ferry boat, you are inside history, the Dubai history. Very interesting bit of old Dubai, with the Spice Souk, old harbor, and etc. Very nice view in the afternoon.
Inexpensive and short way to see the old Dubai. A five minute scenic ride costing only 0.3 USD each way will take you to the historic part of Dubai.
Show cruise. The dhow cruise through the Big Bus was relaxing and the views were wonderful. Refreshments were for sale.
A bit of old Dubai. Very interesting bit of old Dubai. Take the ferry across the creek to visit the Souks and then back. Then sit in a café and watch the dhows go by.

Authentic Dubai. If you want to experience authentic old Dubai then head towards the Creek. Hop onto an Abra (AED 1) and enjoy the fascinating view. Unlike most of pristine Dubai, this is where the workers and working Dhow depart from. You can visit the Gold, Textile and Spice souq or visit the museum and heritage centre.

A way to see where it all began. The creek is an integral part of Dubai's history. The sites, smells and sounds are a great way to get a taste of what it used to be like as a trading centre. The buildings may have grown, but the premise of its use still applies today. It's amazing what these dhows (traditional vessels) carry onboard!
Cruise tour. Take a cruise tour in the creek with regular licenced boats. It includes buffet dinner and Egyptian dancers. A lady walks around adding Henna to those women who want to give it a try.

Nice - if you know where to go.. The Creek is a bit of an Enigma. The lower parts are full of small stalls selling a lot of tat and it can be annoying trying to dodge the 'vendors'. The other parts of the Creek are very impressive indeed.... especially the 'Dubai Creek Golf club end' up around the Park Hyatt.... This area is a hidden gem. The lower parts have character and may be good for the bargain hunters, but do yourself a favour - visit the ParkHyatt and take a stroll along the water edge. Its stunning - a part of Dubai that people rarely see.

Fantastic. After coming from Dubai mall, we headed fast to the dubai Creek for our Dhow Cruise dinner. We arrived on time and we boarded our assigned boat as what was stated in our voucher. The boat was okay but not that great, but was is great is our experience and the sight and lights that sorrounds you when the boat starts its cruising in the creek. The Tanura dance was nice at close view and the magic was fun.  Just a tip to all travellers, there are lots of dhow companies offering dinner cruises at Dubai Creek and Bur Dubai Creek. With crossed finger just wish that you will be assigned to a more welcoming one. Our experience this january 2015 was not so great but the one we had last December 2013 in Bur Dubai Creek was more enjoyable.

Worth a visit!. There are things to see and do on both sides of the creek such as the Museum and Old Fort and markets after you cross on the dhow. It gives you a good sense of the place away from all the glitz.

A Place To Tave A Very Nice Time. It was one of the first places in Dubai, i've visited for years. It's made for tourists, but still have the autentic look of the arabic world. The first few modern buildings built in Dubai stand there, but they don't disturb the view, they're matching to the buildings, built ih typical for the arabic countries style and this together with the old souq, with the whole ships (most of them restaurants) and the old town part Deira on the other side of the creek gives the unique touch of this place. Must see by sunset!
Something special about cities with water. Take a bus for 1 dirham and cross from one side to the other. Gets you out of the hubbub for a bit too!

Dirty Creek, not maintained. We have availed Dubai City Tour & apparently this is our very first stop. Dubai Creek divides Deira & Bur Dubai! There is an available dhow to transfer people between Deira & Bur Dubai & vice versa via the Creek (cost is AED 1).Since the water is dirty (saw loads of floating garbage), it's quiet smelly.Next time visiting Dubai, I will definitely try riding the dhow via The Dubai Creek!
Old Dubai. Really interesting area to visit and explore, the Old Fort and Museum in particular is well worth a visit

The water ferries are a must.... Your taxi across the creek is a rickety, wooden, barely functional water ferry. That's what makes it so much fun! Pennies for a ride, you'll enjoy a great view of the old & new Dubai. They're also your ride to the 'souks', selling all manner of things - some of the hidden gems of local culture. Spices, gold, and assorted other goods from around the region can be found here.

Hidden gem!. Took a taxi from Jumeriah Beach to the old Dubai.. Cost around £23. Top tip - just jump on the metro as this will take you straight there for around £2, it will also probably be quicker as the traffic can be very busy. When we arrived the smell of the spices coming from the spice souks were amazing. We bought a mix of spices to make some curries back home (not tried them as yet!).... Barter with the souk owners, don't be afraid to start with a low offer with a view to moving upwards. Take a ride across the creek on one of the local boats called an abra - ride with the locals, it will take 5 mins or so from one side to the other - will cost about 20p. Definitely worth a visit.
If u have time can go their. Nothing so great but good if you have time can go their....i was told its world longest natural creek and one of oldest
Fantastic. The creek cruise is fantastic in good day, and it took almost one hour to enjoy the landscapes of both sides of the creek.

Ride the water taxi across the Dubai Creek. Took the water taxi across the Dubai Creek to get to the gold and spice souks. It was a short but relaxing ride -- for only US$0.25. The taxis fill up quick but seem to run continuously so there was only a few minutes wait. We had great views of Dubai on both sides of the Creek. Very interesting.

A break from the Modern Dubai. Taking a water taxi across the creek is probably the cheapest things you can do in Dubai 1AED! But its great and highly recommended. Although nothing in Dubai seems to be old, this area is more working class and its nice to wander round with normal people and enjoy the buzz.

A view of the old Dubai. Yes, the new city is impressive with all these tall, ultramodern buildings but there is an old part of Dubai that you can't miss called the Creek where you can find old markets, restaurants and the feel of the Arabic culture. Walk around at your will, it's safe and owners of the stores will try to sell you everything they have, but that's the tradition and of course you must bargain with them to get a good price... it's part of the fun.

Beautiful oasis beside the Creek. Lovely park beside the water front of the Creek with expanses of lawn of Wimbledon standard. Ideal to relax under the trees for picnics with the family. We will definitely go back and check out the Dolphinarium next time. Cooling breeze coming from the Creek.

Busy Waterway. Dubai Creek divides Bur Dubai from Dierra and is a busy waterway full of hussle and bustlle. Take a walk through the old souks on either side and have a ride on a abra to get from one side to the other. Evening time is best.
Beautiful. Beautiful view of the "real" Dubai. The wooden badges really a great sight. The Dubai Creek area are always alive, especially at night time.

Lovely waters..... Lovely swimming and snorkelling in the creek. Lovely fish and the perfect way to cool down after the heat of the day. Note that in high summer when temps reach 40 deg plus, there will be some jellyfish in the warm water. Wont spoil, but just be aware.

Overrated.. Reading the local travel guides I expected to see something special here. But no, some local boats that provided a focal point for the river but precious little atmosphere, nothing particularly historic about the atmosphere and nothing special. Yes, it's nice to sit by the Creek for a drink but nothing to write home about.

Creek park with dolphinarium and bird show.. It good walking by the creek, Thy made a small mini beach. The park is good for families and kinds to enjoy barbeque and relax under the sun. The Dubai creek park have Dolphinarium and the Bird shows over here. To visit creek an hr is good, but it would g8 if you can add dolphin show in Dolphinarium.

Still the Middle East, with a touch of India..
