Its a well known fact, but not shouted loudly, that if all the people from the Indian sub continent plus Phillipinos went home tomorrow the Gulf States would grind to a standstill. Dubai Creek, which has more the profile of a decent sized river, than the normal idea of a creek. It buzzes with life till late at night, Abras(water taxis) ply their trade for a dirham a trip per person , and the whole area has loads of interest for people watching. In the evening brightly lit boats do pleasure cruises, meal, entertainment and two hours of sightseeing for around 100dirhams, which is a great bargain by any standards. This was my favourite part of Dubai.

The Creek. We initially got off at the wrong stop and walked out the station to nothing. When we got there it was worth it (get off at Dubai Healthcare City and get a taxi to the Creek Park. Really good for kids and so peaceful. We hired the dual bike and was so much fun.

Old Dubai built around this old port. The Creek in Old Dubai is worth a couple of hours of people watching to get a feel for how this port might have been before the hustle and bustle of the expanded commercial retail world took over in the rest of Dubai.

This is what Dubai is all about. It is easy to miss the real Dubai with all the modern glitz, this is where you can see and experience the hussle and bussle of life along the creek and in the souk. A night time dinner cruise provides a very different perspective with all the lights and noise of Dubai.

Very busy. Picturesque, lots of traffic. Yachts, abras, dhows, and other boats going by. Costs nothing to just watch the boats go by. Find the Creekside Cafe in Bur Dubai for breakfast and enjoy the view.

just for a one time ride. the divider line of old dubai with the new ! nothing much except the historical value , having taken cruise at the marina we gave ourselves a thumbs up ! this was not so enjoying plus the construction work was going on near the ruler court ! nearby small malls were a good bargain though ! just enjoy the ride by taxi if u have to choose between 2 cruises creek or marina choose the marina ! not the creek !
Love the Creek!. I love walking along the Creek and watching the Dhows cruise by. Well lit and safe with decent food options along the way. Great place to stroll and enjoy Old Dubai.

Must see this. A visit to Dubai must include a trip on the little boats taking you across the creek from one side to another. It is very cheap but if you are a bit unsteady on your legs take care as you have to step on the boat and negotiate other passengers to sit down. My husband and I paid for an extended trip and we were taken down the creek and back again. I wouldn't say there was much to see that we couldn't have seen if we had walked, in fact the men loading the ships could be seen at a closer distance if you had walked. It was amazing to see the things they were loading on the most rickety of boats - it looked like something from the Arabian Nights but the men had washing machines and fridges on their backs. Travelling on the creek was cooler however, and it was a lot easier seeing everything from the boat and no walking in the heat. It was unforgettable.

Underrated and beautiful. We were lucky enough to do a ferry tour through the creek not that long ago. Dubai is probably known for the ultra-modern city element and shopping and the desert. However, the Creek is absolutely gorgeous when viewed up close. We went on a clear day, and the water seemed clean and the atmosphere in the Creek was generally serene. For a bit of contemplation and something new, I would highly recommend taking a boat tour on the Creek, and bring a camera. It really is a different (and surprising) side of Dubai.
Local flavor. Here you can see the old Dubai, older building, boats, souks, small alleys. People trying to sell you stuff you don't need.. scarfs etc. But also gold, spices, fabrics. Worth visiting.

Very Interesting place. I walked throughout the area and learnt about the history of Dubai. I especially liked the Dubai Museum. I learned so much about how Dubai came to be as it is today. All tourists should make this stop.

Interesting Architecture. The old buildings at the bottom end of the Dubai Creek are interesting and well worth a visit. The place has been well restored and is clean and neat. Walk along the creek and then cross over the creek in one of the many boats and go through the spice souk. Well worth a visit and quite different to the glitz of modern Dubai..

Ok. Did a trip along the Dubai Creek as part of the Hop on Hop Off bus..The Big BusBoat was sub standard and trip short and very ordinary... The audio was so low could not hear it.... We did this trip a few years ago and it was for over an hour and extremely interesting.Would give this a miss if you are doing the The Big Bus

A piece of traditional Dubai!. We visited the creek at sunset which I must say I felt was the best time to visit!The creek is easily accessible on the metro & once you get off the metro head towards the sea. You get to walk through a traditional souk where I must admit you did get hassled but only in a nice kind of way!!! Lots of lovely gift shops, Indian street stands where you can pick up a samosa for less than 50p!!!Then you head towards the boats you can hire a private one if you wish but we decided to take the public one it was 1 dhs each !!!!This boat takes you over the creek . You can get off & enjoy a fresh fruit cocktail, coconut juice( served in the coconut) or a milkshake and watch the world go by & the sunset set over Dubai .A great experience that gives you a taste of the local culture & take in the atmosphere definetly worth the trip!

Clean. Unlike lots of places in the middle east, I have to say that the waterfront of Dubai Creek and the water itself are amazingly clean. The best way to see the creek is to take one of the Abra taxis across or to hire a abra for an hour cruise of the creek. I enjoyed going from the Textile Souk over to the Spice Souk. Very gentle and fast....

Very good. OK so we get there by coach its a old looking part of town and the boat trip up the river is very pleasant , You can buy a beer and just enjoy the view while sipping the beer, After you take a walk around the town have a bite to eat then get the coach back to your hotel, yep its worth a visit
Worth a visit. A lot more real than other parts of the city. Interesting & vibrant with real people not the usual expats you encounter.

A must in Dubai. Forget about Skiing in the sun, Mega Malls and the Burj - spend an afternoon walking along the creek and then wander into the gold suq on one side and cross the creek by water taxi to old Dubai. But walking along the creek is best, watching the old dhows being loaded and unloaded with all manner of goods - cars, fridges, furniture, ACs, tyres etc etc. Still more dhows and their crews are just relaxing awaiting their turn. Bring your camera along as there is much to photograph. When you are finished you could take a night trip on a floating restaurant. So much of what is best in Dubai happens along the creek.
Not a lot to see. Latest area to get a makeover, so not a lot to see , lots construction going on . Boat to other side nice, but then you are viewing lots of construction ??

A mini Chao Phraya. popping out of the narrow streets of the Meena Souk onto the Dubai Creek at night is an explosion of light, hustle and bustle as nighttime dinner cruises like mobile Christmas Trees vied for space with Abras (ferry boats) plying their trade across the souk in huge numbers. It reminded me of a scaled down version of the Chao Phraya in Bangkok, where the river is the life-blood. The creek is, in its lower reaches at least, a real attraction with many of the tradition aspects of the old town on show.
Go see it -- it was pretty cool. Great place to stroll around at night, watching the water taxis and the small freighters offloading their cargo to sell directly on the street.

Old dubai. The area round the creek is noisy bustling dirty and full of character, and it feels like stepping back into the origins of the cityGold souks and spice souks are great fun and take a water taxi across the creek.I always try and go there and get away from the glitz for a while
In the gold marked. There was very funny to visit the gold marked, we met at lot of interesting people in this site. Hope we meet them again.Special the guy who sold us Arabic dresses and gold.
Historic. This was a very interesting place to go to. Learning the history of Dubai, and how it was developed was very interesting.
Interesting. Worth a trip on the creek and a visit to local souks. The round the city bus gives a free river cruise.

Dubai Evening Dinner Cruise. This was a Groupon Tour and once we got over the hiccup of finding the boat, as they Company had changed it's location collection point, the tour itself was a great success. The food was OK, but the entertainment on board was fabulous, and seeing all the other boats on the water lit up was amazing. My parents visiting, absolutely loved it. A good night's entertainment.

Dubai Creek tour. The creek tour was included on the big buss ticket, so we did the tour in the morning. You have the option to do with dinner at night, but for me to see the cities face from the creek was more important that the night tour. We had in schedule to do the night tour with the bus.From the creek you see a different face of Dubai, and the importers from all over the world, of course the majority from India and Asia.Strongly command this tour during the day.

Somewhere with some character. Dubai Creek provides a great contrast and gives a small insight into what Dubai was really like before the developers and concrete pourers moved in. I enjoyed watching the dhows sail in and discharge their cargoes at the dockside and the very cosmopolitan feel of the place. Although we didn't do the abra ride (at AED1 this must be the best value attraction in Dubai!) it looked worthwhile to give a different viewpoint.We toured the gold, textile and spice souks and bought some excellent dates. As you might expect, stall owners are keen to get your business but a polite decline and a smile works every time so there is no real hassle.The sights, sounds and smells (especially the fish market) contrast nicely with the rather sterile concrete canyons in some other parts of the city
Romantic Dinner on the boat. Well entertained with dance and show. Atmosphere was good. Staff was good. It was Free from Funtours package I had.

Amazing.. It doesn't seem possible in this day and age when you are surrounded by fantastic futuristic buildings in the setting of Dubai, that there could still be a living page of history, from days gone by, in the form of all these hundreds of Dhows still hand loading their cargo onto these obviously seaworthy but ancient types of craft, Amazing.

Outdoors, Away from the Hustle Bustle (Mostly). The Dubai Creek is a nice place to get out and move around, take a walk, hit a couple of souks (markets), and be away from the high-rise, concrete mother of cities that Dubai is becoming.It's worth taking a boat ride on one of the water taxis, just to see the city from a different perspective. Safe, clean (by UAE standards), and efficient (also by UAE standards).
A tour on the boat. We went on a boat alone in two. The boat could bring 18 people so we were very happy to be alone. Saying that, it was a very boring half hour. OK for one time, not more.
Abra-ride for 1 AED!. The best way to cross the creek is to join passengers on a small dhow called Abra, where you are ferried over for a mere 1 Dirham. The ride is wonderful, especially at sunset!

A taste of Old Dubai - Abras. We crossed the creek on an abra (water taxi) as part of our individual guided tour. The trip only takes 5 - 10 minutes and you can take in all the views and smells as you cross on your way the the Linen/Spice and Gold souks.We really found it a most enjoyable experience.

NOT WHAT WE EXPECTED. The creek is like a river with small wooden boats all around the edge which takes people for rides. They also bring cargo from further up the water where the big ships stop. The cargo is put anywhere all over the docks , very interesting

It's okay. Old dubai. It's good for old people I guess and if you want to get harassed by people selling spices fake watches and clothes.Make sure you tell your taxi driver old dubai Creekside or he will take you to Creekside park which is for kids amusement.Enjoy.
Sailing old world style. Really lovely evening sailing along the Creek in the evening. Meal was really lovely and plenty of it.

The heart of old Dubai. A trip to Dubai is not complete without visiting the Creek and Al Diera. Thousands of people still use the small ferries (Abra) to cross the river near the old port and some Abra operators offer trips up the creek. These are inexpensive and well worth an hour of your time. You can see the old harbour, which is still used by dozens of commercial dhows to trade spices, rice and other goods with Iran and nearby countries. These goods are then sold in The Spice Market, The Old Souk and wholesalers in Al Diera. It's a step back in time. Beware of he street hawkers trying to sell you fake watches and handbags and expect prices to double when there's a cruise ship in port.

Beautiful View. We wanted to have a walk along the creek but it was under construction - only a short opening was left to access it. The old looking smuggler ships painted in blue were lined up on the other side along with the buildings of the Old Dubai - enjoyable view. We crossed the creek itself many times by car when travelling from one side of Dubai to the other and it's always nice to watch boats on the water. The bridges open up sometime after midnight to let the ships cross, so if you happen to be on a bridge at that time you will have to wait for 20 - 30 mins.
Radisson Blu Fish Market. Great end to our holiday, see seperate review. If you are looking for fish with brilliant wiews of the creek , this is the place to go

Nice walk along the creek. The Dubai Creek is a place you have to visit during your escape to Dubai. Book a cruise to dine or just a boat to enjoy Dubai's skyline. For those who do not want boats or cruises, you can still do some walking or jogging by the creek side while enjoying the views of the giant surrounding buildings. I recommend that you go at sunset or at night because the views get livelier as the city turns on its lights.
The real Dubai.. I loved it! Take an Abra and travel to the past. It's like you are in a movie...many stores with thousands of spices from all around the world, gold, wonderful fabrics...You must go!

interesting and worth a visit. The Creek area was a complete change from the glitz of the new Dubai Mall area. The buildings were old and the souks were worth a visit, despite the hassle from the traders. The boat trip across the Creek was only 1 aed and although felt a little precarious was a good experience.
So relaxing. The Creek is one of the classic places to visit in Dubai. The gold is wonderful and the swimming complex is private and relaxing. Well worth a visit. Book first!
The heart of the city. With so much on offer along the creek allow a few hours or more. Or just sit and eat at one of the many little restaurants. Great view not to be missed.
Picturesque. It's the only actually typical site of Dubai. Take an Abra (boat) and cross the river to visit the other side (Downtown or Deira).
Loved it.. This was at the top of our list to visit.Fantastic peaceful laid back even though trading was taking place.
Go by water transportation. The best way to enjoy the place is go there by the Abraor the RTA Water Taxi/Busor maybe from the Dubai Festival City

Sunset by the creek. took the ancient boat and cross the bank. it was during jan and weather is really cooling and just right before the sun set.. lovely cruising.. and visited the gold souk, spices... which is a lovely stroll.. bought a mini camel soft toy as souvenir.
Souks. We visited the whole area including gold souk, fruit souk, fish souk, fabric souk, spice souk and the shore. It was very contrasting to the other modern city parts.
Nothing to see.. We went wth the metro to the end station. Nothing to see or do. So we just returned without getting out.
boat ride -- Abra, is superb. A ride in boat to on the creek and then entering the local market was great. Do your shopping from local markets only. Avoid spending in malls on shopping.

love the creek. If you go to Dubai don't miss going to the creek. The contrast between old and new Dubai is amazing . Take a ride on the little abra boats and see the old dhow boats as they have always been. This area is a must see when in Dubai.

Didnt understand it?. We had booked outings through a travel agent and everyone else on the Doha cruise seemed to be from India or nearby countries and therefore felt very uncomfortable not speaking the same languages and being a big culture barrier. Food was OK. and you do not see much in terms of sights on the cruise. it was a buffet but seemed more like a first come first served basis, though for something which was inclusive of our package could not complain much. If they are able to do these with more of a sophisticated touch, would more than likely do it again. Entertainment was a must see, egyptian dancer, very good and engaging the crowds and a belly dancer too.

A must to see the other side of Dubai. the old town, the creek and the markets give you a wonderful feel about the old Dubai looked like before everything is the biggest and best. I truly enjoyed our little boat ride, the walk around, eating some local food and discover the magic of the orient

Good by day and by night. We've strolled around the Creek area on both sides in the daytime and have taken a dinner cruise on the Creek in the evening. Lovely late January warm weather.The atmosphere along the creek,especially on the south side in the area of the Old Souk is vibrant - busy with locals and tourists coming and going off the Abras and in and around the Souk stalls and local "real" shops.The north side is not so visually attractive, but interesting nevertheless to walk along Baniyas street and watch the boats being loaded by hand with goods of every description. Further along one can see the long line of Dhows tied up which are used for Creek cruises and dinner cruises. But from this side there is access to the Gold and Spice souks and other parts of the old town. This side can be easily reached by metro to Union Square and a short walk. The south side can be reached from the Burjuman metro and a longer walk along interesting local streets on the edge of the old town area. Or an abra ride from one side to the other for i dirham (cash, correct change to the boatman as you get on board).
Beautiful!. Definitely worth visiting when around the Souq area. You can try taking the Dhow from one side of the creek to other. Good place to walk around, click some pics :)

Gold souk a must. Tavel acroos the creek by public boat for 1 dirham just for the experience. Souks are very interesting, you do get asked if you would like fake hanbags,watches etc, but if you say no you are left alone.Super place to get lost in

The real Dubai. Worth a visit en route to the gold or spice souk - just to watch the old wooden boats unloading huge fridge freezers, TVs, washing machines etc is unique (all done by hand!!) - to get a better view, take an hours trip on a boat or even a water taxi from one side of the creek to the other.

Authentic Dubai.. There is very little that is authentic in Dubai but the dhows on the creek give an idea of how the city traded before the end of the twentieth century. It's fun to crisscross the creek in the abras for a few pence. There are regular shops and cafes as well as the souks which are much more touristy. You will be accosted to buy pashminas, counterfeit handbags and spices. The gold on display in the gold souk is incredible, especially the large Indian wedding jewellery.
The ocean at your doorstep. The creek has a plethora of restaurants and shopping options. The evenings turn romantic with the soft lights and cool breeze caressing your face.

Dhow Cruise. Some agencies offer Dhow Cruise in wooden motorised boats, which lasts two hours, usually between 7.30 pm to 9.30 pm. In the boat I went in, it included vegetarian food, and some loud punjabi dance for what passes for entertainment. But, if one ignores these loud interferences, one can enjoy the leisurely cruise of a couple of kilometers along the Dubai Creek. It is not very expensive. Costs about 60 dirhams including food. Some boats are drab, such as the one I went in. But, other boats sport fancy illuminated decrations.
Lovely place. We loved staying in Dubai creek. Close to the souks, it was just so nice to walk around and we felt so safe.

A different view. This gives you a different view of the city in a very relaxing way. You get a commentary and was included in our Red bus tour. Book separately and it is very reasonably priced. The creek is the older part of Dubai and is near the museum and Gold Souk. It's also interesting to see the 'freight boats' being unloaded.
A fun day out. A bit rough and ready, an abra is worth it, but only at a dirham. Don't be cheated. Can Be dirty. Can be pestered.

Fab tour. We went on the creek tour 17th October,,this is a great way to get a view of the marina and an insight into the history of the buildings,,it a beautiful boat trip and it's great fun.english speaking guide is very good too..would reccomend highly..

Must see the Creek!. Go see some of the souks in old Dubai, and then walk to the Creek. See how daily commerce and shipping goes. See the Abra Dock and take an abra to the other side of the Creek for only 1AED. Then walk and see some of the other souks and parts of old Dubai. Great outing.

Boring. It is just a creek, with boats plying it in and out. There are a couple of quiet restaurants along, none of which serves alcohol. It is near the old Dubai, so strolling along can be a little interesting

Great walk, local life!. Dubai Creek was a great and nice surprice! The contrast between modern tall buildings and small wooden boats, local life, street markets - everything amazed us in a good way. We took the small local passenger boat to get from one shore to the other (1 dirham). Once walking along the bay, you can visit the gold and spice market, right oposite on the other side is the souvenir market and the old town and Dubai museum.
Old dubai creek. Lovely boat trip up the creek, part of the Big Bus tour, interesting commentary. Briefly visited the souks, but we were hassled too much for us. Not aggressively, but constantly.

see the other face of dubai. the best way to discover the creek is to take dhow cruise through the creek and there a lot of them near the british embassy and there are sunset cruises and night cruises ,you can choose between.

Nice peaceful time. Spending time at Dubai creek is a very good experience. You can get good peace there. Also Dow cruise facility is available at creek. You can enjoy boat ride. Good restaurants are very near.

Dont go the Bird Show. The bird show is a rip-off - don't go to it...the birds can do very little and sometimes nothing at all...we were really disappointed with this...the dolphin show we saw was the discounted Monday 11am show and was worth the money though plenty of children bought balls for 20 AED to throw in to win prizes (prizes not worth it),...the balls were selected by the dolphins before most had even been thrown in by the children...this apart the dolphins appeared healthy and it was lovely to watch their athleticism
Good view. Nice area to view the bay but full of tourist. Went on city tour but it was just a shopping venture!. Not what I expected on this tour
Dubai Creek. Very nice place to visit, by day or by night, many restaurants, cafee, other delights, many luxury yachts, jaust take a seat and look
good atmosphere. it is a very pleasant tour on boat (1hour) so you can see the new buildings and the boat. you can enjoy also a simple walk around.
Lovely part of Dubai....what it used to be.. Had a great meal on the Creek, at a little restaurant, so much happening in that area, very touristy, but Hey! that's what vacations are about right??

If Dubai had soul, it's here. This is the oldest part of Dubai where it all started in the Bastakiya quarter as a small fishing and pearl diving village.Apart from shiny blistering Sheikh Zayed Road, this is old part with souks, small shops, locals,... Stroll through the small winding streets, have a squeezed juice, eat on the street in local pubs, bargain in shops,... Visit the Gold and Spice souk.Take an abra ride across the Creek from one side to another (1 Dirham pp) or rent your own abra for a half an hour cruise along the Creek (60 Dirham, 14 Eur).

Lovely way to spend the day.. Went to Dubai Creek for most of the day, spent time wandering the heritage village, looking at artworks and various buildings.Walked a long distance past beautifully restored buildings. Lots of cheap eateries or nice restaurants, depending on how much you want to spend.We then went into the souks which are fun but can be a bit annoying with people trying to sell you fake bags, watches and iPhones.Can go on a Abra up and down the creek for about 120 dirhams. Worth visiting.
Lovely Place. This is one of the lovely place in Dubai specially if you rent a boat there and take a tour in the creek along with your family to see Dubai from water

worth it purely for ride of Doha. if you are going to visit the souks and have seen others around the world (Morocco, Tunisia etc) these Are far more modern and I didn't find as interesting. The boat trip was worth it though

Special Experience. I never thought riding a cheap water taxi (only 1 Dirham) can bring a special experience. We can see a lot authentic Dubai's building in a relaxing atmosphere.After a short ride, you can continur your journey by visiting gold and spice souk. Special experience.
Feeling so nice . It's my one of the best place in Dubai it's a such a nice place to spend weekend and the nice creek I will feel like a river where we can enjoy our trip in 1 aed by small boat
amazing city view. this place is just amazing, i been there and crossed by abra from Diera side to Bur Dubai Side and really liked

Nice to see all boats. I walked along the Dubai Creek and took a taxi to the other side, costed 1 AED andles then 10 minutes. You can book a table at a restaurant boat or just eat at some restaurants. Boat traffic at nicght is nice to see.
Old Dubai. its a wonderful experience if you would like to see old Dubai. Its one of the places worth seeing, gives quite an authentic feel about the city itself

Historical side of Dubai. I would say that this place really historical which is amazing. Dubai, obviously is an expensive and fancy city and you must to discover this part of Dubai too. I loved the boat in creek which will take you to the other side of the area opening the market full of literally everything. And this boat trip is only 2 AED! Also the amazing fact is the old Dubai has it's charm, you will find the museum, the arabic restaurants along the lake (i think it's lake), you can enjoy food and shisha with a great view. I love it!

Neat experience. We took the little boat taxi across the creek and it was a true experience. The ride is no more than 5 minutes but it is the way people have crossed the creek for 100 years. It's noisy and busy but so much fun. Don't miss the opportunity to see a different side of Dubai!

Better than the Venetian waterway!. For someone who doesn't enjoy boats too much, it was a pleasant surprise.so this is the way, that people in the older days travelled around in dubai. the old boat system was used. one can take a boat, bask in the sun, enjoy the cool breeze and peacefully glide across the clean waters of the dubai creek. the system is clean and un-crowded. one can enjoy a peaceful ride. we (a couple) got into a boat with only the pilot. had the boat all to ourselves at a meager AED 12 or so. had a fantastic experience!if you take a boat from dubai creek to the heritage village area, it saves you a walk too!

Ride on an abra. Undoubtedly, one of the best things to do in Dubai. We hopped on an abra (small wooden boat) after leaving the gold souks and experienced what life would have been like in ancient times. The creek was absolutely bustling and we felt like locals on our rocking little boat. At 1 dirham paid to the ferry driver, it was the cheapest and most authentic experience of our holiday.

Historical Significance. Known to Ancient Greeks as River Zara, Dubai Creek has an undeniable historical significance in the city surrounding it today. The most authentic way to experience the creek is through the abras (small wooden boats that carry around 10 people at a time).

authentic. best way to enjoy the sightseeing is to take a boat from dubai marina to the creek,or take an authentic boat in the creek,you will enjoy the old dubai houses and buildings and may be you can have a nice meal in one of the floating restaurants in the creek

Traditional hustle and bustle. Dubai Creek is the old heart of the city. It may be old but it is a very active and energetic place to visit. Try the water buses. They are cheap and give you a great view.

Must see... Trip to Dubai is incomplete without visiting this part of the city, to ferry across the creek, or shop by the numerous souks lining the market place. Its an ideal location to spend a nice evening.

Highly recommended. Place where you really get to know the city of Dubai and get the chance to observe how it looked in the past. Definitely worth the visit!We started in Bur Dubai by Sheikh Mohammed centre and continued through Souk to the water taxi which took us on the Deira side. An amazing afternoon walk.

Vibrant, exciting.. Spare an hour and a few pence to take the ferry across the creek and enjoy watching the boats load up, stacking everything, including the kitchen sink, into boats that look barely seaworthy. They are departing to places we have all heard of but are unlikely to visit. This is a million miles away from the sterile shopping malls and Vegas style attractions. Here you get to experience Dubai as it once was - crowded, bustling, loud, smelly and fascinating. The boats are crewed by very young men, daring to cross seas in crafts that are heavily overloaded and are belching black smoke . Wouldn't stand a chance against the pirates now moving into the area. The old Souk near the water taxi stop also offers bargains so much better than the malls and department stores. The fabrics are superb and a tenth of the price in the UK.
An experience. This is the older city.. the bustling markets and people everywhere.. def an experience though.. sometimes it gets too crowded and one should be careful with ones bags etc
Make sure you visit !!!!. Charming place to visit the old part of Dubai. A water taxi is very interesting to see the buildings from the sea. Shops are interesting, plenty of places to eat and drink.

Nice. A visit to the Dubai Creek area is a pleasant one. Ot gives you the opportunity to see an authentic part of the city and its culture. You can ride on a water taxi to enhance the experience and then spend some time looking/ shopping at the souks.

The heart of Dubai. Went across the Creek on an abra from Bur Dubai to the Gold and Spice Souk station. The Abra station by the Spice Souk appeared to be undergoing repairs and so only two docking spots were available, which made for a bit of a wait, but wasn't a big problem. At one Dirham per person per crossing this trip is tremendous value. We enjoyed feeling the wind on our faces enjoying the sights along the creekside particularly the colourful dhows. The Creek feels like the heart of Dubai. Super atmosphere. Well worth a visit. Not for the faint hearted though, getting on and off an abra can feel very insecure, it often rocks as you and others get on, riding across the Creek you are very close to the water with no sides to the vessel to give you a feeling of protection and there can be a violent bump when you dock. All in all a fun thing to do though.

Lots of fun. The 1Dh water taxis late at night over dubai creek with a full moon is lots of funA great way to experience and view downtown dubaiAm not sure if it will be very busy ferrying workers during the day but was empty about 9pm

Abra ride to cross Dubai Creek. It's a good experience to take Abra (water taxi) to cross the Dubai creek to reach the other side where you can visit Gold and Spice Souq in Dubai. The ride is short and you get to see the old Dubai. Here you can buy some value for money souvenirs and spices are nicely packed as souvenirs too. There is a goldsmith shop displaying a world Guinness record gold ring where you can take pictures.
Great ride on abra. You only spend 1 Dirham to ride the abra with great view and good experience ever. Truthly authentic Dubai.

nice place. there are plenty of places and museums to see here and it is a nice place to walk about. You can take a wter taxi ride here too. It is a lot different from the modern part of Dubai and gives a flavour of what Dubai used to be like before it went all Las vegas.
Interesting experience. Very interesting area of Dubai full of history and a place you must see if you are in Dubai just to get the feeling of the past, we enjoyed it.

Had fun in the Abra (cross the river!). It was fun to cross the river... felt like a local in that small boat with no safety at all :) just a dirham the ticket and a lot of nice pictures taken from there. The rest is nice, lots os small business, souks (markets) and big boats where you can have a dinner with show
very good views at night. It is very good experience to have a ride on cruise n feel the likes n dislikes as it cannot be mentioned here

Good Place to Chill !!. The cafes on the side of the road look like those in Europe and you could forget that you are in Dubai when sitting in them. The Yatch rides are great fun and so are the cruises. Added bonus is the long line of sports cars driving around in the area.

Feel the wind. My parents had come to visit us and took them at dubai creek we enjoyed the dhow cruise as well it was quite peaceful to spend time at the creek with kids enjoying the sunset and open air. Good to visit in evening as it will be pleasant

Worth it for the contrast with 'new' Dubai. As with other reviewers, we enjoyed the trip across the creek and wandering around 'old' dubai and the souk. It doesn't quite have the charm of much of the less developed souks and river crossings of the world but it's still a nice diversion away from the gleaming steel and glass. We went just before sunset which made it all the more photogenic and worked in a trip to the museum before crossing on the Abra.

Does not feel like commercial Dubai. Even though it is very short taking a trip across the creek by ferry is highly recommended. You can stroll along the creek and then visit the old bazaars which are a sight in themselves

Must be done. Just a 10 minute boat trip from the new concrete and modern Dubai to the old town Dubai with the Spice market and 240 gold shops in the souk.Each boat takes a maximum of 22 persons but as there are so many boats they tend to carry around 10 a time as there are so many boats.

boat ride. The old boats on dubai creek is a cheap but still enjoyable experience. It costs just one dirham and appox have a 10 minutes journey accross where you can find old souk.We went in the night time so enjoyed the pleasant weather. The smoke from the boat was though little intolerable.Somehow (may be due to the resemblence of surrounding) We got a same feel of boating in river Nile
Dubai Creek. I am in Dubai on a regular basis- and I always go for a walk along the creek. It is beautiful.I like everything- and dislike nothing

Just enjoy the beauty of creek. If you have time just go to creek and watch the activities, movement of dhow and small ships. The water is very calm and with clean surrounding all around its worth a visit

Beautiful creek in a city landscape. I am so thankful to reviews of Dubai creek, without which we will not have visited the place. When we go to Dubai, the main attractions that were normally publicised were the malls and the Burj Khalifa. However, I think one should go to the creek and the markets if time permits. My family rented a boat (120 AED). The boat will bring you along the creek for an hour. As you go along, you can also see the city landscape and the mosques. If not booking the whole boat, it only cost 1 AED for a ride across the river. The market is situated on the other side of the creek and is worth visiting. It has a bit more character and one can find unique stuff at the markets. As we were there in the evening, the temperature was perfect and the sunset was a sight to behold.

Big and beautiful park. The park really big and interested, my children like it because they can ride a drive a cars and pike there, there are different type of trees and plants, it looks that they brought these trees from different countries. Although the park is big, There was no enough canteens nor cafeterias.Ticket price is 5 Dirham, cable cars was closed.

Very Nice!. I really enjoyed the Dhow cruise! which goes for about 2 hours and I went for dinner and it was nice ambiance and the food was authentic and also tasted great. You can go own your own just organize everything at the concierge desk at the hotel you might be staying, a worthy experience!

One of the most important identities of Dubai ....... Must do a Dhow cruise along the Dubai creek. The bridges over the creek look beautiful at night, thanks to some very tastefully done lighting effects.

Creek Park- nice but watch out for horse and trap ride. This is a large, attractive park situated at the Bur Dubai side of the creek. It contains a dolphinarium and there is an area of children’s rides and bike hire and several blocks of toilets. We walked around the small, main, central area of the park then decided to have a ride in a pony and trap. We asked how long this would take and were told it would take around half an hour, went around the whole of the park and would cost 50 AED. In reality, we took exactly the same path we had already walked round, which was only a tiny area of the park and this took exactly seven minutes. When we challenged the driver, he claimed he had said he would take us round half the park, not for half an hour, but either way, we did not get what we had been promised and considered this to be a rip off. Eventually, after some discussion, the driver refunded our payment, however, be warned, it is not worth doing.

Dubai Creek. A place to visit and see the Dubai by the Creek. Nice clean water and cool atmosphere to be. You can collect all your Family & Friends and have good get together.Nice place to visit in evening. To sit peacefully looking at the water of creek as good stress buster.
Nice boat trip. You get your eyes opened to the Old Dubai. Ferry's small boats, large ones and the range of cargos that defy most custom!

Make sure you know the location of the correct ferry terminal. A most interesting area to explore with plenty of really great photo opportunities. Make certain you know the location of the correct ferry terminal to catch the boat to the other side or to explore the Creek. There seem to be concessional ferry terminals and full-fare terminals close to each other. If you walk in the wrong direction from the fort, there are no ferry terminals, just a large white fence that prevents access to the Creek and which runs for several kms.Hiring a boat from one of the many spruikers is much more expensive than the ferry, so be patient and wait for the latter.

Dubai Creek. A scenic, fun outing that is well worth the timeThe Creek is one of those attractions that has a distinct 'local' flavour. Authentic, operating Arabian Dhows plying their trade is something you'll see nowhere else but in the Middle East.You can take a water taxi to and from various points along the creek, visiting the Old Spice Souq or crossing the Creek and taking a short walk to the Gold Souq.The water taxis are lots of fun, but hang on when it comes to docking, these guys believe in parking by touch.At night the floating restaurants pass by, lit up with party lights all over the place.creek-side restaurants cater mainly to tourists and serve mainly Arab dishes and specialities.Lots of fun, very scenic and well worth a trip

Where the History lies!. Dubai creek is always charming and surprising! During winter, it is more romantic with the fantastic view of the array of seagulls on water and uninterrupted cold breeze.Also, anchored boats that loading goods to Iran bringing the picturesque views like a black and white Cinema. Somewhere you might feel you are time travelling to 19th Century.By night, decorated dhows and floating restaurants are making a festive atmosphere. Both banks of the creek, either Deira or Bur Dubai, it is the perfect place to chill.

Awesome view of Abra. I really love Dubai Creek because I loved to use Abra to cross Dubai Creek, During morning hours, you can see the live action of shipping, busy activities, all sorts of people walking across the streets, During the night hours, you can view the buildings and shops lit in busy towns on both sides Deira and Burdubai, where as abra boats crossing each other.

The 'Real' Dubai. Great place to spend a day, ok you will get hassled in the markets but ignore them if your not interested. Don't miss the spice and gold market, Dubai museum worth the 3 AED to find out how the area has developed since the 60's.Find the local restaurants and enjoy the fantastic salads and meat dishes.

About to get even bigger. The main vein or artery of Dubai the Creek is the life bllod of the city since its humble beginings to the modern day focal point of so many places. Dine on the Boadwalk, the Intercon at Festival city or sail and dine to see the spectacular contrast of old and new Dubai.

I like this place, and regularly visiting it. Visited this place more than 10 years back, and regularly visit it again, enjoying the walk along its banks, the view during the sunset is great, you will see small ships load /unload . you can take small water taxi (Public) to travel across the Greek with minimal cost, and you will greatly enjoy that experience

Old but in heart of city. Peacefull calmful and good beach especially in the burdubai side of creek park where you can enjoy most of diera buildings in back drop in the entrance ie the sindaga tunnel goes below the creek bar mouth , you have major areas like historical area in burdubai side and the fishmarket and old diera buildings and dubai muncipality in diera side,lot og cruise boast operate here durinmg autumn and winter season 1 to 2 hr trips ,there is also the traditional small boast which zigzag bw burdubai and diera that the creek divides you have 4 bridge s above the creekteh makthoum bridge ,the floating bridge the business bay bridge and the gharoud bridge,the creek used to end in ras al khor area but now dubai govt is extending the creek to safa park cutting shk zayed road to back to sea
Peaceful. You can sure see the sights and the watertaxi's an experience and a great form of transport and so cheap.

Wonderful experience. Best way to see the Dubai creek, is in dhow cruise. You will see both sides of Dubai. At one side there is modern architectures, while in the other old souks. You will really enjoy.

Go there. I wasn't expecting such a clean pleasant experience. There are a couple of good cafés and always a cooling breeze, and the boat trip across to the gold souk is fun. Great people watching with the dhows being loaded. The markets are a manufactured tourist attraction but that doesn't detract too much from the overall experience.

The last piece of traditional Dubai. it was wonderful to spend half a day at Dubai creek, Catch a local Dow across the creek and into the old quarter for some traditional markets and real sights of traditional Dubai.
Nice boat trip. Very good place to see de inside and old parts of Dubai. You can start from the market, then take a boat and you will get too the souks and gold markets.

Creek revisited. I was in Dubai in 1972 and The Creek was about all there was apart from dessert The Dhows are still amazing and watching the men load them is fascinating. The souks are so worth a visit and a boat trip across the river is a must. The crowds are fun to watch and it is safe to walk about.

I love dubai. Creek whenever I need relax during weekdays or weekend am just go to creek both side old and new beautiful buildinds water boats u will enjoy what a clean maintenance really heart touching deep blue water love dubai

Perceft to see the old parts of Dubai. We walked along the Dubai promenade and we took the abra across the Creek. In contraiction to the modern and alert Dubai this is the perfect spot to get to see the local and "real" Dubai. Crowded and surrounded by the souqs this is a perfect spot to see another part of the town. Well worth to spend at least a half day.

Good walk or run if you're looking for some kind of relaxing environment in Dubai. Escaping the concrete jungle is not easy in Dubai without hitting right away sandy patches. If you don't want always to run the special build track at the Russian beach, a few km along the creek is always relaxing - if you wait, like I always did, until late night or very early morning hours. Best between 4 and 6am. The temperatures are then down to around 30 centegrees even in the hot month and the pollution level it's on it's lowest. And it's before morning rush hour starts. Run or walk from the flyover in Deira coming on the right side of the creek, passing some impressive and expensive looking "boats" and countless historic and modern trawlers with their crew still sleeping or starting slowly to load the empty spaces for a new delivery.

Nice setting....take a water taxi for 1 AED. Safe and nice walking area. Take a water taxi for 20 euro cents and walk to Union station Subway. Water taxi is a normal available mode of transport althought most people want you to take a tourist trip for 20 euro (!) 30 min...

Abra's great, Souk's ok. We did the Abra crossing in the evening which was very atmospheric and highly recommended. The Souk's were very oppressive and were spoiled by constant badgering by touts even when you had said you were not interested to 100 who had already given you the same spiel.If you have the time and are reasonably close be do the abra crossing but I would ignore the markets. The boat station is less than a 5 minute walk from the metro

nice park to rest. a fantastic park, near the souks and the businness center, perfect for children, with tens of activities there. Better go afternoons-evening, because on the morning many of the atractions are closed.

Dubai Creek. It has small boats which takes you from Dubai to Deira and from Deira to Dubai back it has a very minimum charges compared to a Taxi, and it is fun travelling by boat which is called Abra here in Dubai there are RTA boats also with AC you can travel in that also but you need a RTA Card for that, the RTA card if you purchase is valid for Boats, Buses and Metro but only if you purchase a Silver Card the Red card is used as temporary travel card which u can use for a single destination only.

A romantic evening. It was the month of March but the evenings were pleasant as the summer had not set in. I and my wife took a half an hour trip on a small boat along the creek waters. It was a very pleasant and enjoyable ride with only two of us on that boat. The clear open skies with the moon shinning, sounds of breeze, the motor of the boat and water splashing the banks made it a very special and romantic evening for us. It is a pleasure worth experiencing.

This is where Dubai Started. The creek holds a lot history of Dubai. Dubai was born along the creek. A must visit. Lot of cruise options but a must try are the Abra's which are the old traditional ferrying system in the creek and has survived all these years even until now where the commuters use them to cross the creek between Deira Dubai and Bur Dubai. The creek has lot of parks, restaurants, shopping areas, hotels over looking where people can spend time and see life as it goes by in the creek. Some sections of the creek are used for trading by the traditional larger dhows doing business and carrying goods.

Dubai Creek. We went to the Souqs (historic market district) in Diera. And we just happened onto the Creek. You cross it in an abra (small boat) for one durham. Old cute little shuttle water taxis. Don't let their appearance deter you. They are safe and a fun experience. Short ride across the creek to Bur Dubai (more Souqs). There are a variety of boats/tours available to view the Creek. You need the full OLD and New experience of Dubai. This is the OLD. Enjoy.

Still one of the most impressive sites in Dubai.... Burj Khalifa, Dubai Mall, Burj Al Arab, Madinat Jumeirah, Marina, but the Dubai Creek still has the best flair. Regardless if at daytime or in the evening, there is always sonething to see. The loading of the Dows, a trip with the Abras from one side of the creek to the other or a steoll through the creeks, dont miss it!

Relaxation to mind and body . I recently visited dubai Creek, my god the place is like a paradise, just walk around in fresh air and no traffic hazel. It gives relaxation to mind with water in front and oxygen enriched air, lot of eateries within reasonable prices. If one wants to go into travel in water either we can catch small boats carry from Burdubai to Deiradubai in few minutes. It's close to market. Also there are small boats who take passengers in Creek waters with lovely buffet dinner, its just lovely. Please don't miss to visit dubai Creek when you're in town

Look back in time. There is new Dubai with its shiny, tall buildings and huge malls but before all that there is old Dubai which is the area around the Creek - Bur Dubai & Deira. Docked alongside the banks are wooden dhows transporting goods to/from nearby Iran. While the cargo may be modern, the means of transport is like looking back in time. Cargo is break bulk, not in shipping containers. The loading and unloading process is still done manually. They ship all kinds of goods, from food items to car tires.There are a quite a few water transport options around the Creek. The cheapest is the abra, which takes you between Bur Dubai and Deira in small, traditional wooden boats for 1 AED. There's also the water bus which does the same in a modern boat and costs 2 AED. As for sightseeing cruises, the Dubai Ferry has several route options, one of which takes you between old and new Dubai. In the Creek area near Al Ghubaiba metro/bus station there is a cluster of restaurants where you can chill out and smoke shisha while watching the world go by. Along that stretch you'll find heritage places of interest as well.
Nice vibe. A peaceful enjoyable trip down the Creek. The feeling of cool sea breeze can match no other. The view of the Dubai skyline is pretty impressive. You can see the old and the new of Dubai.

Most enjoyable on abras. Abras (water taxis) offer a great way to experience the upper part of the creek, don't miss that. The creek itself is quite large though, and not all parts worth the time to visit.
Dubai Creek. My hotel in on the Creek--I have a fabulous view of the skyline of Dubai--especially the Burj Khalifa.
Good experience. We took a dinner cuise. Food was average but beautiful sights. They also had dances in the cruise ship.nice!

Dubai Creek - Best Experience of Old Dubai. This is now a nice time of the year to visit the Creek as it is more temperate. The Dubai creek separates the Deira side of Dubai from the Bur Dubai side of the city. The Deira side houses the early areas of Dubai and the bustling traditional markets of Arabic spices and incense, dry fruits, gold, cloth and umpteen items that are traded into or through Dubai. The Bur Dubai area houses most of the Consulates and banks, apart from several trading stores and shopping and residential areas. You can take an amazingly reasonable 'Abra' ride for 1 dirham, go travel like a local There are modern boats run by the Dubai transport authority too.The Creek has a Corniche on either side where you can sit and watch the other side of Dubai, watch the boats go by, hear the water against the edges. Every evening the creek comes alive with dinner cruises on old wooden dhows ( now air conditioned for comfort) or the fancier glass enclosed cruise boats that apart from a meal on board take you up the creek and down the other way. The dinner cruise lasting for about an hour and a half to 2 hours.What with the traditional 'dhows' on the wharf on the Deira side that still ply with trading goods against the backdrop of amazing skyscrapers and watching them takes you back in time. If you go early in he day you will be amazed seeing them load the Dhows with everything you can think off including cars, some cut in half old air conditioning units, washing machines even lorries using a simple mobile crane. The Dhows depart on darkness usually for the trip to Iran. Brings it really home to you the trading in Old Dubai.
WILL VISIT. You will not miss drive passing the Dubai creek You can go there when the sun is down for a walk and take a water taxi ride and in night for a dinner cruise with a smoke.

A step back!. The creek is a separation point between the old and the new! I took a trip on the Dhow a wonderful peaceful journey through many boats plying their passengers and goods. The contrast on the banks of skyscrapers and more traditional buildings is amazing. They served food and drinks and although I did not partake everyone seemed to enjoy. A package with the hop on, hop off bus is well worth the time and money.

A must whilst in Dubai. Although much of Dubai has changed and gone high tech, the creek maintains its old charm. Well worth taking a water taxi across the creek to enjoy the views of the older Dubai.

Gentle ride from side to side. It seperates the old & modern sections of Dubai through a naturally formed creek that cuts through to form the classic Bur Deira bank and the lavish Bur Dubai bank. The mini boats that transport tourists from bank to bank are traditional wooden boats with space for approx 10 people and are driven by built in Outboard engines that are a bit noisy, but the view is quite pleasant and soothing. You will notice clean waters and beautifully hand-made dhows that differ in size and colour. One you get to the old side of Dubai, you will be greeted by a more traditional style of market that enjoys a rich variety of good from cooking spices to gold and electronics!Look out for a couple of ATM machines around the place just in case you feel the urge to spree on shopping.

Old souks, Dubai Museum and Water Taxis.... We loved wondering through the old gold souk and the spice souk, although we really didn't want to buy any of the dozens of 'copy' watches, handbags etc etc that we were offered. This maze of little streets and alleyways was quite fascinating. Then across to the Dubai side on the busy little water taxis. I thought I had misread the prices but, no, a one way trip to the other side costs the princely sum of 1 UED per person - about 25 Euro cents! Another old souk on this side and a visit to the Dubai Museum rounded our day at the Creek off! Highly recommended.

i loved the Creek area. the best part of the Creek for me is the pier on the east side of the creek,where the dhows ,traditional wooden sailing boats, are loading and unloading their goods, sight unchanged for hundreds o of year. Near by , on that side, the souks are selling their ware, from fancy gold to spices, to huge pots and pans. i never saw anything so large. there is a fantastic view of all this activity on top of the parking lot just across the street where the small abras are unloading the passengers crossing the creek. on the west side of the creek, it is more mosque, the dubai museum and tradional neighborhood. this is very far from the "Las Vegas" strip which symbolise Dubai for many people. The Creek has a soul. go there. it is great.

Origynal, specific.. The natural bay, where Dubai is initially created, and the team oldest part of the city. It is very interesting to cruise through here on old dubai boat called abra, and view the city from the water. There are several bridges across the bay, and it is good road connection so you can come here and self-directed.

Old Dubai - enjoy the history of The Creek. Whether you are on foot or taking a boat trip, this waterway is one of the most interesting places to go in Dubai. Frequented by old cargo sailing boats, abras and water taxis, this waterway is a very busy part of the Dubai culture by either day or night. You can view cargo being placed by hand on old sailing vessels as if you have travelled back in time 100 years or you can take a trip for 1 dirham on an Abra from one side of the Creek to the other. The Creek is ALIVE and will provide you with endless vistas that are changing all the time. It is such a special experience that you should not miss.There are several passenger boats that offer dinner cruises and you will see the air conditioned vessels lit up like Christmas trees sailing up and down the Creek.Don't miss this if you are in Dubai - put it on your bucket list and soak up the atmosphere.

Water blessings amidst the dessert. Dubai is a very hot place but seeing such huge area of water appeases the spirit. The entire city is full of surprises. The creek , that literally gives hope to the survival of plants and its people, gives a sharp contrast to the concrete roads and small spaces of green. Though we didn't take the boat ride, it reminded me of my youth back in the Philippines where we would take boat rides to a nearby property for a cool drink of coconut water, rummaging forests for fruits like guavas,papaya and mangoes. We went around the area scouring for souvenirs to take home and found a clean, friendly " souk" or market. There were spices, beautiful figurines ( camels in gold),glorious textiles from India, enthralling display of candies in a store ( looked like candyland to me) and preserved and vacuum sealed fresh dates (best buy ever). Too bad there was no free shuttle going back to the hotel, otherwise we could have bought more.Going back to our hotel, we found a Lebanese restaurant where we had a good lunch of grilled chicken, appetizer and a plateful of bread with dippings. Big bottle of water to finish the meal.

Old Dubai - Well worth a visit. The Dubai creek is well worth a visit for those looking some something beyond the shiny new skyscrapers and fast cars. The creek is the centre of old Dubai, it's fun to watch all the boats (they are small) being loaded with all sorts of good to be shipped to places far and wide. You can take a Dow (small taxi boat) across the creek to the old spice souk for 1 Dirham.

Pleasant walk and boat ride. We took a long stroll along the waters edge of the Dubai Creek, followed by a short boat ride using the public boats that criss cross the creek for a couple of Dhirams. Some areas are better than others and obviously it is generally very hot so be sure to wear a hat and take a bottle of water if you intend walking for any length of time. The East side of the creek does not have a lot of shops or refreshment stops and it is a fair walk from the nearest metro station. The West side has the Old Dubai Souk and more to see.
Dubai Creek. Dubai Creek is a wonderful place to walk and view the hustle and bustle of old Dubai. The old dows and a nice place to take a creek cruise.

Lovely evening walk . I had a lovely walk along the creek. Weather is pleasant in October and I discussed not sweat at all, not expected in dubai though. Beautifully lighted boats sailing around make the scene beautiful. Taking a trip with boat is recommended.
Busting port. Was interesting to see the port busy with traditional methods being used.The area is grotty which does add to the atmosphere…take a boat ride which will give you a view of the city.

Nice experience. • Bastakiya & the Souk’so If you do one you has to do the other, take the boats across they are really cool and only 1 dhs (just make sure you have exact change because you will not get any money back on a 10) o Souk = market – meaning typical annoying sales people trying to put stuff on your head or sell you fake Rolex or Louis Vuitton things. If you have the patience this is all fun and a great experience as long as you know how to say no o The gold Souk was quite drawing for my wife and has very beautiful pieces, more or less sold by the weight, they do not pay taxes here, so you will save at least 15-20% on any purchase

Morning walks & Night strolls. Take a deep breath and start jogging consume lots of fresh air and get ready for the day ahead. Missed the morning freshness don't worry wait till the night arise and take a stroll on the creek shore after dinner or take an 'Abra' ride to cross creek, still better enjoy a dinner and an Arabian night dance on a dhow ride along the length of the creek. There are various ways to enjoy the Dubai creek at any time of the day. Enjoy the past and the present Dubai by just revolving 360deg. on your axis. The Dubai Creek joins tall high-rises on one side and the vast spreads of sand and old Dubai on the other. A visit to Dubai is incomplete without visiting and spending some time at the Dubai Creek.

Fascinating Look at the City. Great views of some the extravagant architecture as well as some of the watercraft plying the creek...abras, both motorized and rowed, restaurant/dinner cruise boats and freighter dhows. I wish I'd taken advantage of the opportunity to rent a motorized abra for a costomized tour of the creek.
Water taxi . Took a boat trip around the creek after the big bus tour it's amazing to see the other side of Dubai this whole area is amazing

old dubai. Dubai Creek is a great place to gain an insight into old Dubai with its colourful wooden boats, old buildings and souks. A trip on an abra is a must. They are a fun way to cross the water. Just step onto one and when they are full they will set off to the other side. 1AED for the trip - what a bargain! And you get some stunning views.

A place to cool off. A trip on Dubai Creek provides a welcome breeze from the oppressive heat. You will also get to see old Dubai and the bustling trade which goes on down by the riverside. The water taxi's called Abras cost just 1 Dirham, you pay once you are on the boat. It takes just over 5 minutes to cross the creek, from Al Sabkha station on the Deira side, to Bur Dubai station on the west side of the river. Here you can explore the old town and Dubai Museum. In the evening you can book a meal on some larger Dhows which have been converted into restaurants. There are a couple of skyscrapers overlooking the lower end of the creek. Built in the 1990's you have the Twin Rolex Towers and the curved golden façade of the National Bank of Dubai.
Definitely worth a visit. Would visit this area, great setting, both crossing points of the creek of interest within Old Dubai. Also definitely use an Abra, only 1 Dhms each to cross.

Better Part of Dubai. This is the better part of Dubai in my opinion. The newer sections and hotels tend to be over the top with new building trying to outdo each for no purpose other than that. Old Dubai is still relatively high end but it's less pretentious. Come in the evening for some shopping, a restaurant and or boat ride.

Step into Old Dubai. Don't miss out on the Dubai Creek on your visit to Dubai. You can only spend so much time in a mall! Lots of things to see and places to eat along the creek. You can visit Heritage Village or the visit Sheikh Saeed's home and see pictures of old Dubai. Very interesting to see what old Dubai looked like and compare it to the development today.

Great Fun. I am not a shopper and being dragged around Dubai's malls by my wife could drive me to consider a trial separation. However, an evening negotiating (I use the word wisely) the souks of Old Dubai and making the most of the ridiculously cheap boat services is a must-do for anyone. The Creek separates two market areas, one largely for textiles, and the other side for spices and gold (well, all sorts of jewellery actually). My wife found a textile 'shop' with a fabric and design she loved, and we were whisked by foot through a mind-boggling combination of side streets and alleyways to a tailor, who promptly measured her up and had the entire creation ready for collection the following morning. All in, £38 for a tailor-made outfit. When walking around the markets, however, it's best not to be the timid type, as the constant banter from the hawkers could be a little intimidating to some. Also, over the course of our evening there, I deduced that everything, but everything, can be bartered down by at least 50%, despite the sellers' howls of protest. Good entertainment. Whilst there, the boats are a must. For 50 AED (about £9.50) we got ourselves a Creek 'cruise' all to ourselves for 45 minutes which was wonderful. We went at sunset which was stunning. Another day we invested 1 AED each in the 10 minute trip across the Creek from Textile Souk side to Spice Souk side. Brilliant fun to soak up some real middle eastern atmosphere with largely locals. The whole 'shopping' experience was so much better than being dragged from one Mall boutique to another.

The Old Dubai. This is one of my favourite places to visit because this is where it all started only 45 years ago. A lot has changed since then!Here you can see original buildings and open markets selling clothes etc and souverniers.The transport across the creek is the old Abbra boats. They are still only one dhiram to cross and an experience in itself. This are also has the largest Gold Souk in the world. Rows of shop windows full of gold jewellry, a must to see!Also the Museum which is very interesting showing how Dubai used to be.
Feel like refreshing even in the rush hours. Spent good time having relaxed mind and nothing to worry.had a good ride in RTA tour too in very low cost from and to banyan square and maternal.

Great Night at the Creek View Restaurant. If you are in Dubai you must take your dinner at the Creek View Restaurant. The choices on the menu is long and if something is not there you can have made to order speciality. If you like Lebenese, Indian or American dishs the chef will make you very happy. If your looking for a very cosy international location for couples and families this is the Restaurant for you. Oh the price of dining is very reasonable. Great for watching football or smoking shesha.

Up The Creek Without a Paddle. There are a few different theories as to how Dubai was named. One theory is that the word Dubai is a combination of the Farsi words for two and brothers, the latter referring to Deira and Bur Dubai.Others believe that 'Dubai' was so named by people who considered its souq a smaller version of a thriving market named 'Daba'.Either way, if you are travelling to Dubai for its culture and outstanding architecture, make sure you don't get so wrapped up in the glitz and glamour of this amazing city that you forget to take in the experience of the Creek.You will be sampling the heart of Old Dubai and seeing the hustle and bustle as commuters rally from one side of the creek to the other. The Roads & Transport Authority (RTA) offers many marine transport means for public transport users such as Water Bus, Water Taxi, Ferry but for the ultimate experience for just 1 Dirham each way, take a trip on what is considered the oldest means of transportation in the United Arab Emirates, the Abra.We are blessed with family visitors once every year and this is always on top of their to do list. So many tourists experience so many great things in Dubai but seldom get to experience the simple but fascinating way of life. You really get a sense of tradition especially when you take a stroll through Meena Bazaar: Also known by its former name "Cosmos Lane", this shopping area is known for its textile shops, tailors and Asian (specifically Indian) clothing stores.It is located along 50B Street (near Dubai Museum) in Bur Dubai.A fun and exhilarating part of Dubai that despite being old, is unspoiled.

Soul of dubai heartbeat of dubai.. If you are in dubai you must go across the creek in the Abra an ancient boat which takes you from one point to another. Special visit to spice market and gold souk. You can go for aDhow cruise and see the old dubai by night and have a lovely dinner and some antic show on cruise. Beautiful and memorable evening spent at dubai creek.

Different feel.... Very nice area with different feel to it. Not so commercial as the rest of Dubai. Calm and peacful area with the locals and local transportation, small boats that are also very cheap to travel with. Definately wirth seeing. In the evening you can enjoy nice dinner with local food and music. The boat sails through creek onto persian gulf.

Sense of the Old World. A must go when you visit Dubai. Have a walk around the Mosque, the Palace, Local shops and Dubai Museum. Visit the Silk market! Then take a short boat trip across the Creek to the Spice market, take a trip back in time and go and see the Gold Suk.

A different Prospective. We took the hour long tour on the traditional boats that ply the Creek. It cost 120dirham for 4 people which was great value being able to soak up the views from a different prospective. Though limited in English conversation we were given a limited commentary on the landmarks and buildings that we past.

Great experience!. I took an hour long tour on the traditional boats for 120 Durham well worth it after a long walk in souk eldahab the gold market great way to cool down on the water relax and soak up the city views!

Lovely views from the water. We took several water taxi's across the creek. Everyone jumped on, paid 1D and off we went. Ride was smooth with some lovely views. Short trip to the other side and no sooner had the boat pulled up, people were jumping off! Very quick and frequent water taxis. We took a longer boat cruise down the creek. We were given a commentary of the landmarks and the views again, were excellent. Food was severed on the boat if you liked and it was lovely to view another part of Dubai from the water.
Nice place to visit and enjoy. nice place with cruz facility. boat ride is enjoyable.......................................................................

Dhow cruise Dubai. I have visited dubai on last month and had an experience in Dhow cruise trip.i have really enjoyed dhow crusie with my friends, they are working in emirates. What an adventure is this, unforgettable moments we had tradition food cuisines dinner. we are 5 members paid less amount of money only, because my friend buy discount voucher from kobonaty.com coupon site.I dont know that dhow cruise offer is still live..

Amazing place . This place is really awesome for those who loves shopping,coffee,sight seeing..It's an amazing place with boat rides which takes you from one end of the city to another...you can also book your tickets on water bus and enjoy your ride

Boat ride was great. When we arrived at the creek we were offered a tour in a private boat for 120 dirams however I already knew it only costs 1 diram to cross the creek over to Deira if you share a boat - was good fun.

Dubai Creek, Some Part Natural Some Part Artificial - A Must Visit Dubai Tourist Attraction. Most major cities in the world have bodies of water as one of their highlight attractions not counting Venice which renowned for its canals. Some became focal points the cities. Some of these cities I already visited. London has the River Thames. New York has the Hudson River. Singapore has the Singapore River. Paris has the Seine. Chicago has the Lake Michigan. Cairo has the Nile River. São Paolo has the Pinheiros River. Shanghai has the Huangpu River.For Emirate and City of Dubai, it is Dubai Creek which divides the commercial districts of Deira and historical district of Bur Dubai where the defendants of some of the current ruler of the United Arab Emirates settled and established the country. It is a must thing to do while in that Arabic state.As we toured this marvelous waterway, I learned from my tourist guide that some parts of the Dubai Creek are natural from its inlet at the Deira Corniche where it sources its saltwater from the Persian Gulf while some part are artificial or man-made for further development of the area. The unnatural parts of the creek was a part of the Sheikhs's grandiose plans for Dubai like the Burj Al Arab, Palm Islands and others. Dubai Creek is an attraction by itself but it is also the location of some of Dubai's attractions that our group visited like the Ras Al Khor Wildlife Sanctuary, the Al Bastakiya historic area, the Sheikh Saeed Al Maktoum House and many skyscrapers from the beginning of Dubai's economic miracle. Our tour guide also told us that before the construction of the Dubai Metro and before automobiles and the bridges that connects the banks, abras were the only way to cross the Dubai Creek. Abras are a traditional Arabic boat made of wood. I said to him that it is similar to the Chinese Junks that used to be the only way to cross Victoria Harbour. The tour was capped with a Dhow Cruise. Dhows are sail boat style watercrafts. We saw some of the attractions we visited during our bus and foot tour.What a way to experience Arabic culture.
DUBAI DHOW CRUISE. Went on a Dhow Dinner Cruise. People of different Nationality were present & it was truly a multi cultural experience. Food was very good.Dubai creek connects Deira to Burj Dubai

Where was everyone?. I visited the Creek during the day with a friend, and nobody was there! We got on a small boat, and had a 30min boat trip, of the length of the creek (we paid 30AED each)- it was extremely relaxing and the views were beautiful. We asked to be taken to the busier side of the creek- but there was nothing much going on there either. We visited a mall, which was near enough empty, and sold mostly fur coats. In the end we just hopped into a tax and left.If it wasn't for the lovely boat trip, it would have been a complete waste of time.
Very good experience. Great experience, the trip was great and the food exceptionally good for a river boat trip. Well worth the money and timeq

Great night at the creek. I went on a dhow dinner cruise with my wife. There were many other people and it was a truly multi-cultural experience. The food was excellent and we were entertained by a magician and a dancer.

Love the hustle, bustle and ambience!. I just love the Dubai Creek area. The abras crossing the Creek add so much character and charm to the area. Wandering through the souks and seeing the spices, gold, material, electronics and household goods for sale, just oozes with local culture. It was fun bartering for goods, but at the end of the day I feel if it is worth it to me then it it worth buying at whatever price. These traders have to make a living! Young men wander around selling bottled water and soft drinks from trays was most welcome when the weather was warm, sticky and humid. I think my favourite souk was the spice souk, I recommend the chocolate stones!

Dhow ride and gold market area. First we walked through the Bur Dubai area and lot of shops with textiles, wood carving items and perfumes.. We visited Hindu temple nearby and then went on to boat cruise. It is AED 1 per head and it is a joy ride for kids. Beautiful dubai skyline can be watched while reaching other end. Gold market is nearby and once you are there, it is gold, gold and more gold.... Enjoyed over all trip.

loved the creek. we a family of 2 adults and 2kids visited Dubai for 10 days, of which we visited the creek area many times.  first time -we first took a taxi to the Dubai Museum . After the museum visit we walked to the creek. It takes about 5-10 mins.There is a abra station. Here one can find Indian restaurants like saravana bhavan. You can shop for dry fruits here. one can find these shops on the road before you reach the creek. Since it was very hot (SEP end) we decided to rest till it was evening. There are benches provided along the creek where one can rest, provided you find a place where there is shade. One can book an Abra for 1 hour for 120 AED to go around the creek. We hired an abra around 5.30 in the evening. These abra's can be hired from any of the other stations also, say from the gold souk side also. we later bought a lot of dry fruits.second time- took an abra to gold souk just 1 AED per person from bur dubai side , visited the gold souk. came back to the Bur Dubai side and then visited the Shiekh Saeed house where one can see the history of Dubai.The transformation of Dubai. you can walk along the creek to reach here. If you are interested in history you can surely visit. Next to the shiekh saeed house is the Heritage and diving village. If one is interested in history this heritage tour along the creek is worth the visit.
Abra and a lot of gold.. If you tired from sophisticated metro trains, luxury cars and skyscrapers around you, visit this place and feel authentic emirates.

Ghow ride to Bur Dubai area. Our group took this Dhow ride on the Dubai Creek to reach the Bur Dubai area. The ride was ok and nothing special. Open boat with a roof and only cost 1 AED Dirham or about 25 US cents. Cheap. From Bur Dubai docking we proceeded to the Dubai museum.

Dubai creek area. Took a taxi to the textile souk, it was not worth the effort. The textiles basically consisted of more scarves and pashminas, plus the obligatory genuine fake watches. We were pretty hassled by the storekeepers who stood in front of us to block our progress and tried to drape scarves around our neck.After this we decided not to cross the creek, took a photo and went back to our hotel.
Boat trip incuding bufe dinner with wine and beer. Fantastisk boat trip With the largest wooden "bufe" ship in the world (3 decks)The Food, service and Entertainment were fantastic.

Take a traditional Abra across the creek.. It only cost you 1 dirham to bring you across the creek to the old souk and another 1 dirham to bring you back. The ride takes about 10-15 mins or so but it is more than enough for you to take in the view from the Abra and experience a traditional boat ride that is still very much alive in Dubai. The old souk, personally I feel that there's nothing for me to shout about although I must qualify I did not explore further other than the immediate vicinity. The boat station is near to the metro station Baniyas square.

The heart of Dubai. It's well worth doing a 1 dirham trip across the creek in an Abra ... it feels like the real Dubai! Very busy place with more soul than downtown Dubai. Lovely to have a meal at the side of the creek and watch all the boats go by and then explore the Bur Dubai souq would had a great atmosphere.

Great experience. If you get the chance I can highly recommend a trip to Dubai. It is a wonderful experience,. It is pretty unique with a blend of ultra modern buildings and high class facilities blended in with it's marvellous historic culture .
