A trip on Dubai creek is lovely and the spice and gold souks are well worth visiting - such an eclectic mix! You probably only need 4 nights there to experience this but if you are a true beach lover then go for a week on Jumeira Beach or Palm Island if you can!

History. The creek is amazing. It's busy very busy. It's a working transpirtation route and not just a tourist trap. Yeah there is plenty of look a looky men trying to sell you things but it's great. Look out for the big wooden boats transpiration good to Africa and Asia. I seen the fridge freezers and TVs stacked up waiting to be loaded up. I remember thinking this would not happen in glasgow they would have been gone in 20 minutes. This would take about 1-2hr to visit. You really need to visit hear

Take the boat from the Marina..... About an hour and a half up the coast, best way to see the area in a leisurely fashion. Less than a tenner! Wander round the south side, have lunch in the little Lebanese on stilts (cheap as chips, but very good food every time), take the abra across to the north side, safety not a consideration, engine fumes a disaster so sit at the front, wander round the Spice and Gold souks, then get the metro back.

Amazing views of original Dubai. Go there at night when the weather cools off. The reflection of the city lights on the creek surface is amazing. And if Abras are working (little ferries), take one to the other side and back. It cheap and you can see a lot. Great place.

Old Town is The Best. As others have stated, take a boat across the creek to cool off. It's inexpensive, fun and so refreshing!I think one of the best kept secrets is this one the best places in the world to buy fabric. At the Meena Bazaar there are several shops where you can find anything you are looking for with helpful knowledgable staff.

perfect way to see the two diverse sides of this city. The Dubai creek splits the city - is some 16km from sea to source [accroding to our guide] and is as spectacular as the Bosphorus in Istanbul....The locals use the small flat bottomed boats called Abra's to take them from one side of the creek to the other....The infamous Gold and Spice souks are on the side of the creek making them easily accessible....the traders in the gold souks especially can be "in your face" just as their fellow traders in the Grand Bazaar in Istabul can be...but a polite "no thank you" will suffice....Manners and politeness are in abundance in Dubai....

Arab Dhow on the Dubai Creek. There is a number of operators of the Arab Dhows on the Dubai Creek. We our tour booked via Big Bus Tours. It was very pleasant experience from the Creek's water on the Arab Dhow.

Just Book one of the Taxi Boats, its a great way to spend an hour. So there we were, in august, a family without the " mad dogs" but being english , out in the mid day sun... getting on for 50C look for a place to cool down, No chance...off we went " up the creek and what a great trip it was, shade from the boat was Ok. plenty of water and a chance to get a small glimpse of " old dubai " with a " driver that tried very hard to explain it to us ....

A little more of the Old Dubai. I took a train to Al Ghubaib and then walked to the Old Souq. Did not have a good impression at the Old Souq as the merchants were trying too hard to get visitors to buy things... and it just didn't feel so good for a lone female traveller. On the other hand, I liked taking the water taxi across the river. For only 1 AED, I experienced a little bit of venice in Dubai. The views are of skyscrapers and old buildings but it was nice anyway. The Gold Souq was however a little bit of disappointment for me once again.Maybe its because its too hot so I couldn't properly enjoy myself.

Average Waterfront. Walked from Heritage Village down to the Fort which took around an hour in the heat. Its a pleasant walk with lots of boats and activity on the creek but nothing that really stood out. Yes its a good way to spend an hour but as harbours go there are more interesting places in the world

Dubai creekside exploration. Thisis real, working, no-frills Dubai. Anyone coming to Dubai can enjoy a walk along the creek, and enjoy one ofthe older parts of the city. At one end, is the Shindagha heritage village, with its little museums of life in Dubai prior to oil and pizzazz! s you walk along, further, one can visit one of the older souks, selling spices and minerals , such as frankincense. If you get tired, oone or two cafes ar open, where you can sit and enjoy the water, the work around you and the abras going from one side of the creek to the other. Enjoy a lovly international buffet at the Apple Restaurantin twin Towers, then take an abra back across to the Al Ghubaiba side. Walk back along here, and visit the other touristy souk, where you will be pestred into looking and buying souvenirs. Haggling is essential, ad do not be affraid to walk away. As you walk further along towards Al Fahidi, take a walk through the Hindu are, with its tiny, narrow pathway.I live here and I love doing this on a regular basis.The museums will charge perhaps 3dhs for a visit, and a trip across the creek in an abra is 1dh. Try to carry small change with you.

Great views of old Dubai. Take the water taxi across the creek (river for us westerners) and get a great view at all the boats that come in from the Gulf to sell supplies in the area. Great views of area buildings.

Great fusion. It's pretty much the only place that I felt that I saw the fusion of the new and the old.
Old city where you can see the skyscrapers just next you is quite a view.
You can take the ferry for nothing, which is also a fun thing to do.
Loved it!

Old and new. The watery vein that runs through the city, this body of water cradles the stories of yore as well as the rush of modern life. From old markets of spices and wares, humble houses and enchanting streets to the view from well lit promenades of modern ferries and yachts, this creek side is a must visit on a trip to Dubai. It shows how the city evolved over time almost like a storyteller.I would highly recommend exploring different ways of seeing life around here: a leisurely stroll through the markets on the other side, a Dhow (boat) ride with the locals, a sip or hukkah at a cafe overlooking the waters, a spot with milling tourists on the modern side. Do it all and you'll experience some of the magic of this creek!

Beautiful grass, also good for families. This park is very clean, well kept and has a lot of playgrounds for kids. Large grass areas where you can lay down under the trees in the shade, or you can 'cool your feet off' on the narrow beaches at the creek (no swimming allowed). Beautiful, peaceful creek promenade with views on the bridges and the yacht club. A relaxing, green place as a variety you might long for after all the rushing crowds, many cars and the high skyscrapers of Dubai.
Very Cheap. Its really cheap to go on one of the boats. 2AED to go to the other side. Im just a little creeped out by the water because I dont know what lies beneath it.

Great. Its impressive what we can build, a complete artificial lake were you can almost imagine a tropical gondola in veneza. Enjoyed very much, the downside was being in other hotel. Next time will stay on the spot.

Nice place for a walk n the winters f Dxb. As the summer is still prevalent here today was not the ideal day for a walk by the creek. Floating resturants/ boats are a tad exp but for a first time visitor I would say go for it. Heritage Village on the other side of the creek has good sheesha and arabic food. DEF a must try from the months between nov n march. ENJOY Dubai.

Creek View. Very beautiful view, man made creek we can see small boats both Manuel & motor going ng up and down. Yachts and house boats parked along side which provide dinner buffets and other entertainments.

Creek park & abra ride. experiencing dubai is incomplete unless you have spend some serene time on the creek. the best view of the creek is from the cable car in the creek park and for first hand experience better go towards the bur dubai side and take the abra ride ( small wooden boats) and crossed the creek from the old to the new. sure to be mesmerized by the dhows and the architecture on both sides of the creek.Must do when in dubai

Boat trips not that great. Took a Dhow cruise after all the rave reviews, but it wasn't great. They don't actually go into the creek, food is very average, entertainment is amateur cabaret at best and at night you can't see much. The boats move very very slowly so don't expect an extensive tour. It wasn't expensive though so...

the old and the new- an experience. The Dubai creek separates the Deira side of Dubai from the Bur Dubai side of the city. The Deira side houses the early areas of Dubai and the bustling traditional markets of Arabic spices and incense, dry fruits, cloth and umpteen items that are traded into or through Dubai. The Bur Dubai area houses most of the Consulates and banks, apart from several trading stores and shopping and residential areas. Crossing the creek is by road or the metro ( green line) or the choice of an amazingly reasonable 'abra' ride, There are modern boats run by the transport authority too. The creek has a corniche on either side where you can sit and watch the other side of Dubai, watch the boats go by, hear the water against the edges or simply take in a sunrise or sunset. Its a place to walk, jog or simply unwind. Every evening the creek comes alive with dinner cruises on old wooden dhows ( now airconditioned for comfort) or the more swanky new glass enclosed cruise boats that apart from a meal on board take you up the creek and down the other way. The dinner cruise lasting for about an hour and a half to 2 hours.All in all, the creek is a must see area to take in Dubai and its amazing change into a modern world class city. What with the traditional 'dhows' on the wharf on the Deira side that still ply with trading goods against the backdrop of amazing skyscrapers and watching them takes you back in time....such is the magic of Dubai creek and what it offers.

interesting and inexpensive trip. Worth the effort . Visit the Gold and Spice Souks on one side of the Creek, then get the foot ferry (about 50pence) to the other side and see the Cloth Souk. The ferries are "step on/step off", and great fun.
Quite a few nice cafes by the Creek for refreshments (non alcoholic)
Abra on Dubai Creek. At 1 Dirham to cross the creek it's about the cheapest authentic Dubai experience you can have. Best done during winter though.

Small private taxi boat. We decided against the more touristy dhow boat cruise and opted for just the local taxi boat down the creek! It was relaxing and enjoyable, 120 dirham between 5 so easily a bargain!

the most authentic part of Dubai. I love this area of Dubai. It's not particularly pretty, or clean, and there's not necessarily specific 'attractions' to visit, but it's got a real sense of itself, as if it hasn't changed terribly much in the past few hundred years, except that the dhows and abras ploughing the creek now have electric motors, and the souks have souvenir shops in them. This was, and in some ways still is, the heart of Dubai, and the reason for the original settlement. It's still a bustling cargo hub, with all manner of mysterious goods being loaded and unloaded all day and all night. The souks carry on their traditional business hours (meaning all the good places close around 2:30), and the traditional haggling over a cup of tea or Arabic coffee for your purchase will take you back in time. spices, material, clothes, tobacco and gold are the primary commodities, but even just wandering up and down the narrow souks, savouring the smells and the sounds and the bustle is a fantastic transaction in itself.across the creek from the gold souk is the dubai museum, really worth visiting, and you can also walk through the old town and visit galleries and cafes which have taken up habitation in the old dwellings.recommend to go in the cooler months from September to May, but whatever time of the year, definitely worth a half a day tour, or a full day tour if you're going to take in the museum as well.

See Dubai from the water. Spend a few hours drafting down the creek seeing old Dubai to one side and new Dubia to the over, a totally enjoyable experience. Water taxis are cheap but treat yourself to a tourist boat, well worth the dining experience and a cheap night out. Wine is very cheap on these boats so a very romantic night can be had. Excellent phot opportunities.

A nice experience especially watching the sunset. A nice experience . We arrived late afternoon when the heat started subsiding. We took an old boat (dhow) for an hour long trip up and down the creek. Cost 60 Dirhams for half hour or 120 for an hours trip. Really nice old traditional fishing and trading boats were docked on the edges. The sunset scene over the creek was awesome. After night falls the large touristic floating restaurants colorfully lite are amazing to watch with their colored lights reflecting on the water. The old souq ( bazaar) is just on the opposite side of the docks. You can stop there for cheap souvenirs and spice shopping and many other things. Very interesting place.

20p well spent! ( The best 20p. boat ride ever!). An amazing trip which has everything; history, culture, excitement and the thrill joining the local people cross the Creek! From Bur Dubai to Deira; see the sights and weave across the Creek as Abra and Dhow wend their way across,and up and down . See the cargo waiting along the Creek-side to be taken world-wide on the Ocean going Dhow. Join the locals lining up at the Abra Station and embark on the journey of discovery across the Creek. Disembark on Deira side and explore the Spice Souk and Gold Souk....amazing!
Tradition and Originality. When you live or stay in the modern Dubai, you should visit this place to feel and see physically the historical transformation and development of the city.

Neat part of Dubai. The Old Souk is located near the Creek and is easy to access from the tour buses or the water taxi's. There are a range of vendors trying to sell all sorts of stuff and the range of textiles is incredible. Expect the street hawkers trying to sell you all sorts of stuff that you do not need, but they are all part of the atmosphere. The range of products in the shops is amazing, so if you have time its well worth experiencing this old part of town.

Authentic way to travel. Captivating views over the creek. It's a must to catch a small ferry boat over to the souks but be prepared to jump on board. Barter for materials or diamonds in the souks. Prices are at least 75% lower than in the UK! Don't forget to visit the old town which is less touristy. Extreme heat beware to go in the morning and carry lots of water. Mystic calls to prayer from the mosques which you can appreciate no matter what your religion.

Annoying they follow you to sell there stuff. Annoying how the trolley pusher follow you while you shop at fruit and vegetable market .They continuously talk to you . They follow you and the same person will ask ask ask ask ask ask ask ask ask ask you again and again if they can carry your stuff it horrendous horrible and an aggressive placeDon't go alone ! They are staring, following ,and asking you over and over again .

Taste of a more traditional Dubai. I really enjoyed visiting the Creek, and pretty easy to get to via metro!Only costs 1AED (16p) to get to the other side of the river to visit more of the souks!It's a very touristic area and as you can imagine there are just as much, if not more international goods being sold, but still nice to explore, particularly the architecture and views along the creek.I also visited the typical 'in-house' shops with many designer lookalikes - although I did not purchase anything - if interested keep an eye out!
Enjoy an Abra Ride. As part of our half-day tour of Dubai, we rode a private abra along the creek. Refreshing to say the least. Recommend!

Fake, Fake, Fake.... Dubai is just Fake but nice Fake ;)Creek is just the place where you are tempted by Fake production from China (LVMH, CD, Jacobs, ...) at every corner, every boutique.Most are even hidden and you must fellow sales people in (fake) apartments discovering large apartment full of copies...I just cannot buy fake so lose of time.Creek is nothing but it except if you decide to take a boat but 0 interest...

Free Sauna on Creek Cruise. Booked a dinner cruise for two families last week to 'chill' out on the creek with Al Faris Cruises. One family from London who wanted to thaw in Dubai and the other residents wanting to cool on the creek in peak summer. The Cruise started on time, the food was good and the Tanora dancer who entertained during the fag end of the trip was admirable. Especially since he had to brave severe congestion on the small boat. What killed the trip was the extreme heat - the boat did not have proper air conditioning and both decks were boiling. Our suggestions that it was uncomfortably warm fell on deaf years as the staff refused to accept it was warm. However you could see restless passengers changing seats and ready to jump into the balmy creek. What should have been a pleasant trip turned to be an exhausting one. A free sauna one could call it if you are prone to look at a glass as half full.PS Avoid seats near the buffet table as the food warmers add to the discomfort.

A taste of Old Dubai with new Dubai service.. We got the morning train down to Dubai creek and then walked along the river to find a water taxi. The trip along the river was fascinating and our guide was friendly and informative. He was good enough to discuss how to get to the souk and where to find restaurants for lunch. I think that this service is really under sold both as an attraction but also for the information and help you get from the taxi drivers. To miss out on this is to miss out on the history and charm of Dubai.
Interesting to see the 'old town'.. Well worth a visit around the gold and spice selling areas, then you can take an hour water taxi ride for £20.

This is Dubai. It is a pity that most tourists miss this area. By far, this is Dubai. If you visit the UAE and you want to feel the middle east, you must visit the Creek, take an Abra and visit the souks.

It may not be for everyone. The cruise is good, especially at night, but the food and the atmosphere may not be what everyone expects. The spinning dancer was the best part of the cruise. Otherwise seeing the architecture and the areas that you may not otherwise get to see are interesting but I could see how some may not enjoy this.

Loved it.. really enjoyed the creek area.Walked down from hotel on the first day then Saw all from the tour bus. Amazingly busy. Loved the guys carrying freezers on their backs. On another day walked down & took water taxi across to spice souk. Very rustic, get on sit down ,once full off you went. Very meagre amount to pay for crossing.Good easy way to get across creek . Thoroughly enjoyed the trip there & back.

Sensational at night…. Dubai Creek one of the very impressive place at night especially when you have Dhow Cruise sailing and the buildings edging are lite with colorful lights.
Evenings are very pleasant to walking alongside. During DSF the fireworks adds to the glow.
It’s a lovely place.
Must take boat trip!!!. Dubai Creek is so different from new and modern Dubai. Must go there to experience somethyng different and see old culture. For some it was creepy, but nice experiance.
Good to take a boat trip. There are is plenty to do in this are of dubai from restuarants to a boat trip. You will see all the old arab dhow's loading ready to sail to india and the gulf states.

Nice place to visit. The Creek is a really nice place to visit in Dubai. I have been on a dinner dhow cruise and really enjoyed it. There is a Dubai Creek Park, and the entrance fee is 5AEDs whoever wants to come in, but it was empty park when I was there since it was really hot. A lot of nice places and restaurants around. Camel ride, horse carriage and a lot of fun for children is available at the place.
nice walk. love walking along here just watching the Dows come and go it can be bustling here at times bust a super walk and exciting to see how it all works
Worth a visit. Dubai Creek isn't on the main tourist attraction list for Dubai but it's worth a visit. Also catch an Abra whilst you're there.

A step back into history. Trading by sea has been a part of Dubai's history for hundreds of years and the dhows that continue to ply the waters of the Arabian Sea and Indian Ocean still load and unload cargo at the dhow wharfage. Just wandering along this waterfront is fascinating with cargo piled into the wharf with no obvious security - it wouldn't last long in many other parts of the world. Spend some time absorbing the sights and smells of an historic trade.

The real Dubai. Have stayed at the Sheraton hotel on the creek with its easy access to the boats that don't cost much to go from one end to the other of the creek. Stopping at the souks and plenty of other sights while on the boat. There's a air conditioned boat as well which cost a tiny bit more, both well worth travelling on.

A Lovely Boat Ride. we chose to be simple in our approach and opted for a hired boat ride along the creek... in the evening it looks splendid. Light and shadow along the banks of the creek.. all building glistening in its lighting... the dinner cruises getting ready... lit up to color the water through its reflection... the cool breeze keeping you nice and comfortable... you can hire a normal ferry boat to your self for around 120 DHMs. the rates keep changing but they are properly published by the government on the ferry. so go ahead and enjoy... its much better to ride this boat as it gives u a calm and lovely view of the city. the dinner cruise are nice but it takes away the attraction as it is too loud for my liking...

Intersting chaos. We did Dubai creek as part of a city tour and found it fascinating with the wild ride across the creek in the Abras, old wooden tubs with a makeshift roof and then the old souks markets

Standing on my patio, watching the Abras go by........... Getting a hotel facing the Creek was the best thing we did. Our view included the skyline with the Burj Khalifa and the other architectural beauties that Dubai is famous for. The abras are open, sturdy basic wooden water transports with benches and a roof, and barely cost anything to cruise you across. Take an abra to the gold souk, browse around at the dazzlingly showy gold shops, the spice market is nearby too. Pick up chewy camel milk candy, and some spices like zattar and sumak. At night the abras are lit up and float by romantically, like a verse from an arabic poem.

Not so popular but a real local thing. I would advise anyone that wants to have a real flavour of the old Dubai to go to the creek. Just the walk along it in the south side and then crossing it with an Abra, or why not, hiring one for 1 hour (is not expensive). This is where Dubai started and the abra to cross the creek is the oldest mean of transport in the city. Even today is still very used by the people that live in the neighbourhood. I'd suggest this and if you happen to do it before lunch, then finish it up with some food in the Karachi Darbar close to the last abra stop. Great indian food.
Worth seeing!. Dubai creek is wonderful! Our hotel was right on the creek, and the abra rides and souks are right there! A must see!

The true heart of dubai. Forget what the government would have you believe. Dubai creek is the TRUE "downtown".This is where everything that you know today as Dubai all started. This is where the inspiration to try and build a "Singapore of the Middle East" came from. Where Dubai grew into the metropolis that it is, yet they did so bereft of oil. All they had was trade and a mirage. Dubai creek is literally the heart of it all and the closest that anywhere in Dubai comes to having a soul. The sterile glass and concrete does not reign here and you can still cross th creek from either side on the traditional abra boats. The authorities are trying to qualify it as a UNESCO world heritage site. I have my doubts but stranger things have happened.The pirates the smugglers, the wreckers with their false lights: As far as I'm concerned they're all still here. The lights have simply gotten brighter.

A relaxing Creek ride. We took the cheapest boat ride in history down the creek and it was amazing!!! We only did a half hour trip and our guide was lovely. The view of old and new dubai was great and it gave us a few ideas of where to visit next. Would recommend this to anyone!

Night-time river cruise. The evening of our arrival in Dubai, I booked a river cruise and dinner on a dhow. Thank goodness it was air conditioned, it was still around 38 degrees at 9 o'clock at night and very high humidity. Meal was very good with lots of variety and the atmosphere was good. The service was also good. The evening cruise took about 3 hours, and the lights of Dubai reflecting off the water was magical. At one point we ventured to the upper deck but the heat drove us back into the comfort of the cabin.Next day we did a city tour that included a trip across the creek on the smaller abra, what the locals use as a water taxi.
A glimpse of 'old dubai'. A worthwhile trip down the creek seeing the past and present together and what plans they have for its future!!

Take an abra across the Creek. For just AED1 p/person you can cross the Creek on one of Dubai's very local, authentic water taxi's (also known as an "abra"). You just hop on and pay the captain :) The journey takes approximately 7 minutes to reach the other side and is such a treat to commute with the locals, as well as have views from the water. It was a definite highlight for us and would recommend it to anyone. Don't forget your camera!On both sides of the Creek there are several Souqs to be discovered too, including the Spice and Gold Souqs so don't forget your cash

must see Dubai. this visit is a must whilst in Dubai take the Abra across the creek to the see and smell all the Spices on sale they will let you try before you buy stall holder very friendly and informative is a great experience. Walk up the road to see all the gold on offer. You cab also reach the creek now via the Metro green line we would advise buying a gold ticket as the first compartment is reserved for gold ticket holders and you can nearly always find a seat it is a little more expensive but with tickets being cheap anyway is in not a lot more,

busy stretch of water. Dubai creek was a nice transport mode. The tours on the creek were also quite enchanting with the cruises having typical arabic food and arabic entertainment. We were there during the DSF and hence there was a lot of additional cultural activity in that area with a mix of cultures across the world and much of Africa.
Boat Cruise. Boat Cruise by Night. Looking at the skyline while cruising was breath taking. The boat had some Arabian dancers and lots to eat and drink. Very nerve easing I must say.

An excellent evening outing. The Dubai creek is a great place for an evening walk. The water is prestine blue and the skyline is beautiful. It is recomended to take this walk from October to January when the weather is pleasent.

Cheap and Cheerful!. What a great way to see the old parts of Dubai! A cheap method of travel and can take you to the old souks which were great to have a look around. The Abra can take you for as long and as far as you like so worth a visit!

The Old Centre Of Dubai. It's always worth having a walk a long the Creek. It's always interesting to see the Dhows full of things being exported from or brought into Dubai. The Spice Souk - which is close to the Creek - is much the same as I remembered it from when I lived in Dubai 30 years ago. It's very atmospheric. There are some interesting alleys/shops behind the Spice Souk which eventually lead to the Gold Souk. There are some shopkeepers who will hassle you but you can easily ignore them. If you do go into their shops your starting point for bartering is 20% of what they start at.

Dubai creek. This is the old Dubai, all the shows going about their business laden with goods destined for more exotic shores. All the merchandise from batteries to refrigerators packed up on the quayside, all safe, as no-one would dare steal anything. This is a place of times gone by. The creek isn't far from the souks, where the smiling people wait for you to knock their prices down, and the gold and jewellery is so beautiful. I really enjoyed my stay out there and will definitely go again soon.

i Would do it again n again. shewww what an experience! u sit on the abra and get across, as it cuts across, i look out at the different architectural designs and people from countries speaking different languages, some off to work, some are tourists, just drinking in all of this beauty just like me, Love u Dubai!!

Great way to see Dubai from another angle!. We went on a beautiful floating dinner cruise on the Dubai Creek. It was a great way to see Dubai from another angle. By the way, the food was great, service and staff impeccable and one of best dinner cruises we have been on.
cruising boat. We enjoyed the ride on the old boats, a private boat for 15usd , took us around boat sides very relaxing and the it does give you a chance to take pictures of the city.

Don't miss going here. A very pleasant place to visit. Lots to see and do. Great bargains, numerous stores -- bargaining welcomed so good prices may be obtained. Make sure to take the dhow ferries across the creek so you get the experience of both areas of the creek. The creek area is easily accessible from anywhere in Dubai by the metro.
Watch the world go by. Plenty of places to have something to eat or just have a drink. We liked it at night when the whole palace was illumanited

a must do. Travel the creek by dhow and see the sights! From fantastic new buildings to old souks, from large cruising boats with paying passengers to humble traders loading their dhows with anything from fruit and veg to cars. You do not get the impression that this is a manmade creek, it seems like an ancient waterway leading to the sea. Amazing sights, well worth a visit

Nice creek. Nice creekWalking aroundor using the Abra to to from Diera to Bur Dubai this the creek in my view and what i doin the i had a cruise by Almansour Dhow when i used to stay at radisson blue creek hotel ( former intercontinental )but in evening it is very nice to walk thereplease be careful of the humidity

In the evening you should go there.... Dubai Creek is a must visit place in Dubai.It's in Bur Dubai.The best time to visit is Nov to March, after this its hot very hot.Evening time is best to see the creek.To reach here you need to get down at Al Ghubaiba Metro Station(Green Line) or you can take a bus to Al Ghubaiba Bus Stop, it's a bus station, actually. Once you get down,the creek is at a stone's throw. One of the many attractions in this area are Old house of the Sheikh , Heritage Village , there are some restaurants where u can enjoy authentic Arabian food overlooking the creek. This place is clam n beautiful in the evening when u can c bright lit city n decorated boats.If u wanna go on other side of the creek u can take an Abra (small boat).Its takes only 1 AED. But be careful with children because there is no safety measure on Abra.

I loved the creek. The creek I was told was man made however I couldn't see any evidence of that.The creek divides the old city and the Souk area. The creek is bordered by markets and food areas and of course mosques. To cross the creek you travel by a boat that costs 1 dm local currency. You are directed to the next boat and pay the Captain directly.It was a sureel experience to sit on the ferry and cross the creek with the amount of boats, carrying locals from place to place.In the evening I took a dinner cruise that was nice if only for the lights of the city.A must see in Dubai
nice place to walk watch. Walking their watching ships and creek , take an local boat just for 1 ADE between the two banks enjoy the old markets

its green.... A beautiful landscape and lots of trees (which Dubai lacks in other places), the creek was literally a 'cool' place. The green grass pastures with shadows of trees makes it a perfect picnic spot to break out of city's mundane life. It also has a children's park and a hosts a dolphin show.

Deira Creek River Boat Ride. After 2 days of 'walking' Dubai, we decided to take a river boat ride! Took a water taxi from the Gold Souk to Heritage Village then hopped on a river boat for an hour's cruise up and down Deira Creek. It was lovely to get away from the hustle and bustle. & just enjoy the views. Cost was 120AED for 2 of us...absolute bargain. Highly recommended if you just want to see the sights Deira Creek with the lovely fresh breeze cooling you down!

Excellent way to see the city. We took a water taxi tour of Deira creek, Dubai during our recent visit to the city, we boarded the taxi at the water taxi stand close to the textile souk and for AED 120 total, we had a personal ride up then back down the river taking about an hour. The taxi was the same as those which shuttle back and forward across the river all day so you need to be careful for sunburn as they only have a central canopy but the views from the boat as it travelled up and down were superb. The driver was able to answer any questions we had along the way and the trip was both interesting and extremely safe. We would recommend this experience to anyone looking for a relaxing 60 minutes while in Dubai.
Don't visit on a Friday. Don't visit on a Friday or you'll miss half of the stores. You need to be ready to ear all the store people calling you to enter but it's part of the experience.
Great value. We took a one hour boat trip and really enjoyed it. The contrast between the traditional dows piled high with cars, fridges etc and the gold glass fronted buildings was fascinating.
Romantic place. Best place for a walk at night with your beloved one. Beautiful place with so much choices (restaurants, bars, sports..)

Experience old Dubai. This is a must for every visitor to Dubai. Put aside the glitz and glamour for a few hours and experience old Dubai.Take a 1 dirham abra ride across the creek into the sight and smells of the souks.
Beautiful to walk along at sun set. I found it very calm at night even tho it was very busy, there was a nice breeze from the water. Great way to see old Dubai

Renewed continuously. in this area you will meet ancient and new Dubai; it serves well to give you an overview about treasures of its' starting point: trade through water, Arabian soukh, Indian spices, religious places of several kinds etc.

Private boat trip Dubai Creek, enjoyable. When we came out of wandering through the Gold and Spice Souks, jaded by vendors pushing things at us and offering us great deals, we walked across the street to what I think was the Dubai Old Souk Marine Transport Station. Here you can take a ferry across the creek, but friends told us you could charter a boat for an hour-long private trip up and back the creek. My wife and I both enjoyed the experience and thought it was good value for money.There is a set price for the charter, posted at the jetty. The boats and pilots seemed to be under government control.Our pilot was from India and knew his boat handling. Interesting seeing the cargo 'ships' in the creek, the President's yacht, and an enormous complex on the creek with 'Do Not Photograph' signs prominantly posted. Best not to ask too many questions, but what were deer doing inside its tall fence near a childrens' play set. Well worth the hour and money spent doing.
A must do. Across creek by abras and have a dinner on one of the Dhows on the creek. Do both during the day and evening and you will see two different Dubai's

Experience the real old Dubai. I first crossed Dubai Creek in an abra (water taxi) in 1977. And when I last did it 10 days ago, the experience was pretty much exactly the same.OK, so the surrounding skyline is just a tiny bit different but the sound of the motor chugging on the boat as you cross the Creek from one side to the other is just the same. On top of that, the cost hasn't changed much either: 1 UAE Dirham each is about 16p! And where the bigger dhows are tied-up along the nearby wharfs, boxes of goods are still piled high awaiting collection, with no fear of theft - just as they've always been.So if you want a glimpse of the old, authentic Dubai, take a trip across the Creek.

Wonderful Night cruise up River. Our concierge booked this for us. Our cruise was a Dhow Cruise. All inclusive price. Shuttle from our hotel to the riverbank. Where we boarded around 7.30 pm a brightly lit old Dhou. Tables are up stairs and downstairs. We sat upstairs. All the dhou's leave within fifteen minutes of each other asnd go up and down the river for around two hours. During this time we had as buffet meal which had as great variety, there was hot a combination of hot and cold and spicy food. Salads and vegetables. The host was attentive and drinks flowed. Desert was three choices. The entertainment was beautiful, cultural and lively. (Tanura ancer from Arabia) Iwon't spoil it for you by divulging more, but it did have us mesmerised and clapping loudly and taking photos. There was a photographer on board to capture your memory, and photos available before we departed to purchase. The evening ended with the shuttle taking us back to our hotel. The cruises with the magicians are not as good I believe.

A cultural experience. This area of Dubai is a must see. Take a trip on the abra along the creek. It's very cheap. Although bring a drink with you as the heat can be overcoming. It was nice to really get involved and see more of Dubai
nice water tour. cool breeze - part of the big bus tour which was nice - interesting to hear about the "older" part of the city. Enjoyed it and the back drop of the city was beautiful!

a great trip up the creek. This tour well worth going in. Gives you a good overview of dubai in the past. Commentary on cruise was very interesting. Easy to get to from hop on hop off bus. Area very diffent here than in modern dubai full of contrasts

The Creek. A. new experience, a real tast of the old boats tht ply the seas. The creek is borded by some of the most oustanding architect wonders of the modern world which sets agreat contrast to the historic trading world of old Dubai

Get a feel of Old Dubai. See what Dubai used to be many years ago.Core of all business and cultural activities until early 2000.Sure you can find anything from places of worship to night life on both sides of the creek. Food, Street Vendors, Souqs, Shopping Malls, Hotels. A 2-3 hour creek cruise is worth the money.

Sophisiticated. Dubai Creek ticks all the boxes. Great food outlet, an amazing view and a golf course nearby. This is where you can also catch a ride in a seaplane. The only seaplane service of it's kind.

Heartbeat of the old city. A leisurely walk at dusk or even early evening in winter, feels very relaxing as the waves lash against the berth on either side of the creek. The seagulls flying all over add to the romance of the Arabian sunset. There are few cities in the world, that can boast of such beautiful promenades that circle the water bodies such as the Dubai Creek. An ABRA (local boat ride) is a must, if you are a visitor, quick, cheap and efficient transport within the city. A boat cruise on the creek at night is a beautiful experience.
Worth a visit. Nice place to visit. Have you tried relaxing along a creek with a crowd. Try it out. Its worth an experience.

Old Dubai. Take a trip on one of the Water Taxi's to experience the sense of old Dubai. Imagine all of the Trading vessels from Africa and the Indian continent sailing up the Creek loaded with produce. You can still see that today. While you are there visit the Spice Souk and savour the smells of a world of spices

A trip to Dubai won't be complete without it!. A wonderful treat in this modern and super glitzy city! Walk by the Dubai Creek and take in the sounds and sights of a bygone era, take an abra ride, wander around in the souqs, etc. This is a must see part of town!

Always Enjoy Getting On The Water. I love boats so had to go for a trip on the Dubai Creek. It gives a different perspective of Dubai and allows you to get a flavour of the historic side of Dubai and what it used to be like. It's a good way to visit the souqs plus it's a bit cooler when you're on the water. Definitely worth a trip.

A must do!. Visiting Dubai Creek you experience the atmosphere and buzz of the heart of old Dubai. Watch the world go by as you walk along the wharfage, or take an Abra up the creek and see Dubai's amazing buildings from the water. Watch the Dhows being loaded, you will be surprised at how much they hold! This is a whole world away from the glitzy hotels and beach clubs, a definite must do! Make sure you visit the Spice and Gold souk whilst you are in this area, fascinating!

Such a nice contrast. Forget the shiny tall buildings, the heart and soul of Dubai are found in the side streets around the creekside of Deira and Bur Dubai. Whenever I have visitors I take them on a simple trip around the creek. Starting by the US embassy catch a water bus to cross the water and get off next to the Dhow loading area. Walk alongside the Dhows checking out all the weird and wonderful things being loaded and keep going till you get to the spice souk. Then head to the gold souq, head back to the creek and cross the water on an Abra to the old souk and then finally walk along to Shindiga.

Dubai Creek is a little Gem. The creek is a wonderful way to explore the old town & what Dubai was famous for. The boat ride across the creek is an ideal way to explore the hustle & bustle of the old markets. This is an enchanting way to view Dubai's amazing skyline with the old & new respectively.
lovely place. go there for walking then visit dubai heritage village and take one of these traditional small boat to go to the souk of gold

Old Dubai. Loved the old boats the Dowhs laden with goods travelling to far away lands in wooden boats. Lookig at beautiful Dubai from the water as you go sailing down the creek and the ambience around the markets.

Very nice - rent a boat and go up and down. You can haggle and rent a boat, you can also cross on either the Dubai RTA (public transport) mini-ferries or on the smaller but more frequent wooden people boats that give you a closer-to-the-water feeling.Also, you can enjoy dinner on a dhow cruise at night. These tickets are often for sale on the Groupon-clone sites for the Dubai/AE.

Not your modern tourist centre. A visit to Dubai Creek was a very nice change of pace. We'd seen lots of sparkling skyscrapers and modern architecture, so it was great to see a more down-to-earth, cultural place. The river is bustling with sights and sounds. The water taxi across the creek was fun and cheap, and a good chance to get a different view of the city. There are markets on both sides of the creek which are also packed with people and interesting wares. Easy walking distance to the Dubai museum on one side and the gold souk on the other. Well worth an hour or two of your time.

Creek? More like bustling river or inlet!. Dubai Creek is a wonderful divider between the original city in Deira and what has become more well known as Dubai across the river. Staying near the Creek is a treat - watching the ships loading absolutely anything you can think of (except live animals), seeing the beautiful Dubai Chamber and Bank buildings, and accessing the shopping streets of Deira, this is more charming than most of the areas with big, newer buildings. Do not miss the absolute best cheap thrill of Dubai - jump on an abra (a small motor boat) with a compliment of people from all over the world, pay your 15 cents and get a nice ride across the Creek (you can visit the museum on the other side or just walk about). Do this at sunset, then ride back in the dark and you will love it.

Very pleasant visit. We took one of the numerous dhow cruises with on board dinner from the Bur Dubai end of the creek. About 2 hours long, it was a pleasant experience drifting down the broad creek and seeing the sights and sounds of old Dubai on both the sides. The Marina, which we visited the next day is also very pleasant with some greenery (welcome in a desert city !!) around and some short eats stalls. The brightly lit boats on the creek were a nice sight too. On board commentary would have helped understand what we were seeing a little better, maybe it is available on other boats.

Goods to Iran. Every day you can see the stacks of goods waiting to be sailed mainly to Iran as they sit in huge piles often without security. Including televisions, fridges, food, tyres etc. then at night most of the 400 dhows leave for Africa and Iran.

romantic ride in boat. well organised and safety taken on boat. food was served which was also good . spend at least two hours and felt relaxed. while sailing saw lovely architects of building. good experience. even the dance show done by a man was tooo good

Experience Old Dubai... The fiancé wanted to show me Old Dubai..so we boarded an dhow/abra to cross the creek. I have no idea where you have to go to board the boats, honestly I wasn't paying attention. But I'm sure any taxi driver would know. Once you get there it is relatively easy to buy your ticket and board. I felt like we were the only "tourists" on the boat, so it is definitely a good place to get a sense of what "the real Dubai" is like. The boat drivers sit and maneuver the abra from the center of the boat, strange..never seen anything quite like it! But all in all, the experience was enjoyable on the two rides we took across the Dubai Creek. If you are a freak about safety, maybe this experience isn't for you. Yeah don't think we would've gone on it if we had kids or any type of disability. Doubt these are regulated,,and am not sure what would happen if it was to tip over! Can't speak for the cleanliness of the water either..but who cares. Do it anyway.

Relaxing view if the boats. Dubai at night in Creekside is a relaxing activity watching colourful cruise boats go back & forth. Try walking or jogging to the end if the peninsula that leads to spice souk, gold souk and fish market.
Abra's rule!. Walk around and cross the Dubai Creek by abra, then walk all along the corniche! Great views, great walk, simply enjoyable.

Criss cross. For 1 Dhirim its still the cheapest way to cross the water and reach the other side of Dubai. Its fun during busy periods lining up for the dhow to arrive and stepping in and finding a place to seat. Once you set off its case of admiring the views, taking pictures until you get to the other side.

Tradition meets Modern Dubai. This is an excellent place for experiencing the interaction between the traditional Dubai and the modern world. Impressive are the wooden decks of the ship-taxis in comparison to the modern yachts.

The other side of Dubai. Well worth a visit & have yourself a little go on the dhows or water taxisMany places to check out on either side of the creek.Have a go round to the Sook's, unless the hassling / haggling bugs you

Boat ride. We went on a boat down the creek. I wasn't expecting such a big river! It was great to see all the different areas and buildings of Dubai from the water. The boat ride was free as we got it with the Big Bus company. They offer you ice cream and drinks to purchase as you sit back, relax and listen to the audio guide. This isn't a tour that everyone will like. If you are interested in seeing and hearing more about the history of Dubai without anything exciting happening then this is for you. Simple, easygoing and free boat trip. There are other dows available where you can cruise in the evening and have a luxury meal. Some of the dows you will see are beautiful.

Oasis in the desert. Dubai never fails to amaze me in the sense that there is so much greenery around, it makes you wonder if you really are in a desert. Dubai Creek is one such example of a finely crafted promenade where there are tour boats and a nice garden. Is missing a kids play area, and may work well if there is a small area in the gardens where the kids can swing and slide around. Hope Dubai Municipality is listening,

Evening cruise with diner on a "Dow". We booked this through the hotel ( downtown Sheriton) on our arrival late afternoon, basically just looking for something to do for the first evening in Dubai. We were not disappointed, as we were picked up at the hotel door, and returned after the cruise, approx 10 pm. The cruise was almost fully booked", the food was good, and plenty of it (buffet styl) and the waiter service was excellent.The cruise also included a show, a magician, who entertained with various tricks. A very pleasant evening in all, well worth the money, and a great way to spend the first night after a long flight.

Evening ride on the creek. We chartered a river taxi for a reasonable amount of 120 Durum and sailed down the creek and back at sunset. Our driver Sayed was friendly and knowledgeable. yes it is a rustic set up but delightful.
A MUST SEE!. Take a private Abra ride for 100 AED for up to 20pl for a half hour trip down the creek. Guide was friendly and dropped us at the Souks.

a bridge too far. The small cross river trip (1 dirham), excellent value but not enough crossing points. The creek cruise was slow and not that exciting. WE did cross and intended to wallk but due to non-scalled maps, realised that the bridges were too far apart, so had to hail a river boat and bartered a crossing/

Another interesting experience. We had taken a city tour and used a taxi across the Dubai Creek to visit to Spices Souk and the Gold Souk . It was fine with a lovely cool breeze blowing gently. We have travelled on the Creek on several occasions and always found it enjoyable

Dubai Old Part. Went there in February late night. It was weekend and the people were setting there playing games, eating and resting. There is the old market, the old part of Dubai. I have been advised to go to the Greek park but I haven't yet.

Cable car up the creek!. Took a ride in the cable car along the creek... some spectacular views. Cheap entry to the park. Spotless clean. We went in the evening so it was slightly cooler. would love to go back again in the daytime. You pay again for the cable car but it's still cheap.

Take a boat trip with locals. For just 1 AED you can take a boat trip across the creek with that funny looking boats packed with locals - it is cheep and it is fun. Otherwise, I was not too impressed with Dubai Creek itself, but maybe I was just too hot

Old boats.. nothing to do in the day. If you like old oriental looking boats.. come to the creek. The creek itself is cool the way it separates the city, but unless you are planning to dine on one of the dinner cruises (I did not, but held some are pretty good) there is zero to do. Made for a nice walk though.

Took a tour of the creek with Yellow boat. This was pretty fun 90 mins of cruising around the creek and out to see. We saw the Sheiks yacht ( its more like a cruise liner) parked on his 2nd wifes island. Then checked out the new hotels being built saw the palm and then back again on this fast rubber sided boat. Its a little pricey to be honest but we had the entertainer which made it buy one get one free

Lots of floating boat restaurants. We decided to have a ride in a taxi to see the older side of Dubai and crikey this is totally different from the newer side of Dubai could'nt believe it. There are lots of floating boat restaurants we wanted to eat in one but was a little weary as there were lots of them and no one seemed to be eating on them which meant you did'nt know how long the food had been there for. There are lots of water taxis across the creek so try one while your there. Lots of shops and souks. A must see if you are staying in the Jurmeirah side of Dubai a real eye opener and great to see the culture i loved it.

So much going on. This is a different world... lots of people from all over the world, colourful and along the edge museums many of which are free and very well presented. souks every where. Have fun!! Safe too.

FUR SHOPPING. Velvet Furs is in an inimitable position of offering its customers the most magnificent to the most casual fur garments at unparalleled prices. Dubai outlet includes more than 6500 garments which offer the customers a wide range of selection. Velvet Furs is a destination for anyone who will not settle for anything less than the original. Because of the good relation between Velvet Furs and fur manufacturers worldwide, Velvet Furs have the exclusive privilege to present some of the best international brands in its boutique. Raw material selection, manufacturing excellence and classic and contemporary designs are meticulously combined with the unique vision and signatures of their master furriers are the main competitive edge of Velvet Furs with other players in the market.

Always worth a visit when in Dubai. My family and I always visit the Dubai Creek. As my parents used to live here we find it one of the places in Dubai which hasn't changed too much. It is really nice to go to the creek around sunset and hire out an Abra to have a ride on. If visiting Dubai and want to see something different the shops and local attractions in and around Bur Dubai and the Gold/Spice Souq are worth visiting to get away from the madness of futuristic Dubai.

Interesting Place To Explore. The best way to see Dubai creek is to take a cruise on one of the many Dhows an hour cruise will see you taken slowly down and back up part of the creek. As you proceed down the creek you will pass things like the Dubai Museum on your left and the "old Souk" and of course Abra stations. on the return leg you pass the Gold Souk and Spice Souk and lots of working Dhows taking goods up and down the coast.It is a good idea to do the cruise to familiarise yourself with the area, then you can either use the hop on/off bus to move around or walk if you are feeling energetic. Personally I would recommend the hop on/off bus.You can of course cross the creek by Abra there are plenty around (like a water taxi).Try and time you visit to see the creek in both daylight and at night. It is quite nice to see the Dhows all lit up taking people slowly up and down the creek whilst enjoying a meal and usually some dancing.You will need to get a taxi or the metro on an evening as the hop on/off bus stops around 6-00 pm.There is plenty to look around each side of the creek and is worth spending at least half a day there.
Lots of character and fun!. This is a lovely place to visit, more local and authentic without all the bling bling and glitters of Downtown Dubai. Great to walk around, nice restaurants.

Taste of the "old" Dubai. Buzzing relaxed afternoon.... Nice walk along the creek with the constant activities of dhows... From Bur Dubai side where you can also find most of the consulates, it is where you can jump on board of one of the many dhows for a cruise along the creek. But it is from the Deira side where you can have a nice walk, grab a fresh juice from one of the many kiosks, watch the dhows being loaded with all kinds of good and feel like you have been transported back in time.... A must visit...
Should try. You can see many thing in Dubai which next to the river. It is the best choice for guest who want to travel in river

It's OK. I would agree with a previous reviewer. It's OK, but nothing special. The advertising "blurb" gives the impression this is a small little river with places to stroll and explore in the evening. In actual fact it's a fairly large river which is sided by the same kind of towers you see on the main road. It's a just river with lots of tourists and not particularly scenic or beautiful. My wife and I both agree that we would have preferred to spend the evening strolling around the Fountain lake next to the Dubai Mall. There seemed to be far more atmosphere and things to do.

Busy Waterfront Scene. I enjoy the Dubai Creek area mainly because of the feel of the place with all of the boat traffic and buzz of people. There are also some good restaurants to enjoy along the creek closer and at the Heritage Village area where a meal can be enjoyed creekside.The constant moving about of the small boats (abras) creates a constantly moving scene and in the evenings after dark, the larger floating restaurants add to the colorful scene. The downside for me are the vendors and shop employees that want to push their shawls, scarves, watches, handbags, etc. that I just am not interested in. If you want to enjoy a unique space and take a 1 AED ride across the creek, come here and mix it up with the locals and the tourists.

Nothing special. By Dubai standards, I guess this is an "attraction", but it's really nothing special according to me. It's a creek with lots of tourist and small boats taking tourists across and up and down the creek. It's not particularly beatiful - no interesting buildings or historical sites or anything. I would only suggest you going here if you don't have anything better to do - take a stroll along the creek in the afternoon and watch the people.
Nice view. The view is very nice. Lots of boat and floating restaurants. It is also near Dubai Heritage Museum and Mosque.
Boat across the creek. This is a must do if you are in Dubai. Cheep trip across the creek is great fun and after a wander around the Souk's we headed for Bayt Al Wakeel on the other side for lunch.

Atmospheric, must-see on a visit to Dubai. I really like the creek area of Dubai. It's so different to the rest of the city and is one of the few places that really has that "arabian" spirit.There is much to do there - from visiting the many museums, to going to the souks, to visiting the cultural centers to going to the creek park and beyond. Its too much to see (and especially walk) during the day time so my recommendation is to break up your visit to the different ends of the creek and do it over a couple of days.I typically start at the abra dock end of the creek.The metro for this is al ghuibaiba ( and not creek). If you come out of the main entrance my tip is to look behind you as it can get confusing and you can easily miss the whole creek if you end up walking towards the wrong direction. A good orientation point is the HSBC bank and one of the government buildings (I think its the finance ministry). From this point you are at the corner of the top of the creek and can walk left towards the cultural centers or right towards the abra docks and the entrance to the textile/souvenir souq. The abra docks (abra is the name of the wooden open boats which go back and forth across the creek) have a couple of stops along the embankment. Coming from the metro station, the first dock is the boat which takes you across to the souq stop - baniyas. These boats go very frequently and you will find yourself being loaded onto them. They are open boats so you simply need to walk on and sit down, you'll be squeezed next to every nationality, age and sex - there are no rules that need to be adhered to. You do not need to pay until you are on the boat and then it should be maximum of 2 dirhams per person per crossing. Make sure you have small change available but also make sure that if they take your money and you don't get change that you ask for the change back as sometimes they "forget". Crossing the creek on the abra is very quick - a little too quick for my liking as I would have loved to stayed on it for hours, - its fun and you get to be right in the middle of the creek's hustle and bustle. Once on the other side you can head to the gold souq and the spice souq. There are not really any signs so you need to follow your instinct or ask to find the entrance . The gold souq is under cover of a wooden roof but it can get very hot and although its quite wide for a souq it is still crowded. Expect the calls from the shop owners enticing you to come inside and take a look - this is typical for souqs around the world. Apart from the calls there is not really any harrassment. The souq is only really a couple of streets across so its quite small compared to the more famous ones in marrakesch but still worth a visit. The Gold souq merges into the spice and herb souq. Again, it can be quite hard to find. My tip is to look for the spice shop within the gold soug (there are not many) , which is on the corner of an alley - this is the alley which leads to the bigger spice and herb section. Note that there are no shops with refreshments/selling water in the souq so take your own water or be prepared to buy from the men offering cans of coke etc from trays above their heads as they walk around - you'll find these close to the entrance and not further on. At the beginning of my visit I was annoyed by them trying to sell to me but as I got further into the souq and away from them I wish I had bought a bottle or two. After the souq visit you can get back on at the same abra dock and head back to the other side or alternatively walk about 10 minutes up the creek (with creek on your right side) and head to the second abra docks - these also take you back to where you started but the ride is a little longer so extends the abra adventure!Back on the original side of the creek you can either head into the textile souk - which is in a street to the right of the dock (right if you are facing the creek) or left towards the various cultural centers. The textile souq is open air and worth a look. There is not really any emiraati goods to buy - its all of Indian origin but if you look hard enough you can find some quality stuff among the cheap souvenirs.Walking towards the cultural strip of the souq you will go past an art center, a few restaurants (there is one quite close to the creek corner with an ice cream stall outside which has excellent food), and various old style buildings which all house a specialty. My favourites are the sheikh saaed al maktoum house (probably wrong spelling), - this hosts a lot of photo exhibits, old documents, etc which documents the history of Dubai - from the time before the emirates, to the agreements with the oil companies, to the lines of rulership between the different states. The islamic caligraphy center is also worth a visit - not only are the pieces beautiful but you will get invited in for tea with one of the emiraatis who can answer any of your questions. The heritage center is also along this same strip. Some of the houses have fees, some not but none of te fees are prohibitive. My tip is to go to the top of any of the buildings you go into as you get a good view of the modern city from the old and the contrast of seeing the silhouette of the Burj Khalifa in the distance is something quite unique. Also, feel free to open doors and go inside rooms - most of the exhibits are housed behind closed doors due to the sun but lack signs to tell you there is something inside - or the signs are so discreet they are unnoticeable. All rooms are air conditioned and often exhibits are triggered to start when someone walks into the room.You can take boat tours of the creek . There is one from the RTA (the transport system). This does not run very often but if you like to travel on a large, modern air conditioned boat then this is to be recommended. There are two tickets - gold and silver. The gold is 75 dirhams for an hours trip. My recommendation is to buy silver however as although the seats are less comfy, you are then allowed to stand out in the open at the back of the boat and its better for photos. If however you don't mind the heat then its much better to take one of the abra trips or one of the large dhow boats as this really gives you the creek experience.Not far from the creek area is the sheikh mohammed center for cultural understanding and the dubai museum . These are not in the same area as the other cultrual centers however and its advisable to take a map as the walk between creek side and the dubai museums is quite difficult. I have given up quite a few times. The creek is also worth a visit at night as its cooler and the boats are lit up.At the other end of the creek is the creek park. This is beautiful, huge and an unexpected sea of green in the middle of everything. Its a must see but not really doable in the same day so go back with a picnic basket and enjoy its tranquility . At the park end of the creek park you can also head to the nature reservation area and the yacht club if you are looking for some refreshments.My only tip is to take water and a hat as it always seems to be hotter here than in the rest of Dubai and there is not much shade.All in all, the creek is really the best area of Dubai and worth many many visits.
Atmospheric views. The creek is very atmospheric with it's abra boats. They are very cheap and a nice way to experience the Creek! It is a easy way of transport between the two sides.

great to stay & visit. The best area of Dubia mixing old and new.Worth a trip on a abras, though we werent certian of the ticket system. Souks well worth a visit. Better signs would assist as easy not top find what you are looking for.
Night time in March is an excellent to visit. Excellent, atmosphere, very tranquil to see the boats covered in lights, going up and down the creek at night.

Must see. For a little taste of the original Dubai, visit a Dubai Creek. We enjoyed wandering around the souks and doing some hard bartering! Watching the dowhs is also fascinating. Worth visiting early morning or early evening as many places close in the middle of the day.

Great. I spent some time at the Dubai creek Golf Club. I must have to admit, it was a reception, and they were giving away cigars, and I truly enjoyed smoking it by the creek sitting on a huge rock. An enjoyable place.
Very interesting. Took a trip up the creek on a private wooden old boat we were lucky had a guide with good English who made the trip even more interesting. Great way to spend a morning.

Cheap and worth doing if you are there. Visited the Deira area to go to the souks and decided to cross the creek on one of the little boats. Very cheap to cross - something silly like 20p each. The creek is busy with lots of boats and it was an easy and interesting way to get across. Worth doing if you are in that area.
Experiance the creek. Experience what I call the "real Dubai" - hustle, bustle, people, markets. Not to be missed. Take an abra (1 dirham fare, that's all)

Lively, busy and fascinating. Experience what I call the "real Dubai" - hustle, bustle, people, markets. Not to be missed.Take an abra (1 dirham fare, that's all) across to the other side to see the souks and the dhows being loaded with a huge variety of goods. Go to the Heritage Village and visit the Dubai Museum to see traditional houses and find out more about the "old life".

Creek at night. Two gentlemen offered to give a tour on a boat for 150, it was bargain apparently, not too sure as I am not used to the Dirhams. Anyway I gave it a go. It was dark and the creek all lit up was very cool. So we went to the edge of the bay where the bridge is then u turned and headed to the old Souk, can't remember if it was the spice or the textiles one, but there were no spices so..The guy let me drive the boat as well which was quite cool, don't see much at night but all the lights make it and it is a nice way of spending an hour.Recommend it

Rent a boat and see the creek. We walked along the creek and rented a boat for the 5 of us for 100 AED near the Hilton. Had the boat all to our selves for over 90 minutes. We went from the floating bridge up to the markets and back. Great way to see the creek.

Always worth a visit, every day different. It's so alive here. The sun and the water, the high rise and the traders who so want to sell you a bargain. So make sure you do. Bargain I mean. I am not the best at negotiating but start really low. I mean really low. They asked 180 for trousers and I got them for 50 but I know they would have sold for less. Don't be intimidated! Enjoy the ferry. Enjoy Dubai.

Dubai Creek at night. Brilliant and a must to visit on any trip to Dubai. You can take the small taxi boats from one one side to the other or you can cruise the creek in one of the many boats serving food. A great insight into the real Dubai. We ate at a wonderful restaurant which looked a bit like a large wooden balcony sticking out over the water on the same side as the Souks
great views. very cleangood access since bus station and dubai metro is nearbywith deira city center nearbycan see burj khalifa from the other sidelots of taxiswill see this again soon
A bit dirty but lovely to see the water. We had lunch overlooking the creek and it was lovely to see the dhow up and down the creek, some of whom emitted quite a bit of exhaust.
Excellent. We went on a cruise on the Dubai Creek and I don't usually engage in anyhting to do with water but this was serene. I loved it

Special. We stayed in Al Barsha. Of course, it was a big difference walking around in Dubai Creek, the gold and other souks, compared with the other parts of Dubai. I recommend the experience though. Let people try to sell you anyting, from pashminas to fake Rolex watches of fake handbags. Take a water taxi for 1 dirham to cross the water. See wonderful looking colored boats navigate through the water. Of course, when a seagull drops "something" on your foot (as with my wife), it's a bit less romantic ... But it's a must do.

Amazing view & Food. Good place to spend your evening. This offers the tranquility amidst hustle bustle of the city. Went for evening Dubai creek dinner on Dhow Cruise. Food, people on board, Dhow, Tanura dance on board the Dhow..everything was worth the time & money. Must to do while you are in Dubai.

Wonderful "old Dubai" area. Loved the Dhow taxis - we did a private 30 minute taxi around the creek for c£30. The water taxi journey from one side to another is very quick and frequent - every minute! Loved the Gold and spice souks and the architecture around the old quarter. Found the service at the only Creekside restaurant we could find surly and indifferent, which was a first for our entire trip, but the food was fine and it didn't mar the day overall.

Pleasant abra cruise. Start off your visit in Dubai by the Creek. The river that separates the old and modern part of Dubai, where everything started in the 50s. Around 800 libaneses settled here and lived off fishing and pearls, then oil was found and everything changed. We went on a "abra" cruise (the typical wooden boat of the region). It was an hour long, just enough to have a picture of the area and map the following touristic sight to visit.
Ride an Abra!. We took an abra in Dubai Festival City and cruised along the creek. Ticket ranges 25-50DHS depending on the abra size.It was a 30-minute cruise. It was scenic and romantic.

The Heart of Old Dubai. I've loved this area of Dubai since my first trip here in 1980. It is indeed the heart of the old city and an exciting area to visit. I love walking along from the Sheraton to the Gold Souk watching the Dhows being loaded with their cargos bound for Iran, Somalia, etc. An Abra ride across to the Bastakia area is a cheap thrill and allows you to explore the galleries and museums and even get to Bur Dubai.
Nice Boat view experience. Another perspective of Dubai by the creek. Overview if the city. Included in BigRedBus tour package tour. Otherwise you may do this separately.

Lovely for families. We visited the creek on New Years day and there were lots of families picnicking. There was a lovely atmosphere with plenty for everyone to do, from fair rides, to the cable car ride, go karting. I'd definitely recommend it - go along in the afternoon with a picnic and let the kids run wild.

Great time out from the malls!. Dubai Creek is really worth taking the time to discover - you can get a water bus/taxi across the creek for about a dirham, and it's great. There is some good shopping bargains to be found around the creek and it makes a nice change from the ultra modern malls.

Board Walk. Board walk is one of the best restaurant in Dubai Creek area. The have a very good Bar with good seafood dishes. At the entrance they display live oysters and lot of seafood. Nice place to have lunch and / Dinner with family and friends.Here you sit outside on a board walk hanging over the water. You can have a nice view of the creek from here. Recommend this place.
Nice oasis in the Deira. The water here is nice looking and it's a fascinating sight to see all the Dhows delivering the goods for all of the souks in the Deira.
Boat ride. through the creek will give you a sense of the fast development of this once small port , it feels great to be on the boat beating the heat of Dubai

TAKE THE TRIP ACROSS THE WATER!. Fantastic little boat trip. This trip across the water was part of a tour, the weather was perfect, the views were wonderful. Loved it. You'll be sorry if you don't do this on your visit to Dubai.

Shopaholic. Good place to shop on street get good deals in cheap price you name it and you will get it small & big shoping center & Malls. creek is famous for small boats crossing you from oneside of the creek to another minimum charges 01.00 Dhs per passenger.
A must see. I loved visiting the creek both during the day and at night, its a hub of activity and a must see. Travelling on the dhows is a fanatstic experience
lovely views. We stayed opposite the creek and was nice to watch the day to day goings on.Relaxing to walk along and interesting to see all the cargo being shipped.

Boatin for half an hour. Good to book for a trip, the boat will take you through the creek (river) with a guide. After this experience you can try the small water taxis for 1 AED (20 EUR cent), good ploy, take a walk and visit the mosque and the harbour.

Photo Moment. Area to walk along to take beautiful photos of the waterfront. Cross the creek on an abra (flat bottomed open sided water taxi), see the dhows (sailing vessels), view the beautiful waterfront, enjoy the Creekside Park and even take a creek cruise at sunset. Definitely could spend an entire day here.

Value for money !. There cannot be anywhere in the world as cheap as this form of transport ! Just 1 dirham to cross the creek - and very useful this is as the metro takes you to one side and the gold souk and spice souk are on the other. The journey takes just a few minutes as you sit back to back with locals - who are all friendly enough to lend a hand when you are trying to sit down or stand up and the boat is moving ! An experience not to be missed.

Not to be missed. We were aiming for Bastakia but got off the metro at the wrong stop and were directed to walk back along to creek to find it. Glad we did now as it was so different from Jumereih beach where our hotel was - a complete contrast and full of atmosphere - great watching people boarding the abras and all the creek activity with the massive working dhows - so busy. We had to walk through a couple of souks on the way which I am not too keen on really but we just kept saying 'no'!

Beautiful and relaxing... We visited Dubai Creek for our last night before heading on the plane home.This area is a part of the old Dubai and here you really feel relaxed. Or that is if you don't go "down town" to the tourist shops, with way to many people and aversive salesmen.. We even experienced that one held me by my arm, to hold me back in the store, because I wouldn't pay what he demanded.But nevertheless, the Dubai Creek is an really beautiful area where you can take the waterbus from one side to another a and visit different Souks (markets). My girl and I went for a 1 hour boat trip up and down the area and got an guided tour by our captain. We hired the guy for a 1 hour trip and only payed 100 UAE. It was a really nice way to enjoy the views, fresh air and relax in the sun, before heading to the airport.

Lovely, relaxing boat ride. We took a boat trip down Dubai Creek with Dubai Tours as part of the Big Bus Tours. It was great to see the area by boat and something I would recommend.The commentary was very informative and helped guide us to places of interest which we could then go on to visit. It was a great opportunity to take lots of photographs of the surrounding area and it was a great way to spend an hour relaxing.
Refreshing. We took a walk along the creek.it was really pleasant.It was a long stretch but because of its beauty and the wonderful breeze we didn't realise it.enjoyed the evening a lot

Nice to walk around and take an abra to the other site. Dubai Creek is nice to walk around, the boots are loaded with hundreds of appliances. You can go to the abra station and for 1 AED (about 20 euro cents...) get a ride to the other side!

A not so special Moonlight Sonata. Joined this trip expecting special meal in special surroundings: unfortunately it was nothing of the sort.The dhow had two covered decks with seating for around 40 people on each; food was a very average mixed buffet. There was little atmosphere, not even background music, and nowhere to stand to take in the air or the views; in truth this area of Dubai Creek is uninspiring.Staff were polite and efficient and were pickup and dropoffs, but overall an anodyne experience.Surely there are better experiences to be had on one of the dozens of boats out there?
Make sure you catch a boat across the creek. A quick trip across the creek from the shopping in the old town to the spice & gold markets on the other side. Well worth the couple of dollars!

Wonderful place to visit while in Dubai. Dubai Creek is the heart and soul of Dubai. It is definitely a must see during any visit to Dubai. There are wonderful sights and sounds of the very authentic and original life of Dubai.
Dubai as it should be. The creek gives an impressions of what used to be. With the the little ferries goings back hand forth plus the souks either side of the water it's an absolute delight!

Amazing Experience. It was all in all an amazing experience.....Flight was very much comfortable and they also agreed to accommodate the excess baggage while returning from Dubai....Great Help...Special Thanks...Also the OK to Board was not required which was another convenience. Soo Je form the Travel to the Destination visit it was a good experience. Thanks to Jet Airways...

The charming atmosphere of old Dubai!. The Dubai Creek has a very charming atmosphere of old Dubai, due to its old buildings, the old 'port', the shops, the creek itself, and the beautiful, wooden 'abra's, meaning boats.The Spice Souk is located opposite to the creek, and just a short walk away from the Gold Souk.There are lots of boats that will take you to the opposite bank of the creek, where the Meena Bazaar is located. Do try and take this trip in an abra. It is a very pleasant experience.You must visit this place to get a feel of what Dubai was, a decade or two ago.
great but please remove cats from the park. great place but remove the cats for hygiene and safety of people , light up more , its very dark and no sinages for washrooms .
