Dhow cruise at Dubai Creek. We went to Dubai during the Dubai Shopping festival and it was all decked up with neon and LED and the night cruise food while cruising was just great. Costs about 100 AED and worth every Dirhams !!!!

Go as the locals do. Including our Big Bus ticket was a free cruise along the Creek. This is nice to do, it gives a good impression, it takes about 1 hour.
We crossed the Creek several times the way the locals do, in a Dhow. Very nice to do and cheap, only 1 dirham.

A relaxing experience. It is so nice to just sit at a bench and look out over the creek and watch the world go by. You can purchase boat rides etc but I just enjoy the tranquility. It's almost like going back in time to a different world.

Unfortunately rather boring experience. Among different attractions of Dubai I found Dubai Creek cruise with dinner to be rather boring experience. The traditional boat goes in one direction "a bit" than oposite the same distance and again and again... Food was OK, service also fine, but I suppose my expectations were far too high.

Picturesque. i went down here wtih a local friend and it really is beautful... its away from the hustle and bustle and its just such a lovely scenery. we ate and smoked shisha at a local cafe and just watched the boats flow past

A Taste of Old Dubai. I know Old Dubai is kind of an oxymoron, but if one wants an escape from the fast-paced malls and and flashy skyscrapers, then go for an abra ride along the Creek. Watch Iranian and Pakistani sailors unload goods from their colorful dhows. Walk along the Shindagha Waterfront and watch the world go by.
old boats. old way of live in dubai with old boats to this day bringing things in was a nice walk around to see how it used to be and is to this day
A Busy Waterway. Busy Waterway Try the Abrah Crossing Boats as opposed to the Dhow Boats bit nerve wreking and u feel as though u might kust fall into the water but they are qute

A 'must do' experience. If you want to be a proper tourist and see the other side of Dubai this is the place to be. Quite chaotic to find your way to the right boat to cross to the other side. Very old boats, tourists mixed with locals and a very nice scenery to capture. Everything just adds together to give you a very brief but unique moment to see local ordinary life away from the malls, the ferraris and the excessiveness that you experience in the rest of Dubai.
Take the abra. Take a walk along the creek and take an water buss (works with your NOL card, 2 AED) or an abra (only 1 AED). Is very cheap and fun.

Interesting for a few hours. Despite being to Duba quite a few times this was my first visit to the creek. Lots of boats if you want to go for a cruise/meal. Market ok - as seen on the apprentice. Make sure you go on one of the ferries. A bit more authentic than the new "old" town.

Dubai Creek. Dubai Creek is one of the spots where they stop the bus for photography. Its a nice place. You see the Dubai skyline and the various boats afloat on the Creek. On the way you pass the Gold Souk and the Museum. The sea breeze is very refreshing if you take a walk.

Visit Dubai Creek. Whether in Dubai for business, pleasure or both take time out to visit the creek area of the city.Jump on a dhow and take a slow and entertaining escorted cruise up and down the creek and discover the origins and history of the region and its culture. eat in one of the creek side cafes and buy fresh spices and gifts in the souk.Utterly fabulous

Fun to do on your own! No guide needed.. If you want to see Old Dubai, download a map and start at the Dubai Museum. Then go through the Old Souk. Go around the river bend (it actually appears to be across the river when you're standing at the end of the Old Souk) and check out the Sheik Saeed Al Maktoum;s House & Heritage Village. Walk back to the end of the Old Souk and catch a dhow across the river for 1 AED (30 cents!!!) and walk through the spice and gold souks. I think this should take 4-5 if you like to shop. Enjoy!!!

A great experience. Beautiful experience of Dubai of the 1990s and early 2000s.You can take douw rides, other boat rides, walk along the Dubai Creek, rest in parks.There is souqs on both sides of the Creek.Also there is the Dubai Museum very close to the Creek on the Eastside.If you can walk and have time, maybe spend 6 -8 hours exploring both sides of the Creek.Otherwise you can do a quick tour with both ride in 3 hours or less.

Certainly an experience. Souks on either side selling spices, souvenirs etc. Take the water taxi its an experience in itself and the cheapest way to cross the creek. See the old side of Dubai for authenticity. Its a 'must do' if in Dubai.
loved it. lovely and lively with the souks on either side, easy to use the water taxis to go across, and we even spotted jellyfish!
Fantastic. I go there almost everyday, it is one of my favourite parts of Dubai, the old part of the city just makes everything more authentic.
Nice walking area. Take a 2 hours stroll through the "original" Dubai Bastakia quarter, visit Dubai Museum and Dubai Souq, and then take a 1AED Abra ride to the other side of the Creek to Deira.

Enjoyable site and unforgettable memories. Me & my wife visited time to Creek when were in Dubai. Our first visit for Dhow cruise and latter we visited to see Gold Souk and heritage village. Wow no words to say except excellent and unmissible place.
Worth it. Well this place is worth a visit . Went in a Dubai tourist Bus which also could cruise in the waters.
Old Dubai. Cross the Creek by Abra for one Dirham and see old Dubai. Visit the Spice Souk and the Gold Souk. Colourful shops selling scarves, clothes, cushion covers, lamps etc. Great atmosphere.

Worth the effort. To see the culture and get an idea of the real arabic food I highly recommend going along the creek. If you are from a western country just please do yourself a favor and dress appropriately otherwise you will be looked at funnily and feel out of place. I spend a lot of time in the middle east with my company and I know this is one of the best places to find the best traditional Arabic food not to mention herbs and spices. Take the trip have some fun and have a look around it's a temptation for the senses.
Definitely worth visiting. Really great way to see old dubai and very cheap. A must to cross the creek and go and see the souks.

A night of bright lights. The shopping festival is a season where every evening the dubai sky is lit with a variety of fireworks n the al seef street near the creek is with a lot of fun n noise as there a a variety of stalls selling food clothing toys.there r a lot of games.n also a carnival or can say a parade .this is the best time to visit dubai n the creek as it is lit jp miles 151861522
Cruises on Dubai Creek. Been on a couple of these cruises and enjoyed both of them. Usually get a buffet meal included on the cruise and get to see some awesome city landmarks.

Silent & beautiful. The night trip on Dubai Creek on a Dhow was really a different experience. Cruising slowly on an ancient wooden coat called Dhow, enjoying Music, Dance and good food are the added speciality.

BEST PLACE. This should be the first place to visit in Dubai.....Hop off your taxi/bus and enjoy this place on foot........Very beautiful and unique walk along the creek....Spend your first evening at creek and you shall cover almost half of the must see Dubai.... those quiet lanes surrounded by mud walls will taker you to the stories of Arabian nights.....Heritage neighborhood, Arabian tea house, Museum, SMSCU, meena bazar, abra dock station, traditional restaurants serving middle eastern delicacies all fall along the creek....we spent quite a few evenings here smoking shisha along the creek

The Most Authentic Part of Dubai. Well worth a visit to the Marina, the Gold Souk or even just a walk along the Creek where the boats come in, its been 10 years since i came to Dubai and this is the only part i recognise - very lovely highly recommend

Pleasant stroll. I enjoyed essentially all aspects of the Creek, from a dhow cruise, to a visit to the nearby souqs and historical areas, to just walking along the wll landscaped and maintained walkways along the creek. A great place to visit for those of us who just like to stroll around new places.

Neat seeing the historic part of Dubai. My husband and I were interested in seeing the 'older' parts of Dubai so we ventured to the Dubai Creek area. We checked out the old souks, did a little bit of shopping, and took a boat from one side of the creek to the other (only for 1 dirham!). It was an experience to be around the locals area and trying to imagine what it was like being in Dubai back then. I recommend visiting this area to those who are curious about Dubai's history...
Creek Experience. The creek offers boat trips, water taxis, and is also surrounded by restaurants and attractions like the diving centre. Watch the world go by or take part - it is up to you!

replenish by the creek. Indulge in the charm of the enticing Orient where old and new complete each other. Walk along the creek or cross it (on the maybe not so attractive, but very much reliable abra) to go to the Old Souq (Bur Dubai) or the Gold and Spice Souq (Deira). Or you could just enjoy the view in the evening by sitting on one of the terraces (Khan Zaman, Al Bandar, Fatafeet, etc.). Oh, life is sweet!...

Khor Dubai. Cutting through the heart of Dubai, the seawater Dubai Creek winds its way from the trading port on the Gulf to the Ras al Khor bird sanctuary on the desert edge of Dubai.Old-fashioned boats called dhows criss-cross the water from Bur Dubai on the left bank to Deira on the right. Catch a water taxi dhow, called an abra, to get from A to B, or sign up for a romantic sunset dhow cruise traveling further upstream.A cruise reveals the glittering high-rise buildings lining the Creek, passing under several bridges to reach the Creekside gardens. Or take a stroll along the paved promenade lining the Creek on the Bur Dubai side of the waterway.
Take your life in your hands. Take a water taxi up the river at night, then you will understand what I'm talking about. An absolute must!!!! Costs pennies, literally.

Found nothing special. Basically we had a short photo stop here in the morning on our Dubai city tour. Found nothing special. Then we also had the Dhow Chow Cruise in the evening which we found quite boring too.

Old Dubai. This is another Dubai than most people have in mind while thinking about Dubai. No skyscrapers here. This is the old Dubai with small ferry boats and also with dows from other countries, like India, doing business here. Here you can find the real Dubai as it was before the big developments started.
Great Time. Yes, this is the real thing and you can see how the locals cross the creek, plus all of the arab yachts and local shipping. Well worth a visit. A mixture of the old and new.

Abra (cadabra!). Took a trip across the creek in an abra (which in my opinion is the best way to travel on it, far better and authentic than the bigger boats).The only reason I took a star off this was because in the heat, it's unbearable. I was on it when it was 45C and I almost passed out it was so hot. There was no shade either.But it was still utterly enjoyable!

Lovely experience. Many ways you can do this. If you are going on the Big Bus tour then the Dhow cruise on the dubai creek is free. You can also do the creek cruise through the Wonder bus tours. Otherwise can walk along the creek area and cross from Bur dubai to Deira (or vice versa) using the abra (water-taxi) for 1 dirhams.Lovely experience to understand the area and the buildings across the creekside.Recommended

Great experience to get in touch with real Dubai. Dubai is much more than shopping malls or luxury hotels. A trip along Dubai Creek or even better a Abra-boat-trip across the creek will get you in touch with the real Dubai. Looks and smells much more than India or Pakistan and absolute worth a visit.

something that should be experienced in Dubai. not a dollar involved, so why not taking an evening walk around the creek to see the old, new and developing Dubai. the view is amazing and the ride across the creek to the other side (deira) is only 1 dirham. the view during sunset is something you can really appreciate too.

Interesting for a short time. It was fun to see the Abras zipping around and manoeuvring for a dock. The larger boats loaded up for international trade are also pretty cool. If you just want to cross the creek don't get suckered into paying 120 AED a tour. It costs 1AED for the trip across and there's really not a lot to see anyway. Catching an Abra is quite easy, just pick the boat number you want from the signs on the pier and get on board. The driver will take off when the boat is loaded an once you're out on the creek he'll whistle for his money. Note: the boats are not actually tied the the pier for loading and unloading so this trip may not be a good idea for those that are not sure footed!

For 1 AED it's a great ride on an old boat across the creek. This enables you to see the Souks, then cross to the other side to see the old town. We found it was a great day and the boar ride I. The breeze was really nice.

What Dubai is really all about. The creek separating Deira from Dubai is the haunting hub of the two ancient tradiing villages on its banks out of which modern day glitzy Dubai has grown. The over laden dhows that ply its waters remind the visitor of the many centuries of commercial activity feeding the tiny emirates in its hinterland. A water taxi or better still dhow ride up and down the creek is a must for any visitor to Dubai

Nice place. After visiting the souks we took a boat to the other side of the creek. It took about 5 minutes and cost only 1 AED - so either you can rent a privat boat or cross many, many times!It is also a nice place to go for a walk.

Old world feel.. Very much a mix of old and new Dubai. Boats bring goods into Dubai as they have done for decades, but mixed in with all the new buildings and marina. A very enjoyable stroll. Also can take a boat trip along the creek for a reasonable price.

Dubai Creek. You can get to the souks and the creek by Metro. The stop you need is about 4 stops before the one entitled The Creek. Cost by Metro is minimal. The Creek and Souks are a short distance away with the boat ride across the river which is the reason why I wanted to go. Difficult to find your way around the souks but it is worth the trip.

Old meets new.. Love a bit of history? Then this is great...we visited the museum as well as the creek-side walks, cross the creek and moved on to the gold souk. Everything was interesting and informative.

An hour going by buildings. We took the Big Bus tour and it included a "dhow" (really a big boat as opposed to a traditional dhow) on the creek. There are lots of buildings on either side. We had already seen lots of buildings in Dubai, so we wished we had skipped it. However others may enjoy it.

Dubai Creek. Lovely views of the old wooden dows sailing and crossing the Creek.It cost 1 dirham to cross to get from the gold souk and spice souk area to the 'old' souk.Cruises could also be taken on the creek or you could hire your own Dow if you wanted.A must see' when visiting Dubai.

Dubai Creek. Well worth a days trip to see the Souk and the Marina, there is a cultural centre nearby. Lots of places to eat with water views. Take the water taxi across the Creek and visit the gold and spice souks.

Beautiful...... The naturally made partition b/w Dera and Bur Dubai is magnificent And best place to click pichas. Romantic walk by the side is what I enjoyed the most. More beautiful during the knight time when there are cruises moving around.

A link to the past. Taking a boat ride across the Dubai Creek was good fun. In the middle of this amazing metropolis you get a taste of the past as you crowd on to small boats and cross the creek to get to the souks. The kids loved it...and so did the adults!

Lovely place to stroll. The creek is a beautiful place to take a stroll in the evening. Just get your camera along and click away as there are beautiful skyscrapers, abras and other things all around. Most people go for a dinner cruise too or you can use an Abra to get across the creek (but I think this is only during the day, not too sure).
Excellent quality buffet at a reasonable price. With an excellent buffet & as much wine or beer you can drink for Dhs190.00 this really is outstanding value.
A must for tourists. The creek is the central place of old Dubai. Watch the Dhows and use water taxis (Abras) to cross the creek.

Abra. Get the abra across to Diera for a wonderful experience. We travelled in the evening and saw a spectacle of lights. Well worth the cost of 1 dhs per person each way. This transport operates 24 hours a day.

Nice Dinner Cruise. We took a Dhow dinner cruise on the Dubai Creek and enjoyed the dinner, show, and scenery. We drove ourselves and took the tunnel over to the Diera side of the creek. Two words: Big Mistake! Traffic was a royal pain. It took us almost an hour and 15 minutes for about a 4 mile drive. I don't know if the bridge is any better, but be forewarned that traffic in this area is a zoo in the evening.
unforgettable dinner. take the dhow, enjoy your dinner & enjoy the sight seeing of many parts of Dubai with the background of soft music
dhow cruise at dubai creek. we had a very special bonding dinner with our mother during the cruise. the site of dubai is astounding. the waters are emerald green and gave us a very relaxing mood
love it. I love wandering around the general Creek area, it's a lovely place with a great atmosphere. a boat ride is always very enjoyable too

Its a Creek and there are like, loads of boats and stuff.. AED1 to go on an Abra!!! Lordy thats good value right there. The flocks birds follow you on the boat and it gets a bit Alfred Hitchcock sometimes. Dont feed them, they might poop on your head.Its great to see a bit of "proper" dubai and feels completely different to new Dubai.Go, have fun, have a wander but stay away from the Shwarmas Tasty they may be, but they are no doubt riddled with all sorts of stuff.

Excellent experience with cruise in the night. I took a cruise in the night along with my family in Dubai Creek for two hours. The cruise included dinner, dance shows and a magic show. It was a great experience on top deck of the cruise and sailing in the creek with Dubai lit buildings on both sides of the creek. The buffet dinner was good with a good variety. The dance was enjoyable. Price was reasonable.

DUBAI CITY UAE. Dubai is a cosmopolitan metropolis which has grown steadily to become a global city, a business and cultural hub of the middle east - once a pearling and oil industry. Today Dubai has attracted world attention. It's even harder to believe that it went through the Great Depression in the 1930s due to collapse of its pearling industry and many local people starved or emigrated to other parts of the middle east. Things to do and see: Dubai Museum in Jumeirah district is well worth a visit if you want to know how far the emirates history goes back to; Burj al Khalifa the tallest skyscraper in the world; Burj al Arab, a 7 star hotel and Jumeirah beach nearby; Dubailand and the Miracle Garden which opened earlier this year; the man made islands such as the Palms and the Globe can only be seen from space and the new hotel Atlantis; Dubai Mall the largest in the world, where one can shop in designer shops and eat international food under one roof and all at duty free prices; the Gold souk and the Spice souk in the Deira district of al Bastakiya; there is also a hop on hop off double dekker routemaster sightseeing bus - you can buy the ticket(s) from your hotel or from travel agent; the overground metro (mickymouse train similar to the London Docklands Railway), local bus or taxi are reasonably priced; Jeep or Camel Safari followed by dinner and entertainment in the desert. Dont forget to cross over to Bur Dubai (old Dubai) for one dirham on the old fashioned wooden boat not dissimilar from the Dhow on the river Nile. Bur Dubai is where the early immigrants came to work or open small businesses. Spend a day here to experience what it must have felt like to live a hundred years ago; check out the old houses and mosques; eat snacks and drink coffee in one of many small cafes or backstreet restaurants; shop in the covered market for pashminas, cushion covers, arab head dresses, kaftans, arts and crafts jewellery; drink fresh coconut water from the street vendor; buy spices and nuts from the old type supermarkets or perfume oils tobacco and saffron from the specialist shops and much more, before returning to your hotel in Deira Creek. Although a muslim state with international languages spoken, alcohol is only served in hotels, restaurants and clubs; dress modestly and don't forget to practice etiquette before going to Dubai.

colourful and full of characters. I was staying in Deira and enjoyed a few walks along the Wharf and Creek areas. Full of colour from the cargo filled boats and lots of characers. The boat workers were more than happy to pose for photo's - with a few trying out some entertaining poses. This is still a working part of old Dubai and not just a tourist trap area. Jump an Abra or water taxi along the creek for a better look - cheap and good way to see more.

Immerse Yourself. There is no better place than Dubai Creek and the neighborhoods on either side of the abra launches to wander and to take in the flavor of Dubai. The Bastakiya Quarter near the Dubai Museum has great textile vendors; the gold and spice souks on the opposite bank overload the senses. However, take the time to walk the alleys and narrow streets beyond the landmark souks to take in a global perspective. Just as it is in most of the world, products are imported from Asia. You'll see China, the Philippines, Thailand and other countries as the source of goods on containers sitting outside the local shops, ready to be unpacked. There are shops owned by ethnic Chinese merchants (with Chinese characters on the signs over their shops), including a tailor shop. The streets have an ambiance and flavor so different from the glitzy malls, and they are safe to walk. Immerse yourself. Don't fear getting lost. The districts have large maps posted in English and Arabic (on opposite sides). Take the time to learn about the mounds of spices on display and for sale. The merchants are friendly and helpful. And the abra crossing is a bargain at one dirham.
nice scenery. its a very lovely very nice place,you can relax there,viewing creek you can feel good,you can relieved,you can take good photos there

Best Place for Kite Flying. Before 3 years back Our Kite Flying Group invited by local event company to participate in Dubai Kite Festival, its was very nice place for Kite Flying, every year 14th January next Friday all Indian Kite Flying Lovers enjoying Kite Flying at Creek Park, Nice Wind, Good Place to visit.....
Nice. I appreciated the Creek experience in combination with the souk. Authentic. Makes me feel for a change not being in Disney World Middle East.

Basic creek. The creek is moderately ok, but I am not sure whether the water is dirty or it seems to be like that.Currently, there is minimal activity surrounding the creek, but new settings have been taking place since the beginning of 2013. I expect the location to flourish in a few years
Must ride on an Abra!. We experienced a short ride on an Abra which is a boat made from wood. It is the local ferry in Dubai. Our ride was short but an enjoyable experience with the local people.

The real Dubai. This is where anyone visiting Dubai for a short visit in transit or on a holiday, should come and enjoy. This is where you get a feel for the Middle East, watching the old dhows, laden with goods, going along the water. Visiting the Souks nearby and the carefully and most interesting reconstructed museum Village along the creek!
Pleasant water ride in the mid of Dubai. It was nice to know how a small creek happens to be resource for livelihood for such beautiful land of infrastructures.

"Dubai Heritage". "Recommend one of my friend, I visit dubai creek to see the heritage of dubai. Nice ambiance during the afternoon time and ride abra (Boat ) just cost you only 1,5 DHS. Look for the sisha shop near the creak to spend the time. So many shop around offering gift with reasonable price compare with mall.
Water, water, and more water in the desert.. The Dubai Creek developments are some of the top shopping spots in Dubai. The Gold Souk and the many fine shops along the waterways are a delight.
Loved the abra rides.. When visiting the souks make sure you catch the abra from the gold souk to the textile souk on the other side of the creek - lots of fun and very authentic.
water taxi. For one Derham take the water taxi. I started a conversation with people both times and both were very pleasent

deira creek. the abras are a great way to cross the creek. very cheap at 1 dirham. you can catch an abra direct to the gold souk from the bur dubai side of deira creek. water busses also travel up and down the creek which are slightly more expensive than the abras

Interesting to see the historic areas. The preserved parts of Old Dubai are fun, just wander about, you will not know what is around the next corner.
Try spending 1AED to cross the Creek on a local water taxi, well worth it

Dubai Creek with the Gold Souk only minutes away.. A must visit for every visitor to Dubai. Experience the water front with all its daily activity and boats shipping every kind of cargo possible! Take a trip across the Creek on an Abra for 1 Dirham and experience all the sights and sounds of this fascinating City. Then enter the Gold Souk if you dare where hundreds of jewellery shops with window displays that will take your breath away, there is so much gold on display to dazzle you. A purchase is essential and you will need to have a sharp mind to barter for a good price; however that is expected and adds to the fun.
The most beautiful walk way. Dubai Creek splits the city from Deira Dubai to Bur Dubai. On both sides there are walkways which you can walk and enjoy the view.

Using the water bus. We took the water bus over from Bastakya side to Baniyas on the other side.
You can use the same Nol card (for metro) and it has seats and more safe than the Abra. This one way ticket costs about 4 AED.
Good views of the creek..

Experience Old Dubai & UAE Heritage. A must visit during the evenings possibly. Close to Dubai Museum. A very different feel of old rich heritage including an old Souk, Abra water rides (really cheap & enjoyable). Can be accessed from Bur Dubai side or Deira side. Was a pleasant evening trip with family.
Hustle and bustle. Good to see the true Dubai with ships trading along the creek. Good value for crossing to the Gold souk

Very enjoyable.. We went on a boat on the creek as part of the red bus trips around the city. It was very relaxing and most enjoyable seeing a different part of Dubai. The food on the boat was very nice.

The Only Way to See the Old Dubai.. I remember when I was first in Dubai in 1979! and yes the only thing that has not really changed too much is the Creek. Its just wonderful. The Souks, cafe's and general buzz about the place. Not to mention the busy Abras dashing from one station to another. This is a must do when visiting Dubai.
Dinner on the Creek. The evening boat cruise - Dhow Cruise - having dinner out on the creek is well recommended - the wonderful Dubai skyline at night is a sight to behold.
Interesting but dirty. You can see both old and modern Dubai city. Cheep access between Old Souk, Spice Souk and Gold Souk.

to see and cross. it's nice to make a trip there!
there are also nice reataurants and caffees near by.
you can plan your journey or just go and have a tour.
the chance to have a look at Dubai from abras is unpayable!
it doesn't cost mucha and you can cross the creek
Dhow cruise. Worth to spend an hour cruising along the old Dubai. Nice views on the banks and mouth of the creek.

More Traditional Area. Taking a taxi to the Dubai Creek was worth the short drive from the city center. I finally felt like I was in the Middle East. The creek provides you with the feel of culture, traditions, and shopping. I recommend a Dhow boat ride down the creek! Souk shopping is in the area and made me feel like I was transported back in time. I also recommend having a bite to eat by the creek to watch the water taxi's having their busy day.
The real Dubai. Walking around the souks (markets) in the area is wonderful as is getting one of the abras (boats). AED 120 for a 1 hour boat trip up the creek is well worth the money as well.

Great Old Creek. We enjoyed exploring the city on our own. We walked along the creek from Ras station and continued towards Baniyas Street. It offers very nice views of the creek and the boats loading and unloading merchandises. i suppose that was how it was during the old and forgotten era when trade was dominated by these sturdy wooden boats. there are abra stations along the creek to go to meena souk. while walking we we stopped at spice souk, a strip along the creek where we bought souvenir spice pack. the shops are reminiscent of the old says. when we reached to baniyas area there are many clothes shops and souvenir shops and good restaurants. inside rolex towers we ate buffet style in one of the restaurants with an elevated creek view. enjoyed it!

Bustling creek. Loved the morning we spent down on the creek. Bustling, lively, entertaining. Cargo being unloaded from India spilled off boats onto the side walk. We took a walk to the second local water taxi point and passed many boats stacked with precariously balanced loads. For someone who enjoys taking photographs was in my element. Water taxi (slightly longer trip from the second port) was well worth the 1D. Great view from the creek especially atmospheric with the call to prayer booming out across the water.

Peaceful and relaxing. The creek is best experienced from one of the restaurants, over tea. Its is busy and relaxing at the same time. In an otherwise very hectic Dubai, it is relaxing to watch boats sailing by and to people watch. I found sunset to be the best time.

Fantastic sunset in Dubai. The last trip of the day on a wooden Dahl, a cool breeze and fantastic sunset, gave an overall view of the Creek and reflections from the setting sun in the mirrored building surrounding the Creek.

A good way to see old & new Dubai. Went on a short tour of the Creek during the day and then took a boat in the evening for a meal. From the water it is very impressive how the new & old Dubai are merged.

Excellent way to see the old and the new. Dhow Boat Cruise is an excellent way to see Dubia from the creek. The talk on the boat, was very informative, and the hour or two that it took was good way to hide from the sun and enjoy a ice cream, a drink and even local cuisine. We did this tour as part of the big bus tour 24 hour ticket, it was well worth the money.

Great views and so cheap. As we stayed so close this became a favourite trip for my wife and I. Despite their rickety appearance the abra boats provide a fun and very cheap way to see the creek. A single trip costs 1 dirham (0.20gbp). Pay your fare to the boat man and you'll be sitting with 19 other passengers - mainly locals and some tourists along the side of the boat taking in the splendid views of the creek. They have two fixed routes but are an excellent way to see the creek.
2 worlds. take a water taxi from the museum/meena bazaar side to the spice market - that's when you really feel you are in arabia !

Nice way to spend a night.... Took a Dhow trip along the creek and it was a very pleasant way to spend a couple of hours.
Would highly recommend it!

A must. We went for a cruise on the creek which we really enjoyed. Sitting down and relaxing taking in the scenary of old Dubai and new dubai. The man who was driving our boat was very helpful in telling us what all the different buildings were. We found this experience very relaxing

Dubai Visit. We did this on our stop over to the UK where we stayed for one night to break up the trip. We did a half day tour and got to walk along the foreshores and even came back later in the evening and did a river cruise.
Nice "old" part or dubai. Nice to take a boat over the water to the other side for only 1 dirham . At night very nice with all the lights.

Fascinating to watch life pass by. Take a water taxi trip across the creek which is only 1 dirham each way. The creek is very busy with water taxis and cargo boats. See all the cargo loaded just on the pavement waiting to go on the boats and vice versa. Some of the boats you wonder how sea worthy they are but great to stroll along and watch.
Very nice. It was funny navigating on one of those small boats from one side to the other. No problem to find one to get into the souk's districts and for a few AEDs...

Old Dubai. In a city like Dubai, finding something like the creek and the Abras on it is a real treat. Fascinating glimpse of what Dubai was like before the glitz and glamour. The Abras are cheap and very frequent, and lead you to the souques which are a little intense but the place to buy and haggle in Dubai
Worth the trip to the other side.. We took the water taxi over the creek, a very cheap mode of transport. An experience in itself even before we reached the other side!

Interesting one-hour trip. The Hop-on Hop-off bus ticket includes a free dhow cruise on the creek. The cruise is narrated and it provided some interesting commentary. This is not the highlight of a trip to Dubai, but for the "price" it was a pleasant diversion.

A relaxing view of Dubai. A very relax Dhow trip up and down the creek is something to experience. An public address system by the crew provides a guided explanation of the very interesting places old and new along the creek. Free drinks will be provided. The most interest thing I found about the trip and I've done it a fews time is seeing all the Dhows, which still transport good around the Gulf countries and also to India. Would recommend this trip. The Dhow night cruises with dinner should also be experienced.
Very good place. It's a very good park overlooking the creek, it may get better if there is some restaurants that offer good food instead of getting it from outside.
A mix of old and new.... We loved the views here, the old transport ships and the millionaire dollar yachts are a real contrast.. A great place for a walk and bring the camera..
nice ambience. liked the boat ride across the creek - so cheap and the little souks at the other end. this felt to be the more authentic part of Dubai
Fun boat ride at night. Take a ride across the Dubai Creek on one of the boats for 30 cents. Catch a breeze and enjoy the city night scape. Highly recommended.
Great course. Played 18 holes and the seen was unbelievable. The fairways were in great shape and the greens were awesome. Wish my game was the same though LOL. Staff was very professional.
Very pleasant. Do a Dhow cruise down the creek ... with a meal onboard - lots of Groupon offer for these cruise (groupon UAE) - Register and get the deals

Wonderful blend of modern and old history, stunning views of creek especially at dusk!. Essential visit for those going to Dubai. Beautiful during the day and at dusk, seeing abras and dhows lit up like stars and jewels sailing down the creek to the sea.

Very nice at night. We used the boats from Dubai Gold/Spice souk to Bur Dubai.
We wondered about and then took an other boat to Radisson Blue for a nice dinner and a drink.
It was a great night!
Old Dubai spirit. Spirit of Dubai history, but you can for it only between November to March, out of this months it gonna be too hot, you can cross the creek by Abra for only 2 dirhams

Too much Dhows and seems outdated.. Now with Marina and palm developed, the cruise around the Dubai creek is not bad but its like any other city, the cruises are in bunches and you hear noises from every dhows crossing you, good for a large family but for solo, duo, not so much fun..

The real Dubai. A walk along the creekside lets you see the 2 sides of Dubai at once, on the waterfront is the original authentic "working" Dubai, and on the city side, some of the new Hotels alongside some of the old souks.
Well worth a visit - the old gold Souk, and the spice Souk also.

So clean. An enjoyable trip. Make sure you get the price per person, we we're told the boat trip was 120 dirham, so 60 per head for the two of us, however another three people came on, and he tried to charge both parties 120!

Included on the red line of the big bus company. You get a one hour sailing, from the house of commerce and the national bank to the old suq and dubai museum and heritage village it is a very pleasent tour

Nice trip arranged by the bus tour. We had an hour long journey on this boat and saw Dubai from the creek this was informative and really beautiful. You may sit at the top or bottom of the boat and the commentary is quite informative really worthwhile doing do it through the big bus company.

Nice walk when the weather is nice. This is one of the pleasures in Dubai, but unfortunately can really be enjoyed only half the year when the weather is nice (approximately from late October to early May). It's nice to just walk around and see the dhows being loaded as they have been for ages with all sorts of merchandise. Then you look around at the modern Dubai Creekside and it's just simply impressing.
Take an Abra for one diram. For only one diram you can sail across the creek and get a lovely view of the Grand Mosque. Very 'atmospheric' at night.

Visiting Dubai with my daughter. The Creek is were it all happens and where the history is. This is the place to go shopping for fragrant spices, pashmina's, home made shoes and other traditional goods. There is a really mixture of local people and flavours to enjoy.

Quaint old world charm. Go visit this place in the evening, dusk time. Spend some time watching the 'abras' glide by and the evening lights come on. In the background you will hear the prayers come on, while the sun goes down amidst the beautifully designed mosque towers.

History Show. When you walk around the creek you will be in the way back in the history. Wonderful and colourful shops, interesting buildings, business dealings of locals. Eat traditional food, drink fresh coconut juice and take a boat tour at the end of the day when weather starts to get cooler.

Take a boat. Been there to the Heritage Village which is worth a visit by itself (a metro station is nearby, it is also easy by car).I waited on the quay for a taxi-boat, took it from the Heritage Village to the other side of the creek (about 15 minutes trip), Paid 60 dirhams, boat driver wanted more, I thought it was already a rip-off. There a relots of wooden boats loading and offloading goods on the quays, it is interesting to watch, had lunch in an Iranian restaurant (Teheran Restaurant near Carlton Hotel) which was excellent.

Cruise on Dhow with Dinner. Our group took a day time cruise on a dhow, traditional pearl diving boats, across the bay to the Spice Market. It was interesting to see the boats lined up in the port bringing in all kinds of goods to DUBAI. The Spice Market was not as big as that in Istanbul, but was very interesting and fun. Later in the evening we had dinner on one of the dhow boats that are dining establishments. It was an evening of authentic Emeriti food along with wonderful desserts! Even got a henna tattoo as a memento.

worth doing. We took a tour on one of the bigger boats which had an english speaking guide explaining what each building was and general information. It was a nice hour trip showing old and new dubai and refreshing from heat with a breeze. Worth doing if you have time.

Quaint transport between two areas. Contemporary buildings linked by age old boats. Opportunity to see trading boats that carry goods in the area - not huge ocean liners, but older and smaller transports. Easy to commute and wonderful to experience.

good side of traditional dubai. visit old side from Dubai and Cornish bestikyah area with resturants and souqs there old houses there and Dubai libery also shaik mohammed family home you can enjoy there by visit old village I forgot the name of it I think its village or some think like that but its inside greek side but its near albastikeah you can see how old life in Dubai city wasyou should try it
Really interesting!. Took a ferry across the creek to the souks. Strange little boat! Very interesting ships, sounds and colours!

Its a free experience.. First of all its free so of course its a great value for you money. Very interesting to see how the life was before the oil. They have many gold and spice souks along the way that you can do your shopping at. Also many high-end and authentic restaurants that you can choose from.

Dine and cruise.. We did an evening cruise on the Dubai Creek, and had a very pleasant meal on board as well. It was a very pleasant, slow cruise. Many of the buildings are flood-lit and the lights look beautiful, reflecting in the water. Also, other boats doing similar cruises up and down the Creek were lit up with strings of colored lights, and looked really beautiful.

tranquill. just a place to visit sit eat and drink you can find the quite parts or watch some great concerts I have a watercolour on my wall of this place and get very home sick every time i look at it

Fascinating area at the heart of 'old Dubai'. If you want to understand how Dubai was until the last 20 years, then you need to visit the Creek - both Deira and Bur Dubai. This is where the souks are, the heritage houses and museums and the Dhow wharves from which goods are shipped in traditional wooden boats up and down the Indian Ocean. Crossing the Creek in an Abra is a very enjoyable and extremely cheap experience as well as the quickest way to go. Take time in the cooler months to explore and enjoy.

Excellent boat trip down the creek. This was part of the Hop on Hop off bus trip in Dubai. What an experience. The views are stunning, great photo oppertunities. I would recommend this boat trip down the creek. Sit on the top level for great views.

Spent wonderful moments. Dubai creek is separating the Old Dubai and New Dubai, where you can cross the creek in a wooden boat for just 1AED, book for a Dinner on the Dhow cruise, which cruises along the creek to give a glimpse of the city from inside.

Well worth it!. Catch a 1 AED ferry across the Creek. Enjoy a shwarma on one side and then steam across to the other side to enjoy the fabric and spice souqs. Great photo ops at sunset. Totally recommend
Very Good for a walk. Just an amazing place if you and your loved one wants to go for a romantic walk. this place was near to my apartments and just loved a walk there.
Interesting place :). Old fashioned boats are moored here doing loading and unloading of cargoes. One may observed the activities in the cooler morning or evening hours.

celebration on board. we had a birthday celebration on board and it was great .tables where all set out lovelly with table cloths and candles.food was very good.we sailed up and down the creek with night falling.truly amazing.
Take an abra. Take an abra ride up and down the creek to see the sights along the waterway at dusk. Hear the call to prayers as you a floating along the waters and enjoying the local scene.
lovely spot. had a dhow trip along the creek unusual to see all the goods on the promanade waiting to be shipped out from cars to televisions
Brilliant. A must see. If you are in dubai you must travel on an abra. Even in mid summer breeze keeps temp down.
nice place. Nice place, more arabic culture, with good food and shopping, very nice at night with all the nice lights..sheep things to buy,,

Kind of average. We were staying at the Sheraton on Bank Street and decided to do a walking tour (round trip) through the bazaars on the south end of Dubai, alongside the creek with a stop at a touristy "historical" place, the fort itself, and through the underwater walkway to cross the creek. On the other side is the gold souk which was very interesting. Then we took a boat to get back to the other side (very inexpensive). Was a very long walk. The creek itself is underwhelming but you can get a better sense of Dubai walking through the souks. We deliberately avoided the (kitschy) dinner/dance special boat trips on the creek.

Like Venice .... The new and the old together ... very nice.
The Abra is a must.
I didn't like the Deira side, but loved the Textile Souk.

Old romance meets modern chic.. I have travelled across Dubai creek by these romantic little Abra's for the past 23 years, and it seems to me that they have not changed at all but the surroundings have undergone dramatic changes! The abra's are a throw back to a bygone era whereas Dubai has launched itself to the forefront of modernity.

dinner cruise. had an amazing evening trip on a dhow, food was super, help yourself to as much as you like,and the entertainment was good . we were picked up at our hotal and taken back after.alltogather a memorable evening

Just love the history and atmosphere of Dubai Creek.. I just love Dubai Creek. Up towards the mouth of the creek is old Dubai - the old spice and gold souks on one side, Bur Dubai and clothing/fabric souks on the other, lots of little eateries/refreshment stalls everywhere, very atmospheric, and the old wooden abras ferrying all mankind across and about their business. Further down, the creek is lined with the modern glass skyscrapers Dubai has become famous for, and parks, and along the creek there are the decorative and colourful old wooden dhows loading and unloading their goods for trading around the Gulf and on to India, Africa and beyond - always interesting to see what's being loaded that day (they all seem to be loading the same stuff at the same time) which can be anything from pasta to beds to second hand cars, loaded precariously one on top of the other. Beyond the dhows you'll see some very smart leisure craft moored up, including the Sheikh's yacht. On the other side of the creek are all the old dinner-cruise dhows of all shapes and sizes. Fascinating to see the contrasts and juxtaposition of the old and the new, I can so easily pass the whole day in the creek area, simply soaking up the atmosphere and the international melting-pot that is Dubai. The best way to cross from Bur Dubai to the Deira souk area is by abra - everyone uses them, and costs only 1dirham, see the sights with a breeze on your face, although the smell of the diesel can be a bit overpowering, though it only take a few minutes, so is bearable, and the water is very clear. The best way to see the whole creek is to take an abra for yourself & guests - 120 dirhams (approx £21/$35) for the length of the creek and back, takes about an hour - just have a word with the abra drivers at the abra pier to arrange, no booking required. A wonderful day.
Old Dubai. Liked this area a lot. Would have liked to spend more time here but our time was limited. Took a trip across the creek in an Abra and couldn't believe how cheap it was.

Definitely worth a trip. From Bur Dubai Souk board an Abra to Diera - this will cost around 10p (absolute bargain) - it will take about 5minutes to get across on the beautiful traditional boats. I would recommend to get a boat around 8am to have a full morning to explore Diera before it gets too hot! The Dhow boats that line the creek are absolutely beautiful. Take some time out to walk up and down the creek to see the detail of painting that has gone into these boats.

Nice river transport. We used this creek on a guided tour of Dubai in may 2012. Great ride on a Dhow to get to the the gold and spice souks, not much to see in the spice souk but a lot to see in the very hot gold souk.

Mere Creek - nothing special. It is a mere creek. Nothing spectacular. While it is widely used for transportation of cargos and human beings, it is also used in the night for the leisure vessels on which dinner is served. While it is highlighted as a must for visitors visiting Dubai, neither the meal nor the amenities available on these vessels is great. Worse, due to night falling, one can hardly admire the passing sights. Sadly, there is no background voice identifying the buildings one is passing by.

Good day out. Makes for a good day out. Hiring a private Dhow is very cheap and will take you up and down the creek. Some great photo opportunities and not too long for the kids. Spice and gold souks are near by and there is a lovely art cafe near the museum ( which is also worth a visit).

First and last visit to Dubai. Yes, this is very damning, and to be fair we arrived mid-summer and it was Ramadan.We left Rome on a hot, but bearable 33C day to arrive in Dubai where it was 44C and unbearable. The saving grace was the ability to check straight into our air conditioned hotel. However, the hotel was awful and in dire need of a major modernisation and upgrade. It bore no resemblance to the pictures on their internet site or their brochures. The staff were laughable to adequate. A kind of Arabic Fawlty Towers!Our timing was poor as it was Ramadan and absolutely no food or drinks (not even bottled water) allowed in public between sunrise and sunset. This meant either staying in the hotel or sneaking a drink on the bus tour we had organised.The tour through the various Dubai Creek attractions (the souk etc) was just too hot to enjoy. Discomfort on steroids! Get me back to my (very bad) hotel!!! I was unimpressed by the brash glitz of the Dubai generally. Super modern, ridiculously high buildings of steel and glass stand cheek by jowl with primitive basic structures clinging to the seaside on the edge of a hot, dusty desert. No doubt it's a wonderful place for the shallow, flashy rich and those who would pretend to be - but not for me. Next trip to Europe from Australia will be via south East Asia. I have absolutely no desire to return to Dubai.

our first visit to dubai. My wife and I walked from our hotel to Dubai creek and hopped on a Abra the traditional boats the the locals use every day to get from one side to the other it also can get you to the gold and spice souks the abra ride only costs 1 dirham and takes about 10 minites for the trip but you float past all of the working vessels the travel up and down the creek and around the gulf for trade just a relaxing way to travel
noting much to see. the souk are super commercial. Wach out for quality. For good quality the price is the same in all stores. The rest is not realy intresting

Dubai Creek. What an affordable way to get from one side of the Creek to the other! AED 1 for the ride acroos in a water taxi, obviously run by small entrepreneurs! Great way to support the locals! We loved exploring the "Souks" on either side of the Creek - where you can buy anything at all - don't forget to bargain! Also plenty taxis available on the shore-line to take you back to your hotel or your next stop!

Exploit Dubai Creek. A must - take an abra (traditional water taxi) across the creek for 1 dirham (!) and alight on the southern/western shore. Wander around the neighbourhood around the Al Ghubaiba bus station at sunset and watch the locals hanging out in the cooler air. Or go any time of day and visit the Dubai museum. It's lovely to see a part of Dubai that isn't brand spanking new and life feels a little more 'authentic'.

Cruising the Creek. Lucky enough to join up with 2 other girls who had hired an outboard boat for a trip around the creek, It was a good opportunity to see the city from a different perspective.Breeze on the face was a relief from the heat!

Transported back 100 years!. This was the highlight of my visit to Dubai. Old wooden dhows being unloaded and loaded by hand along the Creek. Washing machines, tyres, food, floor, rice. The container port is elsewhere in Dubai but these boats would have been doing the same job 100 years ago. Marvelous to see
Love it!. We always visit this area when we go to Dubai. Lovely, relaxing area. Hope to visit again soon.love the boat rides across the creek.

Pushy hawkers are very intrusive. It feels as if all the touts from Karama have decamped to the textile souq. What used to be a laid back opportunity to buy fabulous silk is now like running the gauntlet of Eqyptian salesmen in the Valley of the Kings

This is the experience you MUST not lose. Dubai Creek is the place you can enjoy during evenings no matter whether you are looking for old side of Dubai or the new one. Enjoy having a Night Time Walk while you can breath in away from the crowd!

Very interesting. The creek is interesting either at night or during the day, we did the Fine Dining Cruise and it was fantastic, plenty of lovely food drink and good views of the creek in this all glass boat.
Nice but Hot. Try going during the cooler months if you are taking one of the wood boats down the creek or you will be HOT. It is an interesting way to see Dubai

Ride an abra for 1 dirham.. Don't pay for the tourist rides along creek - join the locals - much more fun - nice breeze - maybe cool or hot though depending on season. Delightful views of the new and the old - good photo opportunities.

Don't be afraid to sample the old Dubai!!!. Really lovely area. Cheap as chips ride on the Creek (1dirhum) was lovely even if I was the only woman on the boat. Really interesting and great cheap food and drinks!!!

Boat Ride on the Creek. We took a one-hour dhow boat ride along the Dubai Creek. The trip had commentary that told about the different things we were seeing along the way. It was nice to have a different perspective of old Dubai and learn about some of the history.

Very local. Catch the ABRA water taxi's for 1 AED. We were the only tourists on our boat, so we got more of a real feel for how some of the residents travel. Interesting to wander around the sides of the creeks and explore the markets and little shops. Lots of bartering and few posted prices.

Dubai Creek on Dhow Cruise. We enjoyed sailing in the Dubai Creek in a Dhow Cruise. At night the creek looks beautiful with well lit up buildings on either side of the banks. The breeze and the wonderful weather made the ride even more memorable

Dubai Creek. You simply must ply the river called the Creek, cross on the many boats that cross this river, small fares make this an easy trip, dold and spice souk on one side sikl souk and museum on the other. the creek is in the heart of dubai, sit back and savour, its great
What an experience.. If you think modern Dubai is a bit sanitised come down here, take the small ferries across the creek and get a taste of real Dubai.
Excellent feeling .... Historically, the creek divided the city into two main sections – Deira and Bur Dubai. A saltwater creek located in Dubai, United Arab Emirates

"Truly Authentic & Original Dubai". This is a glimpse of the original Dubai starting at around the Sheraton Creek Hotel and walking along the Creek where the many Dhows of all shapes and sizes are loading up with a myriad of goods. Cars even some cut in half, washing machines, tyres, decrepit air conditioning units, paint etc in fact everything you can think off and more being loaded. how they manage to load them beggars belief even with a mobile crane. Many of the goods are old and get refurbished and the Dhows leave at night and cross mainly to Iran apparantly. Further along is the Abra station where you can cross to Bur Dubai for 1 dirham or you can negotiate the hire of the whole Abra for a tour around the Creek for a reasonable fee. Nice in the more moderate climate or at Dusk. The Dubai Museum at Bur Dubai is near the Abra Station.If you continue walking on the Sheraton Creek Hotel side you will find the Spice and Textile Souks and further along is the Gold Souk. All are well worth a visit. Nightime cruises around the Creek with dinner are also available at this location. All the workers are friendly.A real highlight of Old Dubai is memorable on our visit.

Amazing place to stay. We love being by the creek - there is so much going on! We love the little boats that take you across the creek for 20p! The river is a hive of activity day and night, the spice and gold souks are nearby and it is more of the real Dubai as oppose to the Downtown area

a must if youre here for the first time, even the second ;-). Ship from souq to souq - for about 20ct./ride.theres a lot see, smell and taste. you feel like trown in a old movie, talk to the friendly arabs, indians and pakistani fellas and recive a respectful handshake + smile!The area of "Bur Dubai" is also kinda the oldcity... Dubai Golfclub around the corner, floating bridge is close and you casn basicly walk around with no need having a car.

a peoplewatchers paradise. we walked along the full length one evening and into the early night... cargos were being loaded and unloaded by hand on wooden indian ships... tyres, fridges, blankets, food stuffs were coming and going at breakneck speed.... how we enjoyed watching it all.....where was it going or coming from....make the effort if you can.. the gold suke is close by but thats only as a marker on a map... it does not compare to the richness of the creek..... especially in human terms...

Worth the trip. Although the is off the beaten path (compared to the modern part of Dubai) it is worth going especially if you take one of the boats to cross the creek (not the cruises) and if you have a bite to eat at one of the local restaurants.

Moonlight cruise on the creek. For a wonderful experience on Dubai Creek you should take a dhow dinner cruise. The food is wonderful, the service excellent and the most relaxing way of enjoying the night lights. Yet another must-do in Dubai. Most impressing.

So relaxing in a busy diverse city. Just to walk along the creek one side and then take the little boat to the other and experience a different Dubai is a real treat. Late in the evening is a great time as it is buzzing and you get a feel for the real Dubai..
romantic journey. amzing when with a girlfriend or wife .boat ride was amazing down the creek and then dinner buffet was a 1st class experience for me

Great experience. We went to Ravi's and then onto Dubai Creek, this is were the souks are. The gold souk was great, shop upon shop of gold. This place was buzzing, a big contrast to downtown Dudai. This was the old town and more down to earth. Great experience.

Great place to explore Dubai. It's fun to walk along the creek and check out the dhows, souks and just people-watch. The views are nice and you can find places to eat, take an abra ride to the other side, or just enjoy the view.
Go to the spice souk. Experience the very cheap and easily accessed option when crossing the creek, manned by Indian and Pakistan operators very enjoyable.

People Watching. If you love to people watch then the creek is the place to be, always facinating to see the tradies loading their floating homes - boxes as far as the eye can see - well worth a visit.

Surely this attraction is a misnomer. Question. How can a superbly maintained waterway, surrounded by billions of dollars in real estate and infrastructure, be called a 'creek'. Nope. Someone got it wrong. Creek Dubai is frenetic. However, a traveller cannot be surprised by this humble observation when one considers this location's...... location! Locals use this abra-encrusted watery transport system to access the other side. Just like a chicken that crosses the road. It wants to get to the other side! Taking an abra ride is fun, cheap and thoroughly enjoyable plus a fun way of sightseeing. Don't miss it. (PS. Hold on tight to the baby!)

Real Dubai. Really worth a visit. I love going down here in the early evening, the buzz from all the people at the Abra Station crossing over the creek is really fun to watch. Walk along the path from Old Souk Arbra Station going past the Ruler's Court. Do this towards sunset and you get some great reflections in the building opposite. There is also a slightly cooling breeze at this time.
Nice Trip with Boat. We rent a boat for my family and took 1 hour. It is really wonderful trip to see all buildings along the creak from both side Deria (old Dubai) and Bur Dubai. I am recommend it.

Hot on foot. We went for a walk in August. Big mistake! It's so hot many of the historic attractions are closed, and many of the open-air restaurants. We had to seek shelter by going to a small museum, where they nicely offered hot tea and dates. It was partly a "'cultural exchange" pitch, but the host was married to an American, and spoke perfect English.

Great Boat Ride. Went down the creek on a abra boat. The place can get very busy but it's worth the trip.Some great views of Dubai....The cost of the trip was also very cheap.We as a family will do the trip again...

Abra at last!. I had read about the abra (small local boat) experience for years, and finally we managed it. You sit on a shiny linoleum-covered bench, and you move from side to side to dodge the sun. There is not really much to look at on your tour of the Creek: some dilapidated looking fishing boats with underwear hanging on them, and different views of skyscrapers.

Hot but interesting. Did 1 hour cruise as part of the on & off bus trip tour which was a nice plus as bus tour not cheap. Another view of this amazing city from a different angle & interesting history to be learnt.
Nice boat trip. Enjoyed the night boat cruise with an ok meal. Lots of boats to see all lit up. A nice evening out. Worth a go

A different view of Dubai. One morning we hired a boat to take us 'up the Creek'! It was a lovely way to see Dubai's buildings, Royal Palace, Law Courts and a myriad of craft of all sorts. The buildings are amazing, so individual and they look so big from the ground but tiny from the Burj Khalifa! Definitely recommended.

Heart of Dubai. What can be better then hire small dingy Abra ( water taxi) and have the experience as the locals do, either cross the creek from Bur Dubai side after you visited museum towards spice souk or ride along the creek and enjoy magnificent view . Crossing the creek if you share cost just 1 Dirham ( local currency) or less then 25 American cent, if you take it exclusive just only 5.5 dollars . And if you are a group, its worth it, as Abra can take up to 20 pax a boat
What a great place to visit. There is a market just off the creek which is fantastic, the creek itself is a man made wonder. The only dislike was not enough time to enjoy

Nice walk into the past. The Creek is a nice place to walk around & see the sun setting .. walk to the old town & spice souk.. just sit by the creek & watch numerous boats gettin in wid various products ...Old town is well maintained ..

The Most romantic dinner. This is an awesome treat that dubai offers to its visitors. It is the most romantic cruise that does not give you the feeling of Sea sickness and in addition has a lavish dinner onboard.
The best sunset in Dubai. It's good for walking and spending time when the weather is good. It has children play area. It's the house for the dolphin show. Relaxing place, it has BBQ area as well.
Old Dubai and Souq. A very colourful place to visit with a walk round the (spie) souq a highlight, so colourful and such hard sellers but fun!

A brilliant way to see the "old" dubai. Well worth going to the museum around 4pm then onto and abra around sunset. view is awesome and its soo cheap. go round the gold souk and find a schwarma stand. day out for 2 was 20aed
Last authentic place ..... Love the place and surroundings. Feels authentic and cultural... museum is small but beautiful and a trip on the water is great !

The old Dubai with a contemporary look. A must see part of the Dubai. Especially the vintage motorized skiffs are very fun to ride. Good to stroll aside the creek. And it is a joy to sit in a cafeteria and drink a coconut.

Local Ferri by ABRA Boat . . . Real taste of Dubai. The sights and sounds of the Creek are really something, particularly by night. I took an Abra from the spice souk to Hindi Lane on the opposite shore and decided to go on a Gujarati dinner on one of the Dinning hall in Gold Souk. As I enjoyed the sounds of prayer in the mosques and the beautifully lit buildings. Crazy driving from the small boats adds to the attraction, with lots of beeping and some of the boats unlit, there is a drama to be viewed as its unfurls before your eyes. A great way to taste the real Dubai!

A taste of the real Dubai, but hassle, hassle, hassle.. We visited a couple of the Souks one evening and cross the Creek on one of the cheap local ferries.It certainly gives you a taste of the old Dubai, but the amount of hassle from the Souk traders completely put us off any kind of interaction with them and we didn't buy anything in the Souks, which was a shame as we agreed later it could have been a highlight.The ferry trip, was a little nervewracking, with our feet just inches from the water, but the atmosphere and sights crossing the creek at night were some of the best experiences I had in Dubai.

Creek area and souks. These ease of getting to these areas via the metro train system (see separate review) as well as the atmosphere associated with the many many small aircon'd shops in contrast to the large very commercial malls was a welcome contrast. The touts offering watches, gold, spices, clothing etc was typical "old school" market shopping. Loved it.

Atmospheric, especially by night, take an Abra or a Dinner Cruise. The sights and sounds of the Creek are really something, particularly by night. We took an Abra from the spice souk to Hindi Lane on the opposite shore and decided to go on a dinner cruise on one of the dhows as we enjoyed the sounds of prayer in the mosques and the beautifully lit buildings. Crazy driving from the small boats adds to the attraction, with lots of beeping and some of the boats unlit, there is a drama to be viewed as its unfurls before your eyes. A great way to see Dubai!

Beautiful!. I had views of the creek from my hotel (Radisson Inn Blu) and enjoyed daily looking out and seeing the creek. I also enjoyed the dhow boat cruise on the creek which was part of the 'big bus tour' package. Just fyi... if you get on the ship, you'll immediately be asked if you would like the have a sandwich or kebab and what drinks you'd prefer. Just note that this is not at all complimentary (with the big bus tour). After eating they'll come to you with the bill. The food is not at all great especially when you realize you have to pay for it. So heads up, just wait to grab something else to eat after the tour.

Go on a boat ride up the Creek. We got a taxi to the Creek and walked along the front seeing the Dhow wooden boats and the merchandise that was being put on board. Washing machines, all sorts. The heat was too much for us 45 degrees plus being English not used to it. We took lots of water with us and then boarded a Abra flat -bottomed open sided water taxi for a 30 minutes ride down the creek and back again. We had it to our selves and what a lovely breeze and great views. You can either have 30 mins or 1 hour ride. Well worth doing. We then headed to the St George Hotel for some lunch and air con before going to the spice and gold souks.

Old Dubai, a must do. Get away from all the new build and get a real taste of the Middle east by visiting the Dubai creek. Take a ride up the creek and take in the sights and sounds of the souks. A wonderful experience
Lovely food. Food was fantastic. Lovely setting with live music being played as you ate and drank. Drinks a little on the expensive side but no more than we had expected.
great place to get your spices. best place for gresh spice. I got stocked up on vanilla pods at bargain prices compared with UK.Wouldn't bother with knock-off handbags or T-shirts though.

Creek. We visited the Creek Park while there although off season the rides (cable car etc) were not open. Just a note that the last two metro stations that lists the creek park are not yet built and talking to the locals is unlikely to be built. Jump off at Health City station and catch bus C7 to the park. A breeze to do and quick without any hassle at all.
Old Dubai Feel. The only place that looks historic/traditional in Dubai, the rest being a big Disneyland/Las Vegas with 0 culture.Nice old wood dohws (traditional boats) still doing trade with Iran.

Get in on this at 5pm local - Mandatory "To-Do" in Dubai. You need to see the creek at sundown...PERIOD. **This is for hiring a water taxi of your own to take you up and down the creek, not the transfer from one side of the creek to the other.** If you do not, you will miss out on half of the aura of this place. The silhouette of the city as the sun sets and you slowly snake down the creek is priceless. Whether romantic or alone or as a family...that sunset is what transports you to another world. It might set you back 20-30 dirhams...don't haggle the boat (use official RTA operators) driver too much, no sense in fighting for best 'deal', done this 3 times already and it doesn't get old. If you are lucky and go with the flow, the captain of the boat might add in his own personal spin and give you a guided tour of sights and history (thought that is not included in price, another reason not to haggle too hard).
Rapid Transit. The water bus is a great way to see the sights and take excellent photos. It is great if you can get to the front of the boat, and just watch the world go by, sailing down the River.

nice. I visted d dubai creek wit d wonder bus n dhow dinner cruise.I love d view.took so many pictures.d creek was filled wit differnt kinds of boat,ferry,speed boats.awesome view at nite especially wit d dhow dinner cruise.I love d feel of d old dubai

Dubai creek. We took a water taxi from car park to Gold Souk across Dubai creek. We enjoyed the taxi ride and the area is one of the few "older" areas we visited. I would also recommend the Dubai museum also located in the Dubai creek area : great historic and cultural information offered.
nice but in winter. very nice place to go out but the summer humidity will prevent you from a lot of fun, i consider it as a winter place
the other side of dubai. i enjoyed the view and the feel of old dubai. the start contrast to the rest of dubai is enjoyable. it was too hot to ride the ferry, but would have loved to!
No a very interested place. May be because of hot weather or small area, I did like this place very much as it look normal and like small tongue coming from Gulf sea full of Abra and boats.
Bring the camera. This was really a pretty place and I am glad that I ended up going. You get a great view of a lot of things so take your camera.
A great place for a walk.. Both sides of the Creek have an amazing array of things to see. Wear comfortable shoes or boots and a hat and plan to take a break or two in the air-conditioning in a café.

Tradition in a changing city. A "must-do" for visitors. Hire an old wooden abra for a creek trip at dusk, walk along the dhow harbour and imagine where the amazing the voyages which the amazing selection of cargoes are taking on the traditional boats. Visit the Dubai museum to understand the transformation of the last 40 years.
Lying in the olden days. We did not like this place and we were desperately waiting for our Dhow Cruise to end. The food on the cruise was awful. I would not advice Oasis Tour providers to anyone.
Moonlight Sonata. A very pleasant evening. Fortunately the boat was airconditioned as it was unpleasantly hot even at night. The food was very good and abundant.

Average View. Another free ticket from big buss tour, I had an opportunity to have dhow cruise. It was summer and temperature was too hot. The boat itsself completed by air conditioning. But due to the very high temperature, it seems, the AC was not working properly. Scennary along the creek showing the tall buildings (the common view in Dubai). At the other side, some wooden boats were parked, expected some passenger to rent. The view is OK and there's no special things.
Calm and peaceful... enjoy evening walk..with a view..but due to the absence of natural beauty..it is just ok..I will rate it as an average..

Average experience. Unless you are used to buying top designer goods, the big shopping malls in Dubai are all very expensive. Great to visit for window shopping!So, if you want to buy goods at a more reasonable price, visit the old city of Dubai. Shop keepers are friendly and helpful. However, be aware that it's hectic there! Quality of goods is variable, so check carefully and shop around. The prices are negotiable so make sure you haggle. The main shops have credit card machines, and many will be happy to accept US dollars using the correct conversion rates too.For me, it felt like shopping in the side streets of India. You'll meet plenty of guys on the street trying to sell fake watches and handbags. Really annoying! So, the old city of Dubai didn't do it for me. The old water taxi's are a good experience and cheap (1 AED for one way crossing), giving a great view of the creek. But use them when its less busy. The gold souks are over rated and nothing special in my opinion. The shops we visited had the same gold rate as in the UK. Each shop has its own design fees, so again, haggle for discounts if you buy anything. You'll need some photo ID for big purchases (security). An average experience, but a great place to buy cheap souvenirs.
Dinner on the creek. We went for an evening dinner on the creek onboard a dhow, more like a floating indian restaurant very disappointing buffet ,booked through arabian experiences

Evening dinner cruise. We booked and evening dinner cruise on a traditional Dhow boat and we were defiantly not disappointed, we paid around 160 a.e.d per person for a 2 hour cruise down the creek and a 3 course meal.This was a lovely candle lit dinner with a wide range of food from salad and pasta to steak and chicken. we got to see Dubai creek all lit up and night time which was the perfect romantic setting for a nice relaxing evening.I would recommend this to anybody visiting Dubai.

Nice stroll. Walk along the Creek on the Bur Dubai side, from the water taxi stand near the HSBC main builfing to the park side -- long walk but nice in the afternoon; Deira side get s a bit huzzle buzazle as you ll walk through teh loading docks of the Dhaus and it mostly busy in teh evening -- but interesting as well. Get a water taxi and go for a walk around

Beautiful creek. Creek is one of my Personal Favorite place may be its just close to work place..well its best place to walk on breezy track... camel park see the creek in evening after 20:00 Dinner crusie Will start Sailing in creek wel decorated and with amazing choice of food. book a table in those cruise and enjoy the amazing international buffet imagine diiner in creek on beautiful cruise isn't it romantic you can book them by diffrent travel company or can check online..some of them also have perfomances in the cruise so the dinner is more funAl Mansour Dhow Owned By Radisson Blu Hotel Deira Creek can be good optionEnjoy the creekWelcome To Dubai

Relaxing cruise along the Dubai Creek. The dhow consisted of an upper deck and lower deck. Due to the heat we stayed on the lower deck of the ship which was enclosed and air-conditioned, many opted to go above where you could enjoy unobstructed views. During the cruise entertainers will board the craft and perform for the passengers, in our case it was a magician. He was quite good and got some of the passengers involved in his act which was hilarious for those not chosen.Overall I found the dhow cruising very pleasant, although the rest of the family thought it was a bit slow and near the end of the cruise they were definitely bored.

Reality. There you go, hop in a water taxi and get to the real side of Dubai. Or should I say where the ordinary people live. It was much more fun shopping there too. Never in my life did I buy so much at once. We walked through some residential streets too and it was nearly wrong at how super luxurious the other side of the city was living.
Nice. Looks good. Especially from Festival Promenade and the attached hotel. Business Bay crossing and Gharoud bridge make good photography.
Great. Liked its convenience and its cheap to cross to bur than by taxi.disliked the fact that they closed too early

Charming either day & night. Took two different trips on the Creek - a daytime tour which enjoyable with the tour guide's commentary to learn about the history. Later that day we went on a dinner dhow cruise and watching the Dubai shoreline go by at night was worth it - bring a good camera to capture it.

IT DOESN'T GET ANY BETTER. This is real Dubai - none of the high rise non-sense. Get there via the Metro and you have a full day and evening out. It is as good as the Hong Kong ferry getting a 1 dirham per person ride on the abra. Alternatively get the airconditioned waterbus using your metro pass. Better still, on a friday you can go all the way to Dubai Marina for 50 dirham - over an hour down the coast and around the Palm. Check the RTA website for timings. You can also get an hour on an Abra for about 100 dirhams and take up to 20 people - have a good fun haggle but look after your driver - they don't get paid the same a cruise liner captains!Dubai Creek is as good as it gets. Pungent smells, authentic and full of real people - it beats the Burj hands down

A good way of seeing some of 'old' Dubai. Take an abra (a water taxi) and explore the creek.Make sure to visit the spice souk (market) and the gold souk.You can also visit Al Fahidi Fort which is also a museum.

The "real" Dubai. A step into another world - without the 24 hours 1000 watt lightbulb. The waterfront is a delight and crossing over in one of the boats is great fun. whenever I visited Dubai, which was often, I always stayed in the historic area and loved walking around and eating in the small restaurants.

Testimony of the glorious past.. The Creek is a channel or arm of the sea which divides the city in the middle. A visit to the boardwalk bordering the Creek offers an overview of this historic region showing a mix of modern building alongside the newly restored historical buildings.The observation that rolls around there can serve as a testimony of the glorious past that Dubai has played in the region since the advent of the Islamic Umayyad and Abbasid dynasties, a time which was consolidated as a trading post for caravans crossing the Persian Gulf and the Indian Ocean.Notable is the handling of the "dhows", wooden vessels chartering goods to many neighboring countries such as Iran, India, Iraq and several African countries through its small harbor that spans much of the channel.
Bollywood Sparkle. Lama Tours dinner cruise had good food, Bollywood dancing, and a spectacular lit up Whirling Dervish dancer - great fun.
Nice little ride. Very relaxing and another look around the area. Hope on and off and go thru the markets , souks. They serve refreshments on the boats

Dubai Creek.. Dubai creek is an awesome place to go, where you find a mix of historic Dubai in midst of the present cosmopolitan city.
