Nice to take a look at Old Dubai. When you go to the Old Souks (Gold and Spice_ You must at least have alook at the creek. You can go across it on a water taxi for about 20p!

Culture. When you go to see the creek, is when you discover the origins of the city. You can cross the creek with an abra, a typical boat which costs only 1UAE Dirham.Nice views during the day, amazing at night.

Worth an hour. Ask around at the little independent boats on the creek and you can get an hour ride for about 30 Durham. Don't fall in because it's filthy but you get a good view of what's there. Once was enough for me but if you want to say you got to see it, this is a cheap and pleasant way to do that.

On the way to the spice markets. It was such a hot day when we took this trip, around 44c and 37 at midnight.Some people did not want to leave the bus.I found that it was tollerable and you could adjust if you didn't think it was a marathon. Take you time, drink plenty.Arriving by coach, we visited a couple of sites near the sheikhs residence, this is on the photo prohibited list.Keep the camera low.The creek was a fascinating place with reasonably clear water, but with quite a bit of garbage floating around. Plastic bottlesHere you will find a lot of Dows (sailing boats ) that travel to India and other places.Most of whats in Dubai come in by this way.The trip across the creek is done by motor boats, that have car engines fitted down below.Rough as rough, but suit the landscape.The trip across only takes around 10 minutes maxiumum.When you get off the motor boat , you are at the spice markets and gold markets.Tons of gold hanging in shop windows.None of the locals work in these places. most work done by Indian or pakistanis.If time was not important, I suppose you could hire one of these boats and cruise a fair way up the creek.
Smell and feel the real Dubai. Nice to visit during the day. Skyline is nice, best place is the harbor. Nice to see the traditional action and the way of loading the ships.

The creek. We visited the creek. This is something you have to experience when in Dubai. I think after staying in such a nice area of Dubai, the creek is a bit of a shock. It's very busy around the market area. The local traders more or less pounce on you the minute they see you. Lots of gold souks, so ladies, make sure your man has plenty of money !! Take a trip on the dhow boat across the creek, that's an experience in itself. It's such a contrast to the new stuff in Dubai, but definitely worth a visit. Although we did not take the creek dinner cruise we did observe this and it looked fab
Dubai Creek. A nice clean waterway that runs through the old Dubai and takes you to many places and attractions.
Boat ride on the creek. We did the boat ride and it was really interesting learning about the history of Dubai. Well worth a visit.

One of the "only" cultural things to do in Dubai. There really isn't much culture in Dubai, if you're looking for it, honestly, forget it!However, if you do crave some novelty of culture or would like to see something of old, then "the creek" and it's little ferries is it. The Creek is a small segment of old dubai, unlike the name, the Creek is more like a widened river canal. The only thing that truely makes it old is the myriad of small wooden boats that coast people back and forth for 1 dirham.It's quite an interesting little trip if you can spare an hour. There are no life jackets, now safety precations, just an old wooden boat, battered from use over time (seriously, the wood looks roten on so many of these boats, but it adds to the experience of it all)When you journey on one of these, you can't help but be charmed by how many of these littered the waterways and how seemlessly they putt along to their destination.It's quite a liberating experience and it's one of the only moments where you feel like a local (local migrant worker to be specific).One of the things you will soon realise whilst on this little journey, is simply the fact that there are no local Emirates travelling on them, just migrant workers. Overall, the ferry crossing is a lovely, relaxing cruise. It's a pleasant means of travel that'd no doubt be worth a couple of pictures.
relaxing. We had a relaxing boat ride around the creek it lasted about 1 hour.You can get food and drink on the boat the Shawrama (chicken wrap) was lovely
ferry crossing. The abra ferry boats crisscross the Creek which cuts Dubai into two...join the locals for 1 dirham or charter your own boat for 2 hours for 100dirhams...it is great.
Dubai Creek. Take a water taxi over from one side to another. Enjoy the ride.
Ferry Ride. Ferry Ride upto the 7-star Atlantis Resort. Fun way to spend time with family and freinds.

Real Dubai. If you fancy heading back in time away from the air-con and skyscrapers, hop on the metro and head for the creek. If you get off at Union, cross the road towards The Radisson and your on the creek. Take a walk and see anything from spices to washing machines being loaded onto wooden dhows. Halfway along past the Rolex towers you'll come to the first Abra station. For a dirham you can take a small wooden dhow across the creek to Bur Dubai or keep going and you will come to the gold souk, spice souk and even further along the fish souk. If you want to see real Dubai, head to the creek!

Beautiful. Old Dubai part isn't as glam as new Jumeirah but thats what i love about it..take water taxi( 1 dirham pp.) to cross to other side..especially evening..magical when town is in light,etc..few shisha smoking cafes..will not give away clues but we ended up puffing till 4am and place was still full of locals! great night,loool ;)

A re-visit. Very hot but had a cool ride on an abra at 100 dirhams (£17) I last worked as captain of a supply boat in Dubai Creek but it is dhows only now. Very interesting and I was shown a video of the history of the creek in the old port office in the souk.

A tast of Old Dubai. The closest you will get to old Dubai and one of the few areas that can be explored on foot.The Creek is bordered by Bur Dubai and Deira, the oldest parts of Dubai's built up areas. These are full of shops where you can haggle, unlike the malls. The Gold and Spice Souks are nearby.The Creek can be inexpensively toured for a couple of Dirham on the water taxis (Abras).
great area to venture and engage locals. Even if you don't buy anything, grand souk great place to talk to locals. bring lots of water and get ready to bargain.
back in time. get on a boat and enjoy the city ski line from creek. see the old boats and the original people of dubai

not much to see. there really is nothing much here... some markets set back but nothing special and dhows (boats used to ship goods) parked up.. I guess the best bit is you can get a boat across to the other side where you can find a very small "old" part of Dubai with old houses and on the water front by the market area is a great local cafe with a terrace jutting out into the water and great local food- but too hot this time of the year to be out during the day...

Raise your heart rate. Took a dow trip down the creek which was a lovely way to see other bits of Dubai. It can be quite nerve racking as you don't think there is anyway the dow will not take in water, but its actually a really nice way to see Dubai
The boat dinner is not worth it!. We took the dinner boat in June. Bad idea. The food is terrable, not much to see. Marina area maybe better?
Hot, no where to sit. Views are ok, it would be better if it was cooler, or if there were lots of shaded areas, and plenty of seating areas.

Abra kadabrah. Not bad in the cooler months, if you want to park near the British embassy and nip across the creek on a local abra, which is fun and very Arab/local - so great for tourists, the abra can take you directly to the spice soukh on the opposite side (Diera side) and it can be an interesting time to take photos and see some traditional Middle eastern culture. Would avoid this activity in the hot summer months.
ride the abbara. nice ride for the abbara there with a very very low cost .. don't miss it it is a very nice experience

Average. After paying for the famiy ticket we discovered that over half the trip had bought a groupon ticket £30 cheaper. We took the amphibion package, i think going direct to the creek and ask at the side of the creek would be better value
The Ride Across The Creek. I must stay the it is clean and my husband and I enjoyed the ride across the creek in the abra. It only cost 1 dirham per person.
The REAL Dubai. One of the first places I take visitors. catch an abra across the creek, stroll amongst the spice and gold souk. very hot at the moment so be warned!
The old and gold. The true essence of Dubai can be seen around this place, a must place to visit.

Dinner Cruise a must.. Look around for these Dinner Cruises, the charge varies from approx £45 to £125. We went on the cheaper cruise and was pleasently surprised at what we received. Picked up by car from our hotel and taken to the boat, we had a window seat in the air conditioned dining room. Dining was Buffet style with a selection of salads, hot food and desserts. Plenty of choices and enough for seconds. The cruise lasted two and a half hours and went the full length of the Creek. After dinner you were encouraged to go on the top deck and watch the other cruise boats and the shore. As stated, we were pleasently surprised and now wonder what you would have got on the expensive cruises? Once docked our car was there to return us to the hotel. A great evening.

A little sight seeing adventure gem. I went down to the old town and haggled with an Abra (ancient wooden boat) driver for an hour-long tour of the Dubai creek. I had the boat all to myself and it was a relaxing hour trip full of great photo opportunities and wonderful sights. I got a view of things you just couldn't get walking around. At the end I had the driver drop me on the other side of the creek to visit the Souk. Another excellent adventure in Dubai. Very inexpensive but haggle anyway...it's just expected and it was quite fun. Take the camera.

Abra ride is a must. Just cross the creek once or twice with the public Abras. It is interesting to see the average people in Dubai commute. Watch out for private boats that offer to carry you across, not as colorful as the Abras and way more expensive. If you liked the trip consider hiring an Abra for an hour. The creek area is a welcoming contrast to the glitzier part of the city.
worth a look. ita an experience , try crossing on the arbra.wouldnt bother with the dinner cruise as not worth thetime or money

My short visit. to Dubai Creek was at night and it was a hot one so we took a stroll around but what I saw and all that I know make it a not to miss attraction. its a slice of Dubai before the craziness hit.
Nice place in the middle of Dubai. Take a trip on the ferry bus boats it cost you only 1 Dirham and it's a really nice experience
Nothing too spectacular. There is nothing too spectacular about the Dubai Creek for me except for the Dhow Cruise.
dubai creek. Still one of my favorite places at Dubai.. the old charm and this place would any day win against all those 'malls'
Moonlight cruise. Dinner cruise on the creek was excellent. Package was available with or without alcohol.

A good walk round. We walked around Dubai Creek park (entrance Dhs 5), definately worth it and very cheap. The park is really clean and gives good views around the creek and surrounding areas, you can hire bikes etc once inside. We took a cable car ride whilst in the park which was really good and gave us a nice rest after a long day of walking. Make sure you enter the park in gates 1 or 2 as the higher numbered ones were closed when we went which meant more walking!!
This is Dubai!. The Creek is the real Dubai.Dubai grew up around the Creek and you can still sense that heritage as you watch the working dhows.A beautiful, must visit area!
More oriental than the rest of the city. You have to see it in the night time, take a little boat going from one side to the other or a night dinner cruise. The views are really amazing
An experience. Only 1 dirham to travel across the creek a must if going to dubai

Dhow dinner cruise (Rustar). We were picked up from our hotel at 7.30pm to the dhow (boat). The dinner and cruise started at 9. It was an excellent way of seeing the Dubai Creek area - lots of lights, boats, activity along the river. The plentiful buffet, a mixture of Arabic, Western and Asian food was fresh and delicious. There was also an amazing performance by an Egyptian dancer. There are many dinner cruises and I'd recommend the one we went on Rustar.
Just a Creek. It's just a creek and nothing special. We went on a dinner cruise on a wooden boat. Not much to see along the river and it just turns back.

Caught a water Taxi. Walking along the creek we spied the water taxis and hopped on. The ride took a few minutes and took us to the other side. Easy and inexpensive and a good way to cross over. A good experience and photo oppottunity for the traveller. It was also much cooler on the water and a welcome break.

Colourful. A cultural experience plenty to see and do or just take a lazy stroll along the creek bank and watch the bright lights of the floating Dhow restaurants pass by. Take a water taxi to cross the creek in the evening when it's cooler.
Beautiful place!. Dubai creek is a beautiful place to visit. Lovely views. A Dhow cruise is highly recommended!

Cruise across the Creed. We took the abra across the "creek" which is really a river. The cruise was included in the hop-on, hop-off bus tour. The tour was great and took us though the gold, spice and fabric markets. The views along the creek were great and our guide told us alot about trade and development in Dubai.

Definitely worth a visit.. The old water taxis are great - 1 dirham to cross the water - cheapest trip out on our holiday! Herb and spice market smelt wonderful. Gold market was a sight to see but no prices in shop windows so we didn't bother to go into any shops. If you are going there to buy you need to research what you are looking for so you have an idea of comparitive prices. everyone says that the diamonds are of a very superior quality and those we spoke to who had bought reckoned it was very good value.

Interesting. For the time of year we went it was too hot to stay outside too long. Water taxis were fun and cheap. The old Dubai seemed more like an Indian shopping district than an AE area. Souks were overwhelming. We headed straight back to the comfort of the air conditioned Dubai Mall.

Old Dubai. It's great to escape briefly from luxury and see the wooden dhows and souks, but it is extremely hot and tiring and a couple of hours is enough to send you back to the luxury. Taxi fare from Atlantis about 70 AED each way.

A taste of old Dubai - but not that old!. Visited Old Dubai - loved the museum it was extremely well done. The Creek was interesting - crossing was easy - but I love really old places and even old Dubai seemed to be not that old. Interesting experience but glad we stayed at Al Manzil instead of in old Dubai
Hustle and Bustle of Old Dubai. Souks, dhows and old Dubai - best go early morning as the day we went it was 46 degrees and too hot to appreciate the atmosphere and aromas!
Beautiful views at night. We had a two hours cruise in the creek at night. The views of the tall buildings were soo amazing. but the weather was not good.

Breath taking Views. Its the traditional part of dubai that found long time..Although the splendid modern city extension and prestigious sites and constructions..The night by dubai creek is not to be missed..Amazing views of dubai sky line ..and best Location to have a perfect view is a cafe bar restaurant Called the QD's by the entrance of Park Hayat Hotel

Enjoyable stroll and soak up some of the old Dubai. Dubai creek was the original Dubai where all the trade was carried out and where Dubai started.We walked during the day - madness! and even though it was scorching we did enjoy the views and thinking about old Dubai against new Dubai.There are quite a lot of things to to along the creek and one is to catch the water taxis only 1AED to pop along to the other side.You have to wait till the water taxis are full before they start driving but it's a good way to cross one side to the other.A must visit on the creek is the museum and the Sheikh Saeed Al Maktoum Home (former ruler of Dubai) and the old (renovated) souks where you can see all the spices and gold (but be very careful).Would I go back to Dubai Creek: Yes. Its free, its traditional and the original Dubai.
Creek. When you are in Dubai you have to go on a Abraarnacross the Creek from Deira to Bur Dubai. A very cheap mode of transport.

walk along the creek. Dont go during the day . It is just too hot. Go in the evening and walk along the creek. You can see all the boats , DHOWS that goes to Iran, India and yachts in another corner. It s a good walk.
An expereince. This is a great experience - ride the little boats over to the gold souk - treat yourself to some jewellery by bargaining them down in price - ladies cover up

Dubai's best attraction! See it using the inexpensive RTA boats. I wasn't expecting much, so when I got to Dubai Creek, I was blown away by this authentic and historic waterway, which is still full of life every minute of the day. It was fascinating to see the hundreds of wooden cargo ships all along the creek bank that come from nearby countries stacked full with endless varieties of goods. The public transit authority (RTA) runs boat trips on the creek and out to sea for less than half the cost of the tourist boats. See http://www.rta.ae/wpsv5/eservices/PDF_Catalog/Water-Ferry-Brochure-english.pdf for information, or Google "RTA ferry Dubai". Another terrific low-cost alternative is to hire one of the small wooden creek crossing "abra" boats for 120 AED to give you a 1-hour private ride up and down the creek.
Dubai creek. We took a bus and boat tour around the creek and surrounding areas. Learning about the creeks past and present history. Interesting
A walk through the Old dubai. Must try- the dhow cruise. explore the old dubai. Next to the creek, you have the bastakia and the gold and spice souks. Dubai is not just glitz and glamour!!!

Scary!. we asked taxi driver to drop us at Gold Souk but don't think it was where we indended to go. We ended up at lots of jewellry shops and loads of "Prada, Gucci, pashminas, Come to my shop" pestering so kept walking to get away from them and could not easily browse in shops. Never did find the indoor gold souk. We did come across the spice souk which was good and full of tourists, we were getting used to being pestered by this stage! Walked over to the creek but too hot to walk about much. Did not feel as safe in this area as at hotel or in malls however nothing to base this on as nothing happened to us. bit harder to find a taxi back. I would go back now I am more prepared as to what to expect. Keep your belongings close.
cruise on creek bad idea. the cruise thing on the creek is bad, dont do it, food is not good and they cramp u like sheeps

Amazing. It was the most exotic yet errie feeling floating down the creek,in an old open air, pillow laden boat, I felt like Queen of Sheba.. the call to prayer echoing from both sides of the creek, the red red sunset glowing in the background. Maybe one of the most moving experiences in my travels

The artery of Deira and Bur Dubai. This is real Dubai for me - not the Disneyesque plastic rocks or the pseudo-souks or operating theatre clean luxury venues. This is 200 broken fridge freezers waiting to be transported on a real ship by young economic migrants working hard towards a better life. Soak up the atmosphere here - sights, sounds and smells abound.

Another 'Dubai favourite'. If you want to get away from the glitz and glamour of modern Dubai, go to the creek to experience traditional Dubai. Park your car near the museum, and start walking through the textile souk. Lots of trinkets, clothes, pashminas, thobes, materials and treasures to be found at a bargain. Try the 'disco sandwich at the little sandwich bar at the beginning of the souk - yum yum yum; plus the freshly squeezed orange juice - can't go wrong. Keep walking under the wooden tressles until you reach the a bra/ taxi rank on the creek. Hope on a 1 dirham abra to get to the other side of the creek and alight at the ' gold souk' stop. On the opposite side of the road you will find the spice souk - enjoy the colorful array of spices presented in Heshen sacks, and smell the amazing aromas! Be friendly to the vendors and they'll be super friendly to you! At the back of the spice souk, you'll find the gold souk - lots and lots and lots of gold! Know your pries and know how to bargain! A wonderful, authentic, fresh day out
FUN!. I had a great time on a boat ride around the creek also had dinner on one of those barges...........that too was something you have to do atleast once!

Interesting experience. We took one of the little wooden boats across the creek to the Spice Souk and Gold Souks. The boats look ancient but zip around the creek like they did in the old days. I think the boats are one of the few elderly things still working in the city. They are cheap and a great way to get around and see the creek. We also had a dinner cruise on a dhow. The boats are all lit up like Christmas trees and look pretty on the water. The views are lovely at night but don't bother going for the food. It was very disappointing.
Great experience. Enjoyed walking through the souks, took a boat across the creek, visited the Dubai Museum, and ate at Bayt al Wakeel Restaurant and Cafe.
Most Interesting.. One of the most interesting places in Dubai! A 'must do' for anyone visiting.
Private ride. Take a private tour of what the locals call a creek. We call them rivers but best way to see Dubai and very inexpensive. For a private showing only 6 BD per person or 60 AED.

Average!. Did a creek dhow cruise as part of the Big Bus tour. Waited a long time for the boat to arrive and when it did, we were sent to another boat. All went and sat upstairs for a good view, but sound system wasn't working, so didn't really know what we were supposed to be looking at.
its ok, but nice for a dinner at night. ex0pensive but lovely when it hot during the day, and theres a ice breeze at night.. the lights are gorgeous

Interesting Old Heart of Dubai. The Dubai Creek is the original settling place for the people of Dubai. It is the heart of the original settlement. It is still a very busy waterway with many Dhows plying their trade between Dubai and other emirates as well as Iraq & Iran.
Real dubai. Definately go to the creek and the old, spice and gold souk if you want to see a little glimpse into the past and the real hussle and busstle of real dubai.

What a way to spend the evening !!. Please don't go alone, cz the time spent with your loved one shall be forever cherished in times to come. The best walk way to stroll with the creek front in the evening. Also, a boat ride on the creek is worth every dime. It just cost 2 Dhs.  Lot of dinning options are available along the creek and you can take a ride on the boat to dine with your family.
Non-stop action. Could stand or sit and watch the boast going back and forth all day. Really vibrant and the cheap and easy way to hop between the souks

Man Made Beauty. Its truly an amazing place very close to their old memories
saw how they lived centuries ago but they need to improve the cleanliness their especially throwing plastic bottles on the creek
Worth the visit!. Walk along in the late afternoon. ¡Not in the middle of the day, it is too hot!
Dhow cruise. Try dhow cruise, it was about 140 Dhs per person, including decent dinner :) I assume price is higher than service. Anyway it is "must-see" sight of Dubai, so Creek is nice to see

History and atmosphere. A number of interesting tourist places boarder the Creek. Would suggest taking the Metro to Al Ghubaibu station which is at one end of the Creek, and then walking along visiting the various attractions and Souks before taking a Dhow across the Creek (ferry cost about 20p), and rejoining the Metro.
very nice area. Lots of history about Dubia here. Excellent musium and a boat trip along here is a must

A wonderful way to see parts of old Dubai. My family paid 120 AED for an hour's trip on the creek in our own private boat. We got to see a lot, and particularly impressing we found the ships going to Iran with a lot of cargo. We went in late afternoon, when the temperatur was perfect and the creek busy of people going home from work. It was well worth it, and seeing the city from the creek is very different from taking the Sheikh Zayed Road :-)

Dubai's real Docklands. Dubai Creek is full of Dhows that ply their trade across the Gulf and Indian Ocean. Get an Abra across the Creek from the Bur Dubai Souk to the Deira side and then take a walk along the Dhow Wharfage area and see closeup what gets traded to and from Dubai on these traditional vessles. Recommended for a unusual perspective on Dubai and its trading roots.
This is a time warp.. Souks on one side and glass and steel skyscrapers on the other. See the old and new Dubai and be reminded this "country" only entered the 20th century in 1960!

Nice. Its good but not great. Walking distance from old souks.. Gold and spice. Do bargain....whether gold or spice. Wooden dhows docked here look good but if it gets missed amongst shopping ,dont sweat. Try abra ride to cross creek for burdubai...
The heart of Dubai. All the hubbub of Dubai centres around this waterway through the middle of Dubai
The waterboats are best. Take a shuttle boat to the old souk and barter for a wooden one back. All the sense of the old days I imagine
Old part of Dubai. experience the old part of dubai. dont forget to hop on to try the Abra (boat ferries).

Great place, great atmosphere. Great place with some really beautiful views of Dubai from the water. Be sure to take the abra to go across the creek. Lots of souks around the creek area, including the gold souk and the spice souk so be sure to explore these.
Great Contrast between old and new. I took a water taxi across the creek which was enjoyable and very cheap, worthwhile to see the contrast between old and new Dubai.

Nice place for kids to enjoy. Dolphinarium, the camel ride, Childrens park, Cycling for the whole family, monorail and the city views and a very good play park. It's simply amazing. Don't miss it if you are in Dubai with kids.
lovely. Just have a wander round, its lovely get the boat to the other side its really cheap. Also go to the souks around the creek they are great.

A great day out. A great place,for a day out,a trip across the creek,on a small wooden boat,loads of creekside restaurants, museum,Gold souk,
old town,busy way of Arab,daily work,atmosphere,great place.
If you go by Metro,do not get off at The Creek station,as it is miles from the creek,get off at Al Ghubaiba.

Love it. Great park there with bicycles you can hire. The park also contains Children's City which is a bit like an educational museum. My children liked it although it did need updating.
We love eating at the Boardwalk Restaurant which is part of the Dubai Creek Club where the Park Hyatt is.

Where the real Sinbads still are. Dubai Creek is one of the few authentic place in Dubai and I really love it for years and years now, it is my favorite place in Dubai and one of the most beautiful view if you stay in the old Sheraton or the Radisson on the Creek(formerly Intercontinental Hotel). It is not that easy to explore because of the heat now and the parking problem but it is worth making an effort because it is a bustling and extraordinary place, where the real Sinbads still are! It is one of the few harbours where you can still see the real dhows doing real trade. You will see the Indians (and other nationalities) dockers pushing hand carts in the middle of the traffic and taking the boxes of everything under the sun: fridges, TV, cooking oil, sinks, plastic items of every sort... to beautiful wood boats (some looking like ships you see only in Pirates of the Carraibeans or in Disneyland Paris Pirates grotto, it is the one I know!). On these graceful and traditional dhows are the sailors in their lunghis, T shirts and flip flops, who will cross the Arabian sea, the Indian ocean and bring their cargos I don't know really where but you just dream when you see them, you are taken to another time and age. You can walk near the boats, take some photos, but for me I never wanted to take one of these dinner cruises, I prefer to watch the real thing, not to do the touristy bit! When we use to stay at the old Intercontinental Hotel, I use to love watching the creek and the boats from the little balcony with its scruffy clump of bougainvilliers stubbornly surviving in its dry pot. Now there are more fancy hotels, but none have this delightful view.

Creek at sunset. This is a lovely area to stroll around in the evening when it's a bit cooler and it's gorgeous to take photos here when the sun is setting over the water. The short abra trip from Deira side (outside the spice market) over to Bur Dubai is fun, one of the only remaining traditional activities in Dubai I reckon. We walked through the Bastakia area and up and down the Bur Dubai side, then sat at a cafe and had a coffee and smoked shisha while watching the lights twinkle on the water, beautiful!

A gentle trip along the creek. When in Dubai take time to visit the creek where you can either hire an abra for a trip on the water or walk along the path beside. You can still see dhows offloading/loading their cargo so are transported back in time. This is the side of Dubai that few tourists visit.

Pretty nice. Nice place to be. The dhow cruises are a scam. The food is bad and the cruise is useless. They just go around in circles!
You can get on for as cheap as 75 Dhs, just wait till the empty dhow is leaving the jetty. They usually ask for 250 pp.

Worth the time to explore. It's worth getting out of the souqs and exploring the streets around the creek, depending on how hot it is! But some of the shops on the other side of the creek, opposite the Gold Souq etc, have some fabulous kitchenware and textiles. Get off the beaten path and you'll find some real bargains.
Nice scenery. Close to the Gold and Spice Markets. Also to the Dubai Museum
Busy. A place to really see the way the locals live and work. A great contrast between the local boats and the tourist boats.

Hehee. Used to love coming to the bar in this place, even on my own,
free bottles of wine ;)

A Must See. I had seen a lot written about this place and there is only one time of day to visit here. That is at night. The scale of the place is mind blowing and the restaurants are even better. We tried the Meat Co. which was excellent. Some seriously big steak on offer here

Beautiful. Your visit to Dubai is not complete without a visit to Dubai creek. All the books will tell you to take a dhow, and you definitely should. It's really inexpensive and an excellent cultural experience.

Hmmm..yeah.. Interesting. A trip across the creek in an abra was fun, and it only cost 1 AED, and the cruisers were very nice. All of the restaurant and party boats were all lit up, which was all good.amazing that such a small body of water has so much traffic on it. Really busy.

A bit like the river Thames. Nice walk from the Al maktoum bridge to sea at Deira, nice long walk then caught a taxi boat back (like a gondola with an engine) nice relaxing way to see the views...
Avoid the floating restaurants...poor service long delays and horrible food on these Boats!!
Everything is right here. Its the area you want to stay in. Close to everything no car needed.
Nice walk. Its great to walk by the creek especially before the dinner boats set off its very nice to see the boats all lit up
It's a creek ???. Don't realy know wat to say ......... I had a very pleasant time crusing the creek .... but nothing special.
The Lifeline of old Dubai. I would recommend catching an Abra, or 2, for trips up & down the creek for an inexpensive & great view of life along the creek.

Worth a visit, but......... Crossing the creek on an "abra" is great. One AED each way ! To the south of the creek is the textile souq and to the north the spice and gold souqs. These souqs are really interesting to walk through. However, be prepared for some hassle. The local shop owners will be in your face to sell stuff. If you want to buy, be prepared to barter. A good ploy is to tell them you live in the Emirates.....say you are visiting from Abu Dhabi or Al Ain. Good luck!!

Lovely view. We ate in a restaurant in a shopping mall near Dubai Creek and had a wonderful view over the manmade river. We were also lucky enough to see a firework display, which lasted over half an hour.

Loved it. For me this was one of my highlights of my trip to Dubai. Going on an abra at sunset with call for prayer reminded me of where I was. Its a world apart from the high rise and glitz and glamour thats so often associated with Dubai. So much atmosphere, wandering around the souks its easy to get lost but with no hassle from store owners its a real pleasure to stroll around and wow the gold souks are amazing!

Creek park. Creek park, Children's city are great for the kids to spend an entire day, great view of the Gold course from the park, cable car was not working when we visited. 40Dhs for family entry to the Childern's city & 5dhs per person for park entry, dolphine bay also inside the park.

An must see - the cultural heart of Dubai. A trip on the creek in an abra to see the sights in Deira and Bur Dubai is an essential part of any visit. Take in the Textile Souq, Museum and Hindu Temple then cross over the Creek to Deira and the Gold Souq - and don't forget to look at the trading dhows on the way, plus have a fresh fruit cocktail and samosa at one of the many kiosks

As tourist you either like it or not. we have accommodate a lot of friends and family from different ages and we found out you like it or not. the great thing is you can get lost here and you don't feel you are in classy/fancy Dubai anymore. hence you like it or not, but no worries always enough taxis to get out of there and it is SAFE to walk around!!!
Like the Mersey on steroids. Worth looking at it on the videos on youtube. Not worth going to see. The stink of diesel fumes and garbage will make your hair fall out.
Nice experience. Very nice to experience and seeing where old meets new. For only 1DHS it is well worth it to cross over and come back.

SoSo. Dhow tour is interesting, but too long and hot. Keep it short and sweet and focus on other points of interest. Our guide did not explain much and barely spoke english. This area is nice for taking shots of the wooden Dhows though. That made it worth while.
Great!!. If you want to dine out there are some fantastic boats for cruising and dining out.

" Dubai Creek, a must see in visiting UAE". as me & my husband were wandering around the creek one tuesday afternoon during our visit to dubai, we came across a group calling people for a boat ride.. without knowing whats in store for us, me & my husband just hopped in & payed 70 dhs each... well its all worth it! One hour ride around the creek overlooking the beautiful, architectural skyscraper. The weather is good not hot & not windy. Its the best time of the day 5-6pm..daytime & almost sunset.

Fun on a hot afternoon. We wandered down by the creek and wer offered a one hour boat ride for 100 dhs. It was probably the best money we spent. We had a lovely breeze blowing as we motored along, a shade canopy to keep the desert sun off, and a guide who pointed out the different buildings along the way. It was just my mom and I and near the end the driver let me behind the wheel for a turn!!
Wow! On a Dhow. Good fun to sail across the Creek...... Dinner can be taken on one at night. The local people use this method to go about their business.

fab dhow ride and decent views of the Creek. Good views of the creek, look out for your reflection in one of the telecommunication buildings - short and sweet ride, you must visit dubai creek cafe good views of the golf course and creek from there.
Great cruise on a dhouw. An hour worth remembering, speakers had to be turned up so we could hear the commentary. Clean and well run service.
Interesting Abra. For one dirham, you can cross the creek by water taxi- abra. One of the stations is very close to the gold souq. Noisy engine, nice view.

interesting. i would recommend that the traveller enjoys one of the numerous tours being offered by the tourist agencies on the creek. it could be quite romantic at night with dinner, music, friends on the creek

Nice historic area.. There should be more of this. Restoration of the historic or olden days areas with views and outdoor dining.
There is not enough emphasis on restoring or brining back to life the past in the UAE.
A leisurely stroll through the souk and a nice meal at one of the restaurants there was a great day out.

this is a must. When in Dubai you must go across the creek in a water taxi this costs 20p also took a taxi down the creek , this also was really worth a afternoon but be warned there is no health and safety on the boats

Very Charming. It was one of the pleasant trip. very relaxing, great view & overall an exciting experience. should visit the creek area during the evening time. so windy and very nice. Good restaurents also available on the bank of the creek.
Creek. A ride to the other side of the creek with Abra (1 Dirhem) is highly recommended.
Authentic experience. Rugged and real. A vibrant market area, busy, bustling with amazing smells, good and bad. Take an abra across the creek to the other side and back again. Walk around and enjoy.
great for a stroll. great for walking along, take a boat trip across quiet an experience should only cost the equivalent odf 20p
Creek. Went for a meal on a boat sailing up/down the creek at night. Not a bad meal, a little too fancy for me. A pleasant evening.
good place to troll. there is RTA operated boats with cheap fare and you can enjoy that boat ride, abras are the cheapest option though.
lovely but beware of safety on boat trips. we asked for life jackets and didnt get any, so make sure you can swim before goign on teh cute little boats. But the views are breathtaking

Dubai Creek a must do. The Creek is one of the places you should visit while on a holiday in Dubai. You will get a glimpse of how Dubai used to be, the dhows, the people, buildings, etc. Cross the Creek to Deira and walk around the spice souk! what an adventure, the colors, the merchandise and obviously the spices! Make sure you wear comfortable shoes and don't go there in the summer months as it will be uncomfortable as it is open and no A/C
we went on a boat ride amazing. must do if your on holiday.. the 2 hour boat cruise at night amazing plus romantic :p

Working life without the bling. The creek is one of my favourite places to visit as you get to see the real Dubai without the bling and Glitz . Crossing the creek only costs 1 aed and is well worth it

A lazy ride on the creek. The creek is a wonderful way to take in sites in Dubai. We took an Abra ride for 15 minutes and it was a gorgeous scorching Dubai afternoon.Nice to see how locals travel - Just 1 Dirham to get across to the spice souk etc.

The old part of town. Don't get too caught up in the glitz and modern part of Dubai. The old part around Dubai Creek is fascinating. Be sure to ride the abra across the creek for 30 cents. They are little wooden motor boats that connect the Dubai and Bur Dubai sides and the wonderful markets. On the Dubai side are the Spice Market and Gold Souk. On the Bur Dubai side is the Old Market.
A step into the past. A really great place to stroll and take in the hussle and bussle of everyday life. You can take a cruise or just cross the Creek by water taxi

Wow. This place comes alive at night with all the people and the lights. You can catch an Abra (wooden boat) across the creek - only 2 dhirams. you can visit all the souks, meena bazaar, Bastikaya (old Dubai), the Dubai museum - all siuated around the creek. Good place to buy souveniers - don't forget to haggle.......

The old and the new Dubai. I crossed the Creek almost at sunset hour, sailing on a precarious flat boat with local workers going back home. It was safe and gave me a glimpse of lower medium class lifestyle.
Interesting. An insight to the old Dubai, completely the opposite to the modern skyscrapers and luxury resorts recently built.

Creek dinner cruise. I took the creek dinner cruise with Dubai Funtours for 180 dirhams. I had high expectations so it turned out to be just alright. Not much to see. After a while it got pretty boring. They did have Egyptian entertainment; dancers, etc. It wasn't something that I enjoyed a lot. I wouldn't recommend a tour with that particular company. I didn't get to walk along the shore either which I may have enjoyed more. I think a tour during the day would be much better.
ok day out. Pretty average day out . Would have liked to see more but found it boring.

Great experience. Travelling on one of the small wooden boats between the two sides of the Dubai creek is extremely cheap - only 1 dirham. Great way to get to the gold and spice souks from the Dubai museum side.
A great river trip. Went on the Dhow cruise along the Creek, this was a free trip whilst using the Big Bus tour and a very enjoyable leisurely trip with information being given over a PA on the boad.

Funny as a boat fight. First off, as this review is for the Creek itself, I will start by saying that it is a fantastic resource and well worth a trip by whatever means you choose. The sights on the river are almost as fascinating as the sights on the shore! Choose your time of year carefully if you don't want to get steamed slowly to death by the humidity though.The speed limit on the creek (estuary really) is posted loud and proud at 7 knots so it is as funny as hell watching the police boats planing up and down at 25-35 knots creating huge wakes that nearly tip the abras over along with the heaving masses clutching at their seats for want of a single life jacket amongst them!The mosques opposing each other over the water have a proper sound off going on with each competing for 'loudest and most distorted call to prayer' all at the same time... result? Pure noise pollution and surely no-one can understand a single word. Pity.We took a 'Dhow' dinner cruise (read: modern boat with tacked on wooden superstructure, not a Dhow at all) afterwards we had to re-live the experience and giggle that it was more like a river tour up the Ganges than the Dubai creek! Pure Indian culture, Indian food, Indian music and... wait for it (I kid you not!) an Indian conjurer complete with cheesy soundtrack and a tuxedo! Kids, you may need to Wiki 'conjurer'.Good fun but not a skerick of Emirati culture in sight, in fact Karama seems to have been given over totally to the subcontinent.
Dubai Creek. Lovely experience on the Dubai Creek. Able to see the beautiful buildings of the city.
Great experience.. Get a free boat trip along the creek as part of The big bus tour. Gives you a great insight as to how it all began!
Great Fun. A wonderful experience - and very reasonable. Took you across to the old area where there is an excellent museum - Heritage House.

The Real Dubai. Dubai can give the impression of being all steel and glass towers - as exciting as that may be for some. A vist to the Creek area however gives a different view of daily life. It's a busy environment both on the water and in the adjacent neighbourhoods. Markets, souks, businesses of all kinds - it's all happening.
More Sightseeing Options. Travel during the day, it is so beautiful, and you can take many photos too
Best place in Dubai. Get a 1D Abra ride at night for best value tourist trip in town

Great outdoor experience. The Dubai Creek Park is beautiful. Rent cycles and see the whole park. A wonderful outdoor experience. Carry your blanket and pack a picnic and you will have a memorable experience

definately worth AED1. Cross the creek on a dower for the the princely sum of A$33cents at the time. There are many floating resturants up and down the river, baeustifully lit up.Trading boats with men still loading them the way they have for hundreds of years. Actually saw an Indian bloke lug a fridge up a ramp and on board.PLUS THE gold souk, and spice market awaiting for you on the other side. One of the most wonderful experiences in Dubai/.

A trip back in time. We spent the morning around the Dubai Creek, visiting the various Souqs, my fave being the spice Souq with endless merchants selling many spices, curries etc etc. They're more than happy to tell you what each and everyone is for.We took the Abra from one side to the other, visited the textile Souq and had a lovely lunch at a restaurant called something Wakeel. The Abra trip while short was a really fun experience.Don't go too early as most shops don't open until 11ish.

nice place, very good dinner. With a lot less money than a dinner in Burj al Arab, not to mention they pick you up from and take you back to the hotel, I highly recommend this dhow cruise on Dubai Creek.
old Town. Been here a few times and always enjoyable, you can get loads of things here at really good value!!

See a different side to Dubai. It was lovely to see a different side of Dubai, and the Creek is certainly that. We loved the souks, and the atmosphere. We had a nice meal at a restaurant that overlooked the Creek, it wasn't expensive either. We made the trip across the Creek too, an experience but well worth it. It only costs 1 Dirham each about (17p). There are also cruises along the Creek too, if we'd more time that would have been nice to do. Dubai is a fabulous place to visit, with malls and tall buildings, but make sure you see the old part too. You see the old and the new making it a great experience.
old town of Dubai. old town of Dubai. use the abra boats to cross the creek "river" for only 1 AED. In Deira in the souk you can find authentic arabic restaurants with cheap prices.
Dhow Sail. Very slow moving trip, relaxing, you see "old" Dubai
Dubai Creek. After experiencing all that upscale, high end things that new Dubai has to offer, a visit to Dubai Creek will give an insight as to how "real" people lived and worked

Well worth it!. We hired a private boat for one hour across from the spice Souk. It costs 120 dhs (about $32). You get an hour around the creek with fantastic views of the amazing Dubai skyline plus a refreshing breeze for free!

Really neat at night. Such a nice place for a peaceful night walk when the old Dubai is illuminated and the souk still open on both sides of the creek! Nice and clean place, I would just welcome more sitting area and some open-air cafés along to sip the date shake while watching the dhows crossing the creek.

An interesting experience. One thing to note is that the area is dead during the day and only comes alive at night. However, for couples there are a number of places to relax and enjoy the scenery. There are a number of floating restaurants/dinner cruises ("dhows") that you can book a day in advance, or on the phone for a very reasonable price. Always haggle - There is no such thing as a fixed price..!!

Old natural Icon ... Free, nominal. Dubai Creek is one of the physical wonders of Dubai. It maintains its charm though numerous super malls, cloud kissing scrapers and competing attractions have come up in the vicinity. The creep is basically the sea jetting inwards dividing Deira and Bur Dubai. Deira and Bur are the central commerical areas, so it might be a quite a drive in case u are based in Atlantis or the marina. Cheaper option would be take the metro to Union station or Baniyas Square and walk from there or a direct a cab (standard distance based fares, one good thing about Dubai). Evenings are a good time for a nice walk, lots of shops and eating places line up either side. You could take a 2 dirham dhow crossing (one very 5 mins or so) from the Deira to Bur Dubai Souk (traditional market) or engage any of the upmarket cruises operating the dinner tours.Memorable Moments•Watching the fireworks (happens every night during the shopping festival, the bridges are also tastefully lit) on a traditional mega dhow operated by Radisson Blu Deira (one of the 5* down town options, which I can also recommend).•Watching the ever evolving Dubai skyline from the cruise, do carry a nice camera.•Splashing creek water on the low surface motor dhows operating across the creek.

Convenient creek crossing. The abras are a cheap and speedy way of crossing the creek. There is a station right outside the gold and spice souks. It is vital to ensure that you have the correct amount of money (1 dirham per person) as you don't always get change from the abra drivers

A taste of the authentic. This was a part of the city that hasn't been airbrushed yet.The short water taxi trip for 1 dirham was an experience as are the souks on the other side of the creek. Don't go on a Friday though it is thier holy day and not all of the stalls are open.
Beyond Compare. Wow, one word for Dubai Creek. Its exactly beyond comparison, primo, sans pareil, superlative, transcendent. All words for it.
Dinner with boat ride. The tour should be take in the evening as to see the lights on the river side. The food for this tour is arabic. Tour last for around 1 hour. Nothing much.
Lovely!. it is lovely place to walk around, you can take boat tour in the evening with dinner, great experience!
Genuine Dubai. This is some of the few parts of old Dubai worth visiting. It gives you a real sense of how this place evolved and starngely what it is still all about today as a crossroads for trade.

The board walk. The board walk serves great "bar" food however the main thing about this place is the location. You sit outside on a board walk hanging over the water edge looking at views of the whole of Dubai. I love it.
Old town. A lovely walk up the creek, you see all the boats and their merchandise coming in. Fridges, cookers etc right along the dock.
Not really a Creek. Interesting, but not a highlight for me. The dhows are fun to see, but the Creek area itself was not all that impressive to me.
Typical, fun, but not a ifelong experisnce. you take an old boat, you pay virtually nothing to cross, it is smelly and fun, but the surroundings are not to die for

The real Dubai. This gives visitors a glimpse of the real world in and around the Arab peninsula. The boats filling up with all types of wares, the sailors living under poor conditions, the Arab Muslim world in full swing!

Dubai's Area of Culture. Spend a day around the Creek area and you'll 'do' the historical and cultural part of Dubai in one foul swoop. It's one of the few areas of Dubai you can 'do' on foot - see the Dhows and Abras on the Creek, go across on an Abra (one dirham each way - so dirt cheap), walk along the crowded dockside in Deira (see all the goods stacked up), visit the spice, gold and cloth souks, visit Dubai museum (most of it is underground) Heritage Village, the Bastakiah area, a former Sheikh's house, even have an evening meal on the Creek in a restaurant dhow or the bateaux. Walk slowly, drink plenty of water and have lunch at Basta Arts Cafe.
Creek. Great area for local shopping. Good bargains to be found

a glimpse of the past. Essential viewing for Dubai visitors as the Creek casts its spell with its lively and cosmopolitan atmosphere.Creek Park is an absolute must-visit.It really is one of the city's greta parks and has lots of opportunity to people-watch and soak up the atmosphere of this great city.
lovely beach. lovely beach - although we missed sun umbrellas which are an essential with that kind of sun...

Great place to chill and eat. This area is fascinating during the day when the colourful wooden boats are packed sky high with a wealth of weird and wonderful products destined for Iran and other nearby & neighbouring countries. But it really comes into its own at night when everything is brightly and colourfully lit. Get the history of the area with a tour on an old wooden Dhow, then take a short ride across the creek and back on an Abra for 1 AED per journey, walk around the old markets and then eat on the riverside at one of the restaurants there or fill up on delicious local street food in the market.Finish off in "Dubai-Delhi" - the Indian quarter behind the old markets for a brief excursion into another new culture before going home.
This is the place to see the real Dubai. Take a walk along the Creek which is more like a river and take a water taxi too Both sides have much to do museums, places to eat and real Dubai life
Trip on a dohw. Very interesting area more cultural then new dubai and a trip on a dohw is a must
Absolute must do in Dubai!. A real slice of "old" Dubai. If the weather is suitable, take a couple of hours to stroll round the streets and markets. Do not miss the Fish Souq!

A Part of Old Dubai. This is the body of water that separates Dubai in two parts. It is lovely at night as all the Dhous( dinner boats) are lighted up. Many take dinner cruises along the water..One can also take an Abra across the creek for 27 cents and visit the spice and gold souks. ( markets)..A different look at Dubai but worth a visit.

Dubai Creek During my Stay in IC hotel. I really like his area especially it is quite compared to other Dubai area. You can enjoy dinner in one of the sea tour ships like Alboom which has a romantic dinner.Resturans are avilable in the Jashmal Mall near by the creek.
just for fun. get on the 1 dirahm boat before sunset what a lovely site

dubai's beautiful creek.... i love to look at our creek in the morning, when people do sports, run, or do yoga there. the birds fly around and sing. the wind blows a fresh breeze into my face. the sea is quiet. in the afternoon its so busy...you will see the creek at its peek time.in the evening...its just lovely!!
Love the atmosphere. Dubai is all glitz and glamour, until you go to the creek and you take a step back in time with an old world atmosphere - we love this area with it's history
Great boat ride. This is a cant miss it attraction in Dubai . Just walking along the souks takes one back to the old days.
Still living the Dubai way of life. View the abra's and dhows daily with their cargo or passengers in modern times.
Nice location for a stroll. A city park with an admission fee....they need more remote childrens play corners...some of the equipment shows ageing...time to replace
Good fun. Good experience was good value and saw some more of the sights

Worth a look. Dubai Creek is in the old city & separates Deira from Bur Dubai.
It is a wide waterway with little boats (abras) plying passengers back & forth and it only costs 1 dirham ! You can also take a Creek Dinner Cruise aboard traditional dhows which are brightly illuminated.

Old Dubai. An experience not to miss. A lot to see and do on Dubai Creek, traveeling across on the Abras from Deira to Bur Dubai for 1 Dirham each way as well as visting the markets of Bur Dubai and the Gold Souk in Deira.

A must for the real feel to old Dubai. We had just finished with the Museum and walked to the creek to take the boats over to the other side. We had the transport card that allows us to take the newer water taxis at a discounted price but we choose to take the traditional Dhow which is only 1 AED per person. Walking along the older streets of Dubai and taking the tradtional Dhow is an assult on the sense, sight, smell, sounds & feel. Squeezed wth many other passengers, tourist and many foreign workers we sat facing out along the dhow. The Creek was relatively clean with not much debri or smell. Along the other northern side where we alighted were many cargo ships loading or offloading goods which l understand was destined to other Middle Eastern countries. It was a hive of activities which was very interesting. The creek and old Dubai Area felt safe enough although we did get stares as we walked through old Dubai streets.I love the creek & old tranditional Dubai because its not tainted by comercial tourist setups..yet. Coming from a city where its modern and filled with Malls and Skyscapers, the creek & old Dubai area is a place I feels connects me to the real Dubai.
The thin line between old and modern Dubai. Ride on the abra for one dirham and experience the difference in Nayef Market or go to Creek Park to enjoy the greenery and scenery.
GOOD AREA TO VISIT. Enjoyable location to wander around the souks and cross the creek to visit the museum would recommend.

Great day out. Thoroughly enjoyed my time on the Creek with two children in tow. We crossed from side to side using the regular water taxi's which are very well priced and regular. Lovely walking around the various souques and was delighted to find water and cooldrink machines all in working order and easy to find.

What a trip.. This was another great moment of nearly two hours of boat ride in Dubai Creek, with excellent hot food served on the boat. Have a seat in the bottom deck, have your buffet meal & then go up to upper deck if there is no crowd. Fantastic view od Dubai by night.
nighttime wonderland. there are so many great restaurants in this enclave. there are light wrapped trees. it is so romantic.

A must visit. Take an Abra up the creek so to speak, it cost 120 Dirhams, there were just two of us. The boat was old, smelly and noisy but that was part of the fun. Great to see all of the cargo boats being loaded, unloaded with a huge variety of goods detined for various locations. The boats themselves are mainly wood and as seen at the dockside prone to fires and complete destruction.Also walk along the dock side to see the men sitting on sofas sellinng maily boxed electrical goods just imported or just about to be exported.
Nice Evening Outing. Its a nice and calm place to relax in the evening after a hectic sight seeing and shopping day... Nice, calm and relaxing!

very interesting....... our hotel was on the creek, which we found to be very central. we went for strolls a few times, along the creek, and found itvery interesting to see all the men working by hand, lifting and loading sacks and boxes onto the boats, usually without the help of cranes. we also rented a boat for one hour, for just the two of us, a pleasant relaxing time.the souks are within walking distance of the creek too, so plan sufficient time for this area. it's worthwhile!

Where old meets new .... Very interesting busy place, old Dubai, markets and shops, where the old meets the new. Well worth a visit or a dhow cruise or a visit to the gold souk. See all the old boats on the side loading and unloading their wears. Cheap water taxis across the creek.
Very interesting. Hired one of the typical wooden taxis for 30', very interesting to watch the town from the boat, all the traditional dows, and all sorts of people and cultures.
Nostalgic view. great place, must go to while in Dubai..A ride in the ABRA or the water boats will let you forget Venice..

Which place?. It's nice to visit the Creek, however, the question see it from where? Kan Zaman is Fair with Shisha .... Dhow cruse is nice but ask about which boat, sometimes services are bad in some boats!!! Wounder bus is a Great Value to feel the Creek

The real Dubai .... A good place to visit to see the real Dubai. Bustling markets, busy canal crossing, friendly vendors. A welcome change to what is often a soulless city ... the Creek allows you to experience some real Arabian charm
A genuine bit of an artificial city. Bustling with life and interesting things to see. Well worth an afternoon.

The only part of Dubai that feels authentic. Most of Dubai is glittery and fake but the Creek area, especially the Deira side is the oldest part of town and definitely maintains an authentic feel. I don't think you'll get any better deals there on souvenirs, but I'd still go shopping there, just for fun.
Interesting place.. A bustling and interesting place. Well worth a visit. One of the "have to" places to visit in Dubai just to have a look.
Water taxis. For 1 dirham, you can enjoy a ride of the water taxis. A must do if you're in Dubai.

good trip. We really enjoyed the trip on the creek. We took the dhow to the gold souk and then decided to hire the boat for an hour's trip down the creek. This was lovely, although don't expect the driver to be a tour guide.
Where it all started.. A hive of activity and the real Dubai is here. Must take an Abra to soak up the atmosphere.
Crossing by abra. Feel for old Dubai! Away from the high rise, shopping and madness.

Best Area to Spend Time. I've never been a 'mall rat'. I prefer the history and the variety of the Dubai Creek area. I have tried the street vendors and Dubai Creek Country Club and everything in between. Except to visit the fountains, if I travel to Dubai again, I'll not leave the creek area. Also, I've been there in June/July and you just move slower and later in the evening.

Don't do a dhow cruise just grab a water taxi... best way to see it!. The water taxis only cost 1 dirham and it really is the same as a dhow cruise without the feeling of being ripped off, being told boring and probably heard before facts from a recorded tourist cd. Also you get a feeling of being with all dubians... as everyone uses these and its a great link from Bur Dubai and the souks in deira. It's beautiful at sunset as this is when Dubai comes alive and if you can time it with call to prayer... lovely!

A 'must' to visit. One of the best experiences for us was taking an abra across The Creek. Well worth the pittance it costs and a decent ride too. Nearby are the Souks, the museum, etc, but a trip to The Creek is worth it for an abra trip alone.

Enjoy the 2 hour cruising. During day time, the creek is busy abras going by. The waterfront area is peaceful with some government building and souks. We had a dhow cruise dinner there with Salujia Cruise through local group purchase. The tables on the dhow was a bit crowded. But base on the cheap price (AED75 each), the service and the food are acceptable. We did enjoy the 2 hour cruising, though not too much lights to see at night.
Loving Dubai. If you want to see some of old Dubai, take a trip across the Creek to the Gold Souk, you will love it.
relax by the creek. It is a nice creek (althought) I am used to better ones... still, nice to hang around one day...

A taste of old Dubai with views of the new as well. The Creek is what Dubai was all about from its foundation until the 1990s. You can still see the traditional dhows (and a working dhow ship yard) that were the basis of its mercantile prosperity before the tourism and real estate booms. Take the abra or the water taxi as a cheap alternative to a Dhow Cruise, or enjoy a drink on the balcony of the Sheraton Creek at sunset , and take it all in!
Nice fireworks during DSF. Nice for an evening stroll and the 10 minute fireworks show every night during the Dubai Shopping Festival. Lot of street side shopping and food stalls.
Good place to visit. Good place to visit when in Dubai.It´s more typical then the other luxurious place as Jumerah, Downtown Dubai, Marina Dubai, The Palm Jumerah.
Could has watched the dows all day. What a fascinating place. The little dows dodging and weaving each other was amazing
best in Dubai. really lovely. the ols souks, the Abrataxi, the Dows, and just the atmosphere is great, don't miss it.
Interesting. It's water, what can I say. Still it is interesting to check out the harbour and the small ferry boats
Holiday. Its a nice place to visit when you find your self in Dubai. Lots of fun things to do aroung or to just hand out
Good for cool walk. Best relaxing palce & good for a cool walk. During shopping festival this place is packed just to see Dubai colorfull fire works at creek.
Fascinating. you must take a boat trip on a abras which ferry people between Deira & the bur dubai textile souks.it costs you a modest 1 dh.

The creek was relaxing. Took the Dhow ride in the Dubai creek. It was really nice to see all the hotels. Had our own boat for $25. You can bargain with them. Also went to the old Souk there. It really doesnt look old but it is fun. There are tons of text tiles there too.

driving a boat. The creek is a nice visit. You can take a water taxi across for 1 AD. When we were getting out we were offered a tour for 120 AD for an hour. We settled on going for 30 minutes instead (it was a little chilly on the water). It was lovely. A nice way to see the city night or day. The light at the front of the boat stopped working and my husband ended up driving the boat while the guy fixed the light! A fun time! Totally recommend this.
Its Dubais 'Central Park". Beautiful green area, well kept, infact immaculatey clean, nice for a stroll. Dont miss the dolphin show twice a day, very good
Worth a look.. Did the boat trip accross the creek from the Bastika area, a couple of times, and walked around the souks. Area is a lot more interesting than some of the new ones.

Best part of the city. Great day spent exploring Creekside park, the museum, wharf and souks. Loved the atmosphere and the bustle.Although they do pester you a bit , the traders do take no for an answer and I felt that this part of the city had much more soul than all the new buildings.
Dhow Dinner. Well worth the expense, especially if you are intending a romantic dinner with either your wife or girlfriend
Take a trip in a Abra. A landmark of Dubai. Foe the best experience take a trip on an abra crossing the creek, very inexpensive and enjoyable

a breath of freshness. we walked from gate four to gate 2 traversing the cable car route by foot (near the creek) and it was windy but fun. it shows a different side of dubai - natural, simple and free.next time we'll try the cable car
old meets new. Love the way the old traditonal dhows and abras met the new - sky scrappers and malls. A great walk along the reek side to watch the Dhows being loaded is an eye opener!

Make sure to take a water taxi or a tour on the water. We took the metro into Deira, walked along the Deira side of the creek (enjoying all the old boats that import goods from all over the Gulf region and Asia) and then took a water taxi to the Old Souk (we'd seen the Gold Souk in the past), then took the Metro back to the Dubai Marina area (about 1 hour trip) - check out a day pass - very reasonable - but not good on water taxis.
Busy. Visit the souks and take the water taxi . More interesting then the rest of Dubai
nice area. nice area for shopping or dinning you can walk it is very safe there
The vital water artery of Dubai. From fancy frontages to the fascinating dhow wharves, trips in dhows and crossings on the abras. Great place to people watch.
Lots to do at night. Stayed in a hotel overlooking the Creek. Lots of restaurants to choice from at Festival City. Take a trip on a dhow at night. Great place to spend a week.
nice, but polluted.. We dislike people throwing in lots of plastic bags and bottles. Educate them please

Interesting full of Character. I travelled up the Dubai Creek by speed boat, which doesn't go very fast. We also did a Dhow dinner cruise in the evening both gave us a chance to see the Creek at different times. If you get a chance walk on the North side by Deira here you can see all the sea going dhows loading and unloading their goods. Fab for watching.. Great photo opportunities if you travel along it sharing the new with the old.
Interesting area. We much prefer to stay in the Creek area rather than the beach. Always something going on and we love to watch the old dhows being loaded up with goods.
A Must do .... You have to go across the creek in an Abra. Pop over from the Spice and Gold Souk across the creek to the textile souk. Great chunk of sight seeing and shopping ...
On the creek. you can change sides from gold to spicy souk with little ships. Pay only 1 VAE for one way. Great and make pics

Still a hub of commerce. Having returned to Dubai after 25 years I found, amongst the vast expansion of the area, that the creek had managed to retain much of it's old charm with the old wooden cargo vessels still loading and unloading their wares and the water taxis still ferrying passengers for 1 AED
Nice to see!. I recommend going to the 'Textile' Souk near it and eat at a restaurant on the waterfront!
the real Emirates. If you are eager to see the real Dubai, go to Bur Dubai, look for the Creek, get an abra and you will enjoy it. I promise. But forget downtown: it's another world

Rikkis Dhow Boat Cruise. A word of warning - Don't book Rikkis Dhow Boat Cruise. The food was awful - they cut the trip short by 1/2 hour and our coaches weren't ready to take us back to the hotel so we had 100 people standing on the quay waiting. The Manager then proceeded to scream at the top of his voice that we were in the wrong and they hadn' broken the contract until we produced it and he realised he was badly in the wrong on several accounts. By that time everyone had heard him screaming at me. When he calmed down and apologised - he then asked when we would be making the next booking!- I don't think so. We will take our business back to the dessert safari - much safer bet.

Very interesting Dubai Creek & Souk. Very good atmosphere, finally something real in this extravagant city. Visit the Golk market and take the boat on the Abra; you can ask the captain for a private tour, just do it.
It was an intresting trip. The trip was lovely, very romantic, in the evening.
Lovely old style. Lovely to see a bit of old style dubai as opposed to the many wonderful new buildings. The old boats were good to watch
Relaxing river cruise. You can hire your own boat with driver for 120 Dirhams for a 1 hour cruise up the creek, a very enjoyable way to spend an hour.
great value for money. a picturesque setting, great food, real value and superb service

A quiet bit of hustle and authenticity. This is not the glitzy Dubai in all the pictures, but a working city. Take the little boat across the river and wander the spice market and streets with humble stores selling everything. Perfectly safe, if a bit gritty.

Dinner sailing - an industry - but very pleasant. We were 16 people joining on a Dhow ship for dinner on the creek, and had a great sailing experience, saw Dubai from the sea side and during night. Dinner was good (very Indian recipe) and the cost was low (about 180 AED per adult).

The birthplace of Dubai. The creek is where it all started for Dubai. The creek being a natural port, give birth to a thriving market with boats loading and unloading their cargos and people from different parts of the world doing business. Of course it was much smaller than what Dubai is today and it is difficult to visualise those early days of small fishing villages next to the creek but you still can catch a glimpse of that era by watching the wooden boats (called Dhows) taking in or unloading their cargos at the creek side. If you are visiting Dubai or even a resident of the city, you should do a creek cruise not only to get a feel for the city and its early days but also to look at the city from a different perspective. Of course if you want to avoid the over commercialised cruises then an alternative will be to cross the creek in an Abra, which will be much cheaper but you will see only a small portion of the creek.
A Must Do!. We splashed out and "chartered" our own dhow rather than a water taxi. We were on the water for about an hour and gave a different view of old and new Dubai side by side

great views. Using the Arbes to go between souks on both banks.
Having a trip on Dows in evening
Worth a look. Bustling. Amazing how the dhows make it out of the creek, though, let alone cross the Indian ocean. Fascinating to watch the activity as they are loaded up with every imaginable cargo.

Great entry point to Bur Dubai. We stayed in Deira and one afternoon we used abra to cross the Creek and get in Bur Dubai - the area where the old Bastakia district and Dubai museum are located. We also visited wonderful souks near the abra dock on the Bur Dubai side and then had a dinner in one of the floating restaurants. It's definitely worth spending an evening on the Bur Dubai side of the creek.

Cheapest 'thrill' in Dubai. Dubai Creek is in the seamy old section of Dubai and for people watching, is not for the squeemish. The Abras (boats) that ply between shores of the Souq are the best deal in Dubai. At 1 AED each way, hop aboard and huddle next to your neighbor so that they can pack another 5-6 folks on before departing. This is OLD Dubai, even if the Souq itself is cleaned up and contains as many Louis Vuittan and Rolex knockoffs in place of the (old days) dalah pots and rugs.
Birds 2 see. You got to sit in the abra ride for 1dhs only n enjoy the dubai creek n see lots n lots of birds here otherwise where u get to see birds in desert country ...........
great for a walk round. use the abra and the water bus to get to both sides of the creek, plenty of places to walk to and just to stand and watch is fascinating
The heart of Dubai. travel by abra, dhow or just view from the embankments. The loading of cargo on the dhows is entertainment itself
not to be missed. a bit of culture finally dubai is not all shiny and new, and i definately recommend a visit to the creek have ride on a boat its good fun and then go to the gold souk

Boat Cruise. Have a ride with the boat but haggle with the boat captains lol because you can get a whole boat for yourselves for very cheap instead of going into tourist once for even cheaper, you cant go wrong! Crouse its very nice with beautiful views at night time.

Fascinating Dhows but very busy shopping areas. We visited Dubai Creek Deira side mid-evening and it was very busy. The shops were full of tack and we ended up walking one end to the other then got a taxi to another area for the rest of our evening. We probably didn't see the full area as we should have but our experience was average, wouldn't be in a rush to go again.

Vibrant with Life. This is a great place of outing in Dubai. It gives a feel of river bank of any old city. The Rolex twin towers is now symbolic with the Dubai creek and so are the dhows and abras. It is great to take an abra ride for a short cross over. Still better would be one hour ride on Abra. They can be hired at Bur Dubai water taxi station. The seagulls flying across the waters provide great views and great place for photography too. Dubai Heritage Village is located close by. Can be approached by Dubai Metro's Ghubaiba Station.

Historic Dubai - So different then the modern one. Take a walk on both sides of the creek and see how ordinary folks from Dubai live. We were fascinated and spent several hours wondering the streets and discovering this area.

Old but Gold. You must visit the creek, to get a feel of old Dubai and where everything started. Glad it is still there to see and things haven't changed much. Do get on the Abra to cross over to the gold souq and great experience.
Great for walking. Creek Park and Promenade are lovely and a good way to walk of the fantastic food available in the area.
Never dissapoints. I used to live here back in 1977 and loved it then and still do when I visit. I take the Abra across the Creek to explore the shops.
relaxing. i have been to Dubai 5 times and always go to the Dubai Creek to smoke some shisha in the late evening

nice spot. Its beautiful to witness the salt creek which divides dubai in old and new city. The cruises called the floating hotels, the corporate houses, bank bulidings are good to view at from the land.
Well Worth a Visit. Definitely worth taking either a cruise or the water boat to visit the creek.
Take a water taxi. Only AED100 for a private trip up and down the creek - worth it but only in cool weather.

Good romantic walk or dinner. I had an aperitif on an arabic style restaurant terrace it was amazing to see the sunset from there.
If you are through with other attractions in dubai, keep a 40 minutes or a dinner for this spot

Old and nice. Old part of Dubai and a buzzing place.
If the weather isn't too hot it's a nice walk along the creek.
soak up the atmosphere. a walk along the creek and in the souks is an excellent way to sample the culture of old Dubai
Lovely Experience. Lovely park, plenty to do and amazing seeing all the families out for the day, complete with BBQ, deck chairs, pots and pans.
gate of city. creek has to face new and old if you want to see real Dubai

special experience. getting around on a dhow-style boat on the dubai creek with dinner and entertainment, enjoying the night silhouette or the day water traffic is something you should not miss to do when in dubai.
Old town. Nice to see the old part of the City. Actually, my favorite. Walk around the soaks and cross the creek by the little old boats, was great!
Ride a boat. There are many boats that offer different experiences on the creek. You can take a simple boat crossing which costs 1 Dinar or you can book a dinner boat ride.

Heritage Village is a small but hidden gem. I started my walk along the Creek at the Heritage Village next to the Al Shindagha tunnel. I accidentally cam upon the Heritage Village where a local Emirati Festival was taking place. It was fascinating and one of the few places in Dubai to see local Emiratis enjoing in public their rich culture and lovely haunting music. 200M south you earch the Abra station to the Souks. Up there with the Star ferry in Hong Kong for price and evocative views. Further down on the Bur Dubai side of the Creek,the historic Iranian Bastakiya quarter is a captivating warren of alleys and wind towers. See it at night for atmosphere and visit the gorgeous Basta Arts Cafe for lunch during the day.
go to textile souk and the creek. I love this part of town haggle hard and enjoy whats left of old Dubai
Worth the cross. It is really nice to walk along or to cross it using an abra. Get a glimpse of another side of Dubai life.

Atmospheric but ladies pls cover up!. Its a great area for walking, but ladies, wear some loose fitting long clothes otherwise you'll be the subject of unwanted attention from gangs of Indian blokes. It doesn't matter if your man is with you, you will still get wolf-whistled and leered after. Imagine walking past a building site in Britain and times it by 10. Other than that, its an interesting part of the city and plenty of photo ops can be had.

Nice. Visited in Jan when the Dubai Shopping festival was on. The place was full of tourists and had lovely lighting. the atmosphere was festive with lots of eateries, crafts shops and entertainers vying for attention. A cracker show is held in the evenings and that was the icing on the cake. In simple words it took my breath away. A nice evening spent at the creek and shall be cherished for a long time. Parking is difficult to find. So if you are driving, reach early or take public transport. Also there a number of boats offering sailing packages for about two hours with dinner thrown in. Do take this offer. For approx 100 AED it is worth it.
